en: Neti, the chief doorman of the underworld, paid attention to the instructions of his mistress. He bolted the seven gates of the underworld. Then he opened each of the doors of the palace Ganzer separately. He said to holy Inana: "Come on, Inana, and enter."

akk: ^d-inana ku4-ku4-da-[ni-ta]  gi-diš-nindan eš2-gana2 za-gin3 [šu-na lu2 ba-da-an-ze2-er]  abula 1-kam-ma ku4-[ku4-da-ni-ta]  tug2-šu-gur-ra men edin-na saĝ-ĝa2-na lu2 ba-da-an-ze2-er   ta-am3  ne-e  si-a ^d-inana me kur-ra-ke4 šu al-du7-du7  ^d-inana ĝarza kur-ra-ke4 ka-zu na-an-ba-e
en: And when Inana entered, { the lapis-lazuli measuring rod and measuring line were removed from her hand, when she entered the first gate,} the turban, headgear for the open country, was removed from her head. "What is this?" "Be silent, Inana, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. Inana, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld."

akk: abula 2-kam-ma ku4-ku4-da-[ni-ta]  ^na4-za-gin3 di4-di4-la2 gu2-na lu2 ba-da-an-ze2-er   ta-am3  ne-e  si-a ^d-inana me kur-ra-ke4 šu al-du7-du7  ^d-inana ĝarza kur-ra-ke4 ka-zu na-an-ba-e
en: When she entered the second gate, the small lapis-lazuli beads were removed from her neck. "What is this?" "Be silent, Inana, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. Inana, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld."

akk: abula 3-kam-ma ku4-ku4-da-ni-ta  na4-nunuz tab-ba gaba-na lu2 ba-da-an-ze2-er   ta-am3  ne-e  si-a ^d-inana me kur-ra-ke4 šu al-du7-du7  ^d-inana ĝarza kur-ra-ke4 ka-zu na-an-ba-e
en: When she entered the third gate, the twin egg-shaped beads were removed from her breast. "What is this?" "Be silent, Inana, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. Inana, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld."

akk: abula 4-kam-ma ku4-ku4-da-ni-ta  tu-di-da lu2 ĝa2-nu ĝa2-nu gaba-na lu2 ba-da-an-ze2-er   ta-am3  ne-e  si-a ^d-inana me kur-ra-ke4 šu al-du7-du7  ^d-inana ĝarza kur-ra-ke4 ka-zu na-an-ba-e
en: When she entered the fourth gate, the "Come, man, come" pectoral was removed from her breast. "What is this?" "Be silent, Inana, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. Inana, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld."

akk: abula 5-kam-ma ku4-ku4-da-ni-ta  ḫar kug-sig17 šu-na lu2 ba-da-an-ze2-er   ta-am3  ne-e  si-a ^d-inana me kur-ra-ke4 šu al-du7-du7  ^d-inana ĝarza kur-ra-ke4 ka-zu na-an-ba-e
en: When she entered the fifth gate, the golden ring was removed from her hand. "What is this?" "Be silent, Inana, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. Inana, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld."

akk: abula 6-kam-ma ku4-ku4-da-ni-ta  gi-diš-nindan eš2-gana2 za-gin3 šu-[na] lu2 ba-da-an-ze2-er   ta-am3  ne-e  si-a ^d-inana me kur-ra-ke4 šu al-du7-du7  ^d-inana ĝarza kur-ra-ke4 ka-zu na-an-ba-e
en: When she entered the sixth gate, the lapis-lazuli measuring rod and measuring line were removed from her hand. "What is this?" "Be silent, Inana, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. Inana, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld."

akk: abula 7-kam-ma ku4-ku4-da-ni-ta  [^tug2-pala3] tug2 nam-nin-a bar-ra-na lu2 ba-da-an-ze2-er   ta-am3  ne-e  si-a ^d-inana me kur-ra-ke4 šu al-du7-du7  ^d-inana ĝarza kur-ra-ke4 ka-zu na-an-ba-e
en: When she entered the seventh gate, the pala dress, the garment of ladyship, was removed from her body. "What is this?" "Be silent, Inana, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. Inana, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld."

akk: gam-gam-ma-ni tug2 zil-zil-la-ni-ta lu2 ma-an-de6  nin9-a-ni ^ĝiš-gu-za-ni-ta im-ma-da-an-zig3  e-ne ^ĝiš-gu-za-ni-ta dur2 im-mi-in-ĝar  ^d-a-nun-na di-kud 7-bi igi-ni-še3   igi mu-ši-in-bar  i-bi2  uš2-a-kam  inim i-ne-ne inim lipiš gig-ga-am3  gu3 i-ne-de2 gu3 nam-tag-tag-ga-am3  munus tur5-ra uzu niĝ2 sag3-ga-še3 ba-an-kur9  uzu niĝ2 sag3-ga ^ĝiš-gag-ta lu2 ba-da-an-la2
en: After she had crouched down and had her clothes removed, they were carried away. Then she made her sister Ereškigala rise from her throne, and instead she sat on her throne. The Anuna, the seven judges, rendered their decision against her. They looked at her -- it was the look of death. They spoke to her -- it was the speech of anger. They shouted at her -- it was the shout of heavy guilt. The afflicted woman was turned into a corpse. And the corpse was hung on a hook.

akk: [ud 3] ĝi6 3-am3 um-ta-zal-la-ta  sukkal-a-ni ^d-nin-šubur-ra-ke4  sukkal inim sag9-sag9-ga-ni  ra-gaba inim ge-en-ge-en-na-ni  inim nin-a-na-še3 ĝeštug2 ba-ši-in-gub
en: After three days and three nights had passed, her minister Ninšubur { , her minister who speaks fair words, her escort who speaks trustworthy words,} {carried out the instructions of her mistress} { did not forget her orders, she did not neglect her instructions}.

akk: [na] de5-[ga]-ni šu nu-bar-re  [inim] dug4-ga-ni gu2-ni la-ba-ši-šub  er2 du6-du6-dam mu-un-na-ĝa2-ĝa2  [šem3] gu2-en-na mu-un-du12-a  e2 diĝir-re-e-ne-ke4 mu-un-na-niĝin2-niĝin2  igi-ni mu-un-[na]-ḫur giri17-ni mu-un-ḫur  ki lu2-da nu-«u6»-di ḫaš4-gal-a-ni mu-un-na-ḫur   mu-lu  nu-tuku-gin7 tug2 dili-a /im\-[ma]-an-mur10  [e2-kur] e2 ^d-en-lil2-la2-še3 ĝiri3-ni dili mu-un-gub
en: She made a lament for her in her ruined . She beat the drum for her in the sanctuaries. She made the rounds of the houses of the gods for her. She lacerated her eyes for her, she lacerated her nose. In private she lacerated her buttocks for her. Like a pauper, she clothed herself in a single garment, and all alone she set her foot in the E-kur, the house of Enlil.

akk: [e2-kur] e2 ^d-en-lil2-la2-še3 ku4-ku4-da-ni-ta  [igi] [^d-en-lil2-la2]-še3 er2 im-ma-še8-še8  [a-a]  [^d-mu-ul-lil2] du5-mu-zu mu-lu  kur-ra nam-ba-da-an-gam-e  [kug] sag9-ga-zu [saḫar kur]-/ra\-ka nam-ba-[da-ab-šar2]-e  [^na4-za-gin3] sag9-ga-zu za zadim-ka nam-[ba-da-an]-si-il-si-il  [^ĝiš-taškarin-zu] ĝiš nagar-ra-ka nam-ba-[dar]-/dar\-re  [ki-sikil]  /^d-\ga-ša-an-na  kur-ra nam-ba-da-[an]-gam-e
en: When she had entered the E-kur, the house of Enlil, she lamented before Enlil: "Father Enlil, don't let anyone kill your daughter in the underworld. Don't let your precious metal be alloyed there with the dirt of the underworld. Don't let your precious lapis lazuli be split there with the mason's stone. Don't let your boxwood be chopped up there with the carpenter's wood. Don't let young lady Inana be killed in the underworld."

akk: [a-a] [^d-]en-lil2 lipiš bal-a-ni ^d-nin-šubur-ra-ke4 mu-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4  [dumu-ĝu10] an gal  ki gal   [^d-inana] an gal  ki gal   me kur-ra me  sa2 bi2-in-dug4-[ga-bi kur]-/re\ ḫe2-eb-us2  a-ba-am3 ki-bi sa2 in-na-an-dug4 [ed3-de3]
en: In his rage Father Enlil answered Ninšubur: "My daughter craved the great heaven and she craved the great below as well. Inana craved the great heaven and she craved the great below as well. The divine powers of the underworld are divine powers which should not be craved, for whoever gets them must remain in the underworld. Who, having got to that place, could then expect to come up again?"

akk: a-a ^d-en-lil2 inim-bi nu-mu-na-gub urim2^ki--[še3] ba-ĝen  urim2^ki- [e2-mud]-kur-ra-ka  e2-kiš-nu-ĝal2 [e2 ^d-nanna-še3 ku4-ku4-da-ni]-ta  igi ^d-nanna-še3 er2 [im-ma]-še8-še8  a-a ^d-nanna  du5-mu-zu mu-lu  kur-ra nam-[ba]-da-an-gam-e  kug sag9-ga-zu saḫar kur-ra-ka nam-ba-[da-ab]-šar2-re  ^na4-za-gin3 sag9-ga-zu za zadim-ka nam-ba-[da-an]-si-il-si-il-i  ^ĝiš-taškarin-zu ĝiš nagar-ra-ka [nam-ba]-da-[an-dar-dar]-re  ki-sikil  ^d-ga-ša-an-na  kur-ra nam-ba-da-[an]-gam-e
en: Thus Father Enlil did not help in this matter, so she went to Urim. In the E-mud-kura at Urim, when she had entered the E-kiš-nu-ĝal, the house of Nanna, she lamented before Nanna: "Father Nanna, don't let your daughter be killed in the underworld. Don't let your precious metal be alloyed there with the dirt of the underworld. Don't let your precious lapis lazuli be split there with the mason's stone. Don't let your boxwood be chopped up there with the carpenter's wood. Don't let young lady Inana be killed in the underworld."

akk: a-a ^d-nanna lipiš bal-a-ni [^d-nin-šubur-ra-ke4 mu-na-ni]-ib-gi4-gi4  dumu-ĝu10 an gal  [ki gal]   ^d-inana an gal  [ki gal]   me kur-ra me  /sa2\ [bi2-in-dug4-ga-bi kur]-/re\ ḫe2-eb-us2  a-ba-am3 ki-bi [sa2 in-na-an-dug4 ed3-de3 ]
en: In his rage Father Nanna answered Ninšubur: "My daughter craved the great heaven and she craved the great below as well. Inana craved the great heaven and she craved the great below as well. The divine powers of the underworld are divine powers which should not be craved, for whoever gets them must remain in the underworld. Who, having got to that place, could then expect to come up again?"

akk: a-a ^d-nanna inim-bi nu-/mu\-[na-gub  uru2-ze2-eb^ki--še3]  /ba\-ĝen   uru2-ze2-eb^ki-  e2 ^d-en-ki-ka3-še3 [ku4-ku4]-da-ni-ta  igi ^d-en-ki-ka3-še3 [er2 im]-/ma\-še8-še8  a-a ^d-en-ki  du5-mu-zu mu-lu  [kur-ra nam-ba]-/da\-an-gam-e  kug sag9-ga-zu saḫar kur-ra-ka nam-[ba-da-ab-šar2]-re  ^na4-za-gin3 sag9-ga-zu za zadim-ka nam-ba-da-an-[si-il-si]-il-i  ^ĝiš-taškarin-zu ĝiš nagar-ra-ka nam-ba-an-dar-dar-re  ki-sikil  ^d-ga-ša-an-na  kur-ra nam-ba-da-an-gam-e
en: Thus Father Nanna did not help her in this matter, so she went to Eridug. In Eridug, when she had entered the house of Enki, she lamented before Enki: "Father Enki, don't let anyone kill your daughter in the underworld. Don't let your precious metal be alloyed there with the dirt of the underworld. Don't let your precious lapis lazuli be split there with the mason's stone. Don't let your boxwood be chopped up there with the carpenter's wood. Don't let young lady Inana be killed in the underworld."

akk: a-a ^d-en-ki ^d-nin-šubur-ra-ke4 mu-un-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4  dumu-ĝu10 a-na bi2-in-ak ĝe26-e mu-un-kuš2-u  ^d-inana [a-na] bi2-in-ak ĝe26-e mu-un-kuš2-u  nin kur-kur-/ra\-[ke4] a-na bi2-in-ak ĝe26-e mu-un-kuš2-u  nu-u8-/gig\ /an\-na-ke4 a-na bi2-in-ak ĝe26-e mu-un-kuš2-u  a-a ^d-en-ki inim-bi ba-e-de3-gub  umbin-si-ni mu-dur7 ba-ra-an-de6 kur-ĝar-ra-aš ba-an-dim2  umbin-si 2-kam-ma mu-dur7 ba-ra-an-de6 gala-tur-ra-aš ba-an-dim2  kur-ĝar-ra u2 nam-til3-la ba-an-šum2  gala-tur-ra a nam-til3-la ba-an-šum2
en: Father Enki answered Ninšubur: "What has my daughter done? She has me worried. What has Inana done? She has me worried. What has the mistress of all the lands done? She has me worried. What has the mistress of heaven done? She has me worried." { Thus Father Enki helped her in this matter.} He removed some dirt from the tip of his fingernail and created the kur-ĝara. He removed some dirt from the tip of his other fingernail and created the gala-tura. To the kur-ĝara he gave the life-giving plant. To the gala-tura he gave the life-giving water.

akk: [a-a] ^d-en-ki gala-tur-ra kur-ĝar-ra gu3 mu-na-[de2-e]  1-am3 u2 nam-til3-la 1-am3 a nam-til3-la ugu-ni-a šub-ba-ab-ze2-en  ĝen-na-an-ze2-en ĝiri3 kur-še3 nu2-ba-an-ze2-en  ^ĝiš-ig nim-gin7 dal-dal-e-de3-en-ze2-en  za-ra lil2-gin7 gur-gur-re-de3-en-ze2-en  ama gan-e nam dumu-ne-ne-še3  ^d-ereš-ki-gal-la-ke4 i-nu2-nu2-ra-am3  mur kug-ga-na gada nu-um-bur2  gaba-ni bur šaĝan-gin7 nu-um-gid2  /šu^?-\-si-ni ^urud-lub-bi-gin7 am3-da-ĝal2  siki-ni ga-raš^sar--gin7 saĝ-ĝa2-na mu-un-ur4-ur4-re
en: {Then Father Enki spoke out to the gala-tura and the kur-ĝara:} " { One of you sprinkle the life-giving plant over her, and the other the life-giving water.} Go and direct your steps to the underworld. Flit past the door like flies. Slip through the door pivots like phantoms. The mother who gave birth, Ereškigala, on account of her children, is lying there. Her holy shoulders are not covered by a linen cloth. Her breasts are not full like a šagan vessel. Her nails are like a pickaxe upon her. The hair on her head is bunched up as if it were leeks."

akk: u-u8-a šag4-ĝu10 dug4-ga-ni  kuš2-u3-me-en nin-me a šag4-zu [dug4]-ga-<zu>-ne-[ne]  [u-u8]-a bar-ĝu10 dug4-ga-ni  kuš2-u3-me-en nin-me a bar-zu [dug4]-ga-<zu>-ne-[ne]  a-ba-am3 za-e-me-en-ze2-en  šag4-ĝu10-[ta] šag4-zu-še3 bar-ĝu10-ta bar-<zu>-še3 dug4-ga-na-ab-ze2-en  diĝir ḫe2-me-en-ze2-en inim ga-mu-ra-an-dug4  lu2-ulu3 ḫe2-me-en-ze2-en nam-zu-ne ḫe2-eb-tar-re  zi an-na zi ki-a pad3-de3-ne-ze2-na-am3  ed3^?--[…]-ab-ze2-en
en: "When she says "Oh my heart", you are to say "You are troubled, our mistress, oh your heart". When she says "Oh my body", you are to say "You are troubled, our mistress, oh your body".  "Who are you? Speaking to you from my heart to your heart, from my body to your body -- if you are gods, let me talk with you; if you are mortals, may a destiny be decreed for you." Make her swear this by heaven and earth. 1 line fragmentary"

akk: a id2-bi ma-ra-ba-e-ne šu nam-[ba]-gid2-i-en-ze2-en  a-šag4 še-ba ma-ra-ba-e-ne šu nam-ba-gid2-i-en-ze2-en  uzu niĝ2 sag3-ga  ga-ša-an-<zu>-ne-ne   niĝ2 lugal-me «en» ḫe2-a niĝ2 nin-me(source: bi) ḫe2-a šum2-ma-ze2-en dug4-ga-na-ab-ze2-en(source: dug4-ga-ma-ab-ĝen-ze2-en)  uzu niĝ2 sag3-ga ^ĝiš-gag-ta la2-a im-ma-da-ab-šum2-mu-ze2-en  1-am3 u2 nam-til3-la 1-am3 a nam-til3-la ugu-na šub-bu-de3-en-ze2-en  ^d-inana ḫa-ba-gub
en: "They will offer you a riverful of water -- don't accept it. They will offer you a field with its grain -- don't accept it. But say to her: "Give us the corpse hanging on the hook."  "That is the corpse of your queen." Say to her: "Whether it is that of our king, whether it is that of our queen, give it to us." She will give you the corpse hanging on the hook. One of you sprinkle on it the life-giving plant and the other the life-giving water. Thus let Inana arise."

akk: gala-tur kur-ĝar-ra inim ^d-en-ki-ka3-še3 saĝ keše2 ba-[ši-in]-ak-eš  ^ĝiš-ig nim-gin7 mu-un-dal-dal  za-ra lil2-gin7 mu-un-gur-gur  [ama gan-e] nam dumu-ne-ne-še3  [^d-ereš-ki]-gal-la-ke4 i-nu2-nu2-ra-am3  [mur] kug-[ga]-na gada nu-un-bur2  [gaba-ni] bur šaĝan-na nu-un-gid2  [šu-si]-ni ^urud-lub-bi-gin7 /an\-[da-ĝal2]  [siki]-ni ga-raš^sar--gin7 saĝ-[ĝa2-na mu-un-ur4-ur4]
en: The gala-tura and the kur-ĝara paid attention to the instructions of Enki. They flitted through the door like flies. They slipped through the door pivots like phantoms. The mother who gave birth, Ereškigala, because of her children, was lying there. Her holy shoulders were not covered by a linen cloth. Her breasts were not full like a šagan vessel. Her nails were like a pickaxe upon her. The hair on her head was bunched up as if it were leeks.

akk: [u3-u8-a] /šag4\-ĝu10 dug4-ga-ni  [kuš2-u3-me]-en nin-me a šag4-zu in-na-[ne]-eš  [u3-u8-a] bar-ĝu10 dug4-ga-ni  [kuš2-u3-me]-en nin-me a bar-zu in-na-ne-eš  [a-ba-am3] za-e-me-en-ze2-en  [šag4-ĝu10-ta] šag4-zu-še3 bar-ĝu10-ta bar-zu-še3 ba-e-de3-en-ze2-en  [diĝir ḫe2-me-en]-ze2-en inim ga-mu-ra-an-dug4  [lu2-ulu3 ḫe2-me]-/en\-ze2-en nam-zu-ne ga-mu-ri-ib-tar  [zi an-na zi ki-a] mu-ni-in-pad3-de3-eš  […]-/ed3\-de3-de3-eš
en: When she said "Oh my heart", they said to her "You are troubled, our mistress, oh your heart". When she said "Oh my body", they said to her "You are troubled, our mistress, oh your body".  "Who are you? I tell you from my heart to your heart, from my body to your body -- if you are gods, I will talk with you; if you are mortals, may a destiny be decreed for you." They made her swear this by heaven and earth. They …….

akk: id2 a-ba mu-ne-ba-e šu nu-um-ma-gid2-de3  a-šag4 še-ba mu-ne-ba-e šu nu-um-ma-gid2-de3  uzu niĝ2 sag3-ga ^ĝiš-gag-ta la2 šum2-me-eb in-na-an-ne-eš  kug ^d-ereš-ki-gal-la-ke4 /gala\-[tur kur-ĝar-ra] mu-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4  uzu niĝ2 sag3-ga ^ĝiš-gag-ta la2 im-me-ne-šum2-uš  1-am3 u2 nam-til3-la 1-am3 a nam-til3-la ugu-a bi2-in-šub-bu-uš  ^d-inana ba-gub
en: They were offered a river with its water -- they did not accept it. They were offered a field with its grain -- they did not accept it. They said to her: "Give us the corpse hanging on the hook." Holy Ereškigala answered the gala-tura and the kur-ĝara: "The corpse is that of your queen." They said to her: "Whether it is that of our king or that of our queen, give it to us." They were given the corpse hanging on the hook. One of them sprinkled on it the life-giving plant and the other the life-giving water. And thus Inana arose.

akk: ^d-ereš-ki-gal-la gala-<tur> kur-ĝar-ra gu3 [mu-na-de2]-e  tum2-mu-un-ze2-en  ga-ša-an-<zu>-ne-[ne]  […]-zu^?--ne-ne ba-dab5  ^d-inana inim ^d-en-ki-[ka3-ta] /kur\-ta ed3  ^d-inana kur-ta ed3-da-ni  ^d-a-nun-na-ke4-e-ne ba-ab-ḫa-za-aš  a-ba-am3 lu2 kur-ta im-[ta]-ed3-de3 kur-ta silim-ma-ni bi2-in-ed3-de3  ud-da ^d-inana kur-ta ba-ed3-de3  saĝ-dili saĝ-ĝa2-na ḫa-ba-ab-šum2-mu
en: Ereškigala said to the gala-tura and the kur-ĝara: "Bring your queen ……, your …… has been seized." Inana, because of Enki's instructions, was about to ascend from the underworld. But as Inana was about to ascend from the underworld, the Anuna seized her: "Who has ever ascended from the underworld, has ascended unscathed from the underworld? If Inana is to ascend from the underworld, let her provide a substitute for herself."

akk: ^d-inana kur-ta ba-ed3-de3  lu2 igi-na sukkal nu-me-a ^ĝiš-ĝidru šu bi2-in-du8  bar-ra-na ra-gaba nu-me-a ^ĝiš-tukul ur2-ra bi2-in-la2  gal5-la2 tur-tur gi-šukur-gin7  gal5-la2 gal-gal gi dub-ba-an-na-gin7 zag-ga-na ba-an-dab5-be-eš
en: So when Inana left the underworld, the one in front of her, though not a minister, held a sceptre in his hand; the one behind her, though not an escort, carried a mace at his hip, while the small demons, like a reed enclosure, and the big demons, like the reeds of a fence, restrained her on all sides.

akk: lu2 e-ne-ra in-ši-re7-eš-am3  lu2 ^d-inana-ra in-ši-re7-eš-am3  u2 nu-zu-me-eš a nu-zu-me-eš  zid2 dub-dub-ba nu-gu7-me-eš  a bal-bal-a nu-na8-na8-me-eš  kadra niĝ2 dug3-ge šu nu-gid2-me-eš  ur2 dam niĝ2 dug3-ge-eš nu-sig9-ge-me-eš  dumu niĝ2 ku7-ku7-da   dam ur2 lu2-ka ba-ra-an-si-il-si-il-le-eš  dumu lu2 du10-ub-ta ba-ra-an-zig3-ge-eš  e2-gi4-a e2 ušbar-ra-ka im-ta-an-e3-eš-am3  /ur2\ lu2-ka dam šu ti-a-me-eš
en: Those who accompanied her, those who accompanied Inana, know no food, know no drink, eat no flour offering and drink no libation. {They accept no pleasant gifts. They never enjoy the pleasures of the marital embrace, never have any sweet children to kiss. They tear away the wife from a man's embrace. They snatch the son from a man's knee. They make the bride leave the house of her father-in-law} { They take the wife away from a man's embrace. They take away the child hanging on a wet-nurse's breasts}. { They crush no bitter garlic. They eat no fish, they eat no leeks. They, it was, who accompanied Inana.}

akk: šum2^sar- niĝ2 sis-a nu-gum-e-me-eš  lu2 ku6 nu-gu7-me-eš lu2 ga-raš^sar- nu-gu7-[me-eš]  lu2 ^d-inana mu-un-ši-re7-[eš-am3]  ^d-inana kur-ta ed3-da-ni  ^d-nin-šubur-ra-ke4 kan4 ganzer-[ra-ka] ĝiri3-ni-še3 ba-an-šub  saḫar-ra ba-da-an-tuš tug2-mu-dur7-ra ba-an-mur10  gal5-la2-e-ne kug ^d-inana-ra gu3 mu-un-na-de2-e  ^d-inana iri-zu-še3 ĝen-ba e-ne ga-ba-ab-tum2-mu-de3-en
en: After Inana had ascended from the underworld, Ninšubur threw herself at her feet at the door of the Ganzer. She had sat in the dust and clothed herself in a filthy garment. The demons said to holy Inana: "Inana, proceed to your city, we will take her back."

akk: kug ^d-inana-ke4 gal5-la2-e-ne mu-un-ne-ni-gi4-gi4  sukkal  e-ne-eĝ3  sag9-sag9-ga-ĝu10  ra-gaba  e-ne-eĝ3  ge-en-gen6-na-ĝu10  [na] de5-ga-ĝu10 šu nu-un-bar-re   [e-ne]-eĝ3  ma-ra-[ab-dug4]-ga-ĝu10-uš gu2-ni [la]-ba-da-[an-ši-šub]  er2 du6-du6-dam ma-an-ĝa2-ĝa2  šem3 gu2-en-na ma-an-du12-am3  e2 diĝir-re-e-ne ma-an-niĝin2-niĝin2   i-bi2-ni  ma-an-ḫur giri17-ni ma-an-ḫur  /ĝeštug2\-[ga]-ni ki u6 di ma-ḫur  ki  mu-lu-da  nu-di ḫaš4-gal-a-ni ma-an-ḫur   mu-lu  nu-tuku-gin7 tug2 dili-a im-ma-an-mur10
en: Holy Inana answered the demons: "This is my minister of fair words, my escort of trustworthy words. She did not forget my instructions. She did not neglect the orders I gave her. She made a lament for me on the ruin mounds. She beat the drum for me in the sanctuaries. She made the rounds of the gods' houses for me. She lacerated her eyes for me, lacerated her nose for me. { She lacerated her ears for me in public.} In private, she lacerated her buttocks for me. Like a pauper, she clothed herself in a single garment."

akk: e2-kur-re e2  ^d-mu-ul-lil2-la2-še3   urim2^ki--ma e2 ^d-nanna-še3   uru2-ze2-eb^ki-  e2  ^d-am-an-ki-ka3-še3   ĝiri3-ni dili mu-un-gub  igi  ^d-am-an-ki-ka3  er2 bi2-še8-še8  e-ne  ma-a-ra  mu-un-til3-le-en  e-ne  ta-gin7 nam-ma-ra-ab-ze2-eĝ3-/en\-[ze2-en]   ga-an-ši-re7-de3-en umma^ki--a šeg12-kur-šag4-ga-še3 ga-am3-ši-re7-de3-en
en: "All alone she directed her steps to the E-kur, to the house of Enlil, and to Urim, to the house of Nanna, and to Eridug, to the house of Enki. { She wept before Enki.} She brought me back to life. How could I turn her over to you? Let us go on. Let us go on to the Šeg-kuršaga in Umma."

akk: /umma\[^ki--a] šeg12-kur-šag4-ga-ta  ^d-šara iri-ni-a ĝiri3-ni-še3 ba-an-šub  saḫar-ra ba-da-an-tuš tug2-mu-dur7-ra ba-an-mur10  gal5-la2-e-ne kug ^d-inana-ra gu3 mu-na-de2-e  ^d-inana iri-zu-še3 ĝen-ba e-ne ga-ba-ab-tum2-mu-de3
en: At the Šeg-kuršaga in Umma, Šara, in his own city, threw himself at her feet. He had sat in the dust and dressed himself in a filthy garment. The demons said to holy Inana: "Inana, proceed to your city, we will take him back."

akk: kug ^d-inana-ke4 gal5-la2-e-ne mu-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4  en3-du /du\ ^d-šara-ĝu10  umbin kud-ku5-ra-ĝu10 gu2-tar la2-ĝu10  en3  ta-gin7 nam-ma-ra-ni-ib-ze2-eĝ3-ĝen   ga-e-re7-en-de3-en bad3-tibira^ki--a e2-muš3-kalam-ma-še3 ga-an-ši-re7-en-de3-en
en: Holy Inana answered the demons: "Šara is my singer, my manicurist and my hairdresser. How could I turn him over to you? Let us go on. Let us go on to the E-muš-kalama in Bad-tibira."

akk: bad3-tibira^ki--a e2-muš3-kalam-ma-ta  ^d-lu2-lal3-e iri-ni-a ĝiri3-ni-še3 ba-an-šub  saḫar-a im-da-an-tuš tug2-mu-dur7-ra ba-an-mur10  gal5-la2-e-ne kug ^d-inana-ra gu3 mu-na-de2-e  ^d-inana iri-zu-še3 ĝen-ba e-ne ga-ba-ab-tum2-mu-un-de3-en
en: At the E-muš-kalama in Bad-tibira, Lulal, in his own city, threw himself at her feet. He had sat in the dust and clothed himself in a filthy garment. The demons said to holy Inana: "Inana, proceed to your city, we will take him back."

akk: kug ^d-inana-ke4 gal5-la2-e-ne mu-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4  ^d-lu2-lal3 zag e3-a a2 zid-da gab2-bu-ĝu10 us2-sa  e-ne  ta-gin7 nam-ma-ra-ab-ze2-eĝ3-en-ze2-en   ga-e-re7-de3-en ^ĝiš-ḫašḫur gul-la edin kul-aba4^ki--še3 [ga-an-ši-re7-en-de3-en]
en: Holy Inana answered the demons: "Outstanding Lulal follows me at my right and my left. How could I turn him over to you? Let us go on. Let us go on to the great apple tree in the plain of Kulaba."

akk: ^ĝiš-ḫašḫur gul-la edin kul-aba4^ki--še3 ĝiri3-ni-še3 ba-e-re7^re--eš  ^d-dumu-zid tug2 maḫ-a i-im-mur10 maḫ-a dur2-a dur2 im-ma-ĝar  gal5-la2-e-ne ḫaš4-a-na i-im-dab5-be2-eš  ^dug-šakir 7-e ga mu-un-de2-eš-am3  7-am3 X-TU-ra-gin7 saĝ mu-un-da-sag3-ge-ne  sipad-de3 gi-gid2 gi-di-da igi-ni šu /nu\-mu-un-tag-ge-ne
en: They followed her to the great apple tree in the plain of Kulaba. There was Dumuzid clothed in a magnificent garment and seated magnificently on a throne. The demons seized him there by his thighs. The seven of them poured the milk from his churns. The seven of them shook their heads like ……. They would not let the shepherd play the pipe and flute before her .

akk: igi mu-un-ši-in-bar igi uš2-a-ka  inim i-ne-ne inim lipiš gig-ga  gu3 i-ne-de2 gu3 nam-tag-tag-ga  en3-še3 tum3-mu-an-ze2-en  kug ^d-inana-ke4  su8-ba  ^d-dumu-zid-da šu-ne-ne-a in-na-šum2
en: She looked at him, it was the look of death. She spoke to him , it was the speech of anger. She shouted at him , it was the shout of heavy guilt: "How much longer? Take him away." Holy Inana gave Dumuzid the shepherd into their hands.

akk: lu2 e-ne lu2 mu-un-ne-re7-eš-am3  lu2 ^d-dumu-zid mu-un-ši-re7-eš-am3  u2 nu-zu-me-eš a nu-zu-me-eš  zid2 dub-dub-ba nu-gu7-me-eš  a bal-bal-a nu-na8-na8-me-eš  ur2 dam niĝ2 dug3-ge-eš2 nu-sig9-ge-eš  dumu niĝ2 ku7-ku7-da   dumu lu2 du10-ub-ta ba-ra-an-zig3-ge-eš  e2-gi4-a e2 ušbar-ra-ka um-ta-an-e3-eš
en: Those who had accompanied her, who had come for Dumuzid, know no food, know no drink, eat no flour offering, drink no libation. They never enjoy the pleasures of the marital embrace, never have any sweet children to kiss. They snatch the son from a man's knee. They make the bride leave the house of her father-in-law.

akk: ^d-dumu-zid-de3 er2 im-da-pad3 šex(SIG7)-šex(SIG7) i3-ĝa2-ĝa2  ĝuruš-e ^d-utu-ra an-še3 šu-ni ba-an-na-zig3  ^d-utu murum5-ĝu10-me-en ĝe26-e mussa-zu-me-en  e2 ama-zu-še3 i3 gur3-ru-me-en  e2 ^d-nin-gal-še3 ga gur3-ru-me-en  šu-ĝu10 šu muš-a u3-mu-ni-in-šum2  ĝiri3-ĝu10 ĝiri3 muš-a u3-mu-ni-in-šum2  gal5-la2-ĝu10 ga-ba-da-kar nam-mu-un-ḫa-za-ne
en: Dumuzid let out a wail and wept. The lad raised his hands to heaven, to Utu: "Utu, you are my brother-in-law. I am your relation by marriage. I brought butter to your mother's house. I brought milk to Ningal's house. Turn my hands into snake's hands and turn my feet into snake's feet, so I can escape my demons, let them not keep hold of me."

akk: [^d-utu er2-na] šu ba-an-ši-in-ti  [gal5-la2-e-ne] nu-ḫa-[ḫa-ne]  [šu-ni šu] muš-a mu-e-ni-šum2  [ĝiri3-ni] ĝiri3 muš-a mu-e-ni-šum2  [gal5-la2]-e-ne ba-ni-kar  [… muš]-saĝ-kal 1-gin7  [… ba-ni]-in-dab5-be2-eš-a  […]-/be2^?-\  […]-/eš\  kug ^d-inana-/ke4^?-\ […]-ni šag4-ga-ni nam-DU
en: Utu accepted his tears. { Dumuzid's demons could not keep hold of him.} Utu turned Dumuzid's hands into snake's hands. He turned his feet into snake's feet. Dumuzid escaped his demons. { Like a saĝkal snake he …….} They seized ……. 2 lines fragmentary Holy Inana …… her heart.

akk: kug ^d-inana-ke4  mu-ud-na-ni  er2 gig i3-še8-še8  [kug ^d-inana-ke4 …] [^d-]/dumu-zid-de3\ [(X)] šag4-ga-ni nam-[DU (…)]  […] dam-ni [(X X)] a2-na […]  […] NI [(X X)] X […]  […]-gin7 im-mi-[…] /im\-mi-X-[…]  ^u2-numun2 i3-bur12-re ^u2-numun2 i3-ze2-e  dam lu2 ur2-zu-ne-ne [nu2]-a me dam kal-la-ĝu10  dumu lu2 ur2-zu-ne-ne nu2-a me dumu kal-la-ĝu10  [me-am3]  [mu-lu]-/ĝu10\  me-am3 mu-un-KA×X-e  [me-am3]  [mu-lu]-/ĝu10\  me-am3 mu-un-TAG-TAG X-e
en: Holy Inana wept bitterly for her husband. 4 lines fragmentary She tore at her hair like esparto grass, she ripped it out like esparto grass. "You wives who lie in your men's embrace, where is my precious husband? You children who lie in your men's embrace, where is my precious child? Where is my man? Where ……? Where is my man? Where ……?"

akk: [nim-e kug] ^d-inana-ra gu3 mu-/na\-de2-e  [ĝe26-e ki] /lu2^?-\-zu ga-mu-re-[pad3] a-na-am3 niĝ2-ba-ĝu10-um  [kug] [^d-inana]-ke4 nim-e mu-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4  [za-e ki  mu-lu-ĝu10]  ba-ab-pad3-de3-en niĝ2-ba a-ra-ba-e  […] /ga\-mu-un-dul-dul
en: A fly spoke to holy Inana: "If I show you where your man is, what will be my reward?" Holy Inana answered the fly: "If you show me where my man is, I will give you this gift: I will cover ……."

akk: nim-e /kug\ ^d-inana-ke4 im-ma-an-[…]  ki-sikil ^d-inana-ke4 nim-e nam mu-ni-/ib2\-tar-re  e2 kaš-a-/ka\ zabar ĜIRI3^?- naĝ^?--a-ke4 ḫu-mu-ra-[X X]-a-ze2-[(X)]   du5-mu  /lu2\ kug-zu-ke4-ne-gin7 nam X […]  [i3-ne-eš2 nam]-tar-ra ^d-inana-ke4 ur5 ḫe2-/en\-na-[nam-ma-am3]
en: The fly helped holy Inana. Young lady Inana decreed the destiny of the fly: "In the beer-house, may …… bronze vessels …… for you. You will live like the sons of the wise." Now Inana decreed this fate and thus it came to be.

akk: […] er2 im-/še8\-še8  nin9^?- im-ma-ĝen šu-še3 mu-da-ab-si  i3-ne-eš2 me-le-e-a (X) X-/ĝu10\  /za-e\ mu MAŠ-am3 nin9-zu mu MAŠ-am3  ud za-e  ud-bi ḫe2-tuš-[e]  ud nin9-zu  ud-bi ḫe2-bur2-[e]  kug ^d-inana-ke4 ^d-dumu-zid saĝ-bi-še3 X X bi2-in-šum2-/šum2\-[mu]
en: …… was weeping. She came up to the sister and …… by the hand: "Now, alas, my ……. You for half the year and your sister for half the year: when you are demanded, on that day you will stay, when your sister is demanded, on that day you will be released." Thus holy Inana gave Dumuzid as a substitute …….
Holy Ereškigala -- sweet is your praise.

akk: ĝuruš šag4-ga-ni er2 im-si edin-še3 ba-ra-e3  ^d-dumu-zid šag4-ga-ni er2 im-si edin-še3 ba-ra-e3
en: His heart was full of tears as he went out into the countryside. The lad's heart was full of tears as he went out into the countryside. Dumuzid's heart was full of tears as he went out into the countryside. He carried with him his { shepherd's} stick on his shoulder, sobbing all the time:

akk: i-lu ĝar-u3 i-lu ĝar-u3 edin i-lu ĝar-u3  edin i-lu ĝar-u3 ambar inim ĝar-u3  al-lub id2-da girid2 i-lu ĝar-u3  bi2-za-za id2-da inim ĝar-u3 ama-ĝu10 inim ḫe2-em-me  ama-ĝu10 ^d-dur7-tur-ĝu10 inim ḫe2-em-me  ama-ĝu10 niĝ2 5-am3 inim ḫe2-em-me  ama-ĝu10 niĝ2 10-am3 inim ḫe2-em-me  ud-da ud ug5-ge-ĝu10 nu-un-zu  edin ama ugu-ĝu10 inim mu-e-de3-zu-un  nin9 ban3-da-ĝu10-gin7 er2-ĝu10 ḫe2-še8-še8
en: "Grieve, grieve, O countryside, grieve! O countryside, grieve! O marshes, cry out! O …… crabs of the river, grieve! O frogs of the river, cry out! My mother will call to me, my mother, my Durtur, will call to me, my mother will call to me for five things, my mother will call to me for 10 things: if she does not know the day when I am dead, you, O countryside, can inform my mother who bore me. Like my little sister may you weep for me."

akk: ud ul-e ba-nu2 ud ul-e ba-nu2 sipad ud ul-e ba-nu2  sipad ud ul-e ba-nu2-gin7 ma-mu2-de3 ba-nu2  i-im-zig3 ma-mu2-da i-im-bu-lu-uḫ2 u3-sa2-ga-am3  igi-ni šu bi2-in-kiĝ2 niĝ2-me-ĝar sug4-ga-am3
en: In ancient times he lay down, in ancient times he lay down, in ancient times the shepherd lay down. When in ancient times the shepherd lay down, he lay down to dream. He woke up -- it was a dream! He shivered -- it was sleep! He rubbed his eyes, he was terrified.

akk: tum2-mu-un-ze2-en tum2-mu-un-ze2-en nin9-ĝu10 tum2-mu-un-ze2-en  ^d-ĝeštin-an-na-ĝu10 tum2-mu-un-ze2-en nin9-ĝu10 tum2-mu-un-ze2-en  dub-sar im zu-ĝu10 tum2-mu-un-ze2-en nin9-ĝu10 tum2-mu-un-ze2-en  nar en3-du zu-ĝu10 tum2-mu-un-ze2-en nin9-ĝu10 tum2-mu-un-ze2-en  lu2-ban3-da šag4 inim-ma zu-ĝu10 tum2-mu-un-ze2-en nin9-ĝu10 tum2-mu-un-ze2-en  um-ma šag4 ma-mu2-da zu-ĝu10 tum2-mu-un-ze2-en nin9-ĝu10 tum2-mu-un-ze2-en
en: "Bring, bring, bring my sister! Bring my Ĝeštin-ana, bring my sister! Bring my scribe proficient in tablets, bring my sister! Bring my singer expert in songs, bring my singer! Bring my perspicacious girl, bring my sister! Bring my wise woman who knows the meanings of dreams, bring my sister! I will relate the dream to her."

akk: ma-mu2 ga-mu-un-na-bur2  ma-mu2-da nin9-ĝu10 ma-mu2-da šag4 ma-mu2-da-ĝa2  ^u2-numun2 ma-ra-zi-zi ^u2-numun2 ma-ra-mu2-mu2  gi dili du3-e saĝ /ma\-[ra-an]-sag3-ge  gi dili-dili du3-e dili ma-ra-an-ba9-re6  ^ĝiš-tir-ra ĝiš an-gin7 ni2-bi ma-ra-an-zig3-[ga]  ^dug-šakir3 kug-ĝa2 TUN3-bi ba-ra-an-ba9-re6  ^ĝiš-an-za-am kug-ĝu10 ^ĝiš-gag-ta la2-a ^ĝiš-gag-ta ba-ra-an-/si\-[ig]  ^ĝiš-ma-nu-ĝu10   ^d-nin-ninna2^mušen--ta-e ĝa2 udu-ka sila4 šu ba-ni-ib-ti  sur2-du3^mušen--e gi dub-ba-na-ka buru5^mušen- šu ba-ni-ib-ti  maš2-ud5-da-ĝu10 sun4 za-gin3-bi saḫar-ra ma-ra-an-gid2-e  udu-utua2-ĝu10 a2 gur-gur-ra-bi ki ma-ra-ab-ḫur-ḫur-re  ^dug-šakir3 i3-dur2-dur2 ga nu-un-de2
en: "A dream, my sister! A dream! In my dream, rushes were rising up for me, rushes kept growing for me; a single reed was shaking its head at me; twin reeds -- one was being separated from me. Tall trees in the forest were rising up together over me. Water was poured over my holy {coals} { brazier} for me, the cover of my holy churn was removed, my holy drinking cup was torn down from the peg where it hung, my shepherd's stick disappeared from me. An owl took a lamb from the sheep house, a falcon caught a sparrow on the reed fence, my male goats were dragging their dark beards in the dust for me, my rams were scratching the earth with their thick legs for me. The churns were lying on their sides, no milk was being poured, the drinking cups were lying on their sides, Dumuzid was dead, the sheepfold was haunted."

akk: an-za-am i3-dur2-dur2 ^d-dumu-zid nu-til3 amaš lil2-la2-am3 al-du3  ^d-ĝeštin-an-na-ke4 ^d-dumu-zid mu-un-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4  šeš-ĝu10 ma-mu2-zu nu-sag9-sag9 nam-ma-an-bur2-e  ^d-dumu-zid ma-mu2-zu nu-sag9-sag9 nam-ma-an-bur2-e  ^u2-numun2 ma-ra-an-zi-zi ^u2-numun2 ma-ra-an-mu2-mu2  sa-gaz šubtum6-ta ma-ra-an-zig3-ga  gi dili du3-e saĝ ma-ra-an-sag3-ge  ama ugu-zu saĝ ma-ra-an-sag3-ge  gi dili-dili du3-e dili ma-ra-an-ba9-re6  ĝe26-e u3 za-e dili ma-ra-an-bad-ba9-re6  ^ĝiš-tir-ra ĝiš an ni2-bi ma-ra-an-zi-zi  lu2 ḫul-ĝal2-e i-zi-a im-mu-e-ni-dab5-be2  ne-mur kug-zu a mu-da-an-de2  amaš e2 sig9-ga ba-e-de3-ĝa2-ĝa2  ^dug-šakir3 kug-zu TUN3-bi ma-ra-an-ba9-re6  lu2 ḫul-ĝal2-e šu-na ba-e-ni-in-ku4-ku4
en: Ĝeštin-ana answered Dumuzid: "My brother, your dream is not favourable, don't tell me any more of it! Dumuzid, your dream is not favourable, don't tell me any more of it! The rushes rising up for you, which kept growing for you, are bandits rising against you from their ambush. The single reed shaking its head at you is your mother who bore you, shaking her head for you. The twin reeds of which one was being separated from you is you and I -- one will be separated from you. The tall trees in the forest rising up together over you are the evil men catching you within the walls. That water was poured over your holy coals means the sheepfold will become a house of silence. That the cover of your holy churn was removed for you means the evil man will bring it inside in his hands."

akk: an-za-am kug ^ĝiš-gag-ta la2-a ^ĝiš-gag-ta ba-ra-an-si-ig  du10-ub ama ugu-za-ta ba-ra-šub-bu-de3  ^ĝiš-ma-nu-zu   ^d-nin-ninna2^mušen--ta-e ĝa2 udu-ka sila4 šu ba-ni-ib-ti  sur2-du3^mušen--e gi dub-ba-an-ka buru5 šu ba-ni-ib-ti  [^dug-]/šakir3\ i3-[dur2]-dur2 [ga nu-un-de2] an-za-am i3-dur2-dur2 ^d-dumu-zid nu-un-til3 amaš lil2-la2 am3-du3  šu-zu šu-du3-[a ba-e-dab5] a2-zu a2-la2-e ba-e-la2  maš2-ud5-da-zu sun4 za-gin3-bi saḫar-ra ma-ra-an-gid2-e  siki-ĝu10 mar-uru5-gin7 an-na ma-ra-ni10-ni10-e  udu-utua2-zu a2 gur-gur-ra-bi ki ma-ra-ab-ḫur-ḫur-re  šu-si-ĝu10 ^ĝiš-bulug taškarin-gin7 te ma-ra-ab-ḫur-ḫur-re
en: "Your holy drinking cup torn down from the peg where it hung is you falling off the lap of the mother who bore you. That your shepherd's stick disappeared from you means the demons {will set fire to it} { will smash it}. The owl taking a lamb from the sheep house {is the evil man who will hit you on the cheek} { is the evil man who will destroy the sheep house}. The falcon catching a sparrow on the reed fence is the big demon coming {down} { out} from the sheep house. That the churns were lying on their sides, no milk was being poured, the drinking cups were lying on their sides, that Dumuzid was dead, and the sheepfold haunted, means your hands will be bound in handcuffs, your arms will be bound in fetters. That your male goats were dragging their dark beards in the dust for you means that my hair will whirl around in the air like a hurricane for you. That your rams were scratching the earth with their thick legs for you means that I shall lacerate my cheeks with my fingernails for you as if with a boxwood needle."

akk: inim-bi ka-ga14-na um-ma-da-ĝa2-ĝa2  nin9 du6-da ed3-bi2 nin9 du6-da ed3-[bi2]  nin9 du6-da ed3-da-/zu\-[ne]  du6-da lu2-ulu3-gin7 nam-ed3-da-[nam]  tug2-za ḫaš4-za u3-/mu\-[ni-ḫur]  nin9 du6-da ed3-bi2  nin9 du6-da ed3-/da\-[zu-ne]  du6-da igi il2-la-[ab]  am3-ma^?--an-gig lipiš bal nam-lu2-/ulu3\-[ke4-ne]  ^ĝiš-ma2-gur8 id2-da AM3 X […]  ĝiš šu-ka šu am3-/mi\-[in-du8]  ĝiš gu2-ka ba-an-pad3 bur2-[bur2-bi lu2 nu-zu]
en: Hardly had she spoken these words when he said, "Sister, go up onto the mound, sister, go up onto the mound! Sister, when you go up onto the mound, do not go up onto the mound like an ordinary person, but lacerate {your heart} { your hair} and your liver, lacerate your clothes and your crotch, sister, and then go up onto the mound! Sister, when you go up onto the mound, look out from the mound! The evil ……, hated by men, …… a river barge! They hold in their hands the wood to bind the hands, they are identified from the wood to bind the neck -- no man knows how to undo it!"

akk: ama-^d-ĝeštin-an-na-ke4 du6-da ba^?--[an-ed3 igi] ba-[an]-il2 X […]  ^d-ĝeštin-an-na-ke4 gu2 um-ma-da-[gid2]  ma-la-ga-ni ^d-ĝeštin-du3-du3-e ad^?- […]  gu2^?- keše2-da gal-gal mu-un-ši-/re7\-[eš …] mu-un-ši-[re7-eš]
en: Ama-ĝeštin-ana went up onto the mound and looked around, Ĝeštin-ana craned her neck. Her girl friend Ĝeštin-dudu advised her: "The big men who bind the neck are already coming for him, they are …… coming for him!"

akk: ad ĝar-ra ma-la-ĝu10 mu-ši-re7^re^?---[eš]  gu2 keše2-da ĝe26-e mu-ni-in-/pad3\-[de3]  šeš-ĝu10 gal5-la2-zu im-ši-re7-[eš saĝ u2-a šub-u3]  [^d-dumu]-zid gal5-la2-zu im-ši-re7-eš saĝ u2-[a šub-u3]
en: "My adviser and girl friend! Are they coming?" "Yes, I will point out to you those who bind the neck!" "My brother, your demons are coming for you! Duck down your head in the grass! Dumuzid, your demons are coming for you! Duck down your head in the grass!"

akk: nin9-ĝu10 saĝ u2-a ga-an-šub ki-ĝu10 na-ab-/pad3\-[de3]  saĝ u2 di4-di4-la2 ga-an-šub ki-ĝu10 na-ab-pad3-de3  saĝ u2 gal-gal-la ga-an-šub ki-ĝu10 na-ab-pad3-de3  eg2 a-ra-li-ka ga-an-šub ki-ĝu10 na-ab-pad3-de3
en: "My sister, I will duck down my head in the grass! Don't reveal my whereabouts to them! I will duck down my head in the short grass! Don't reveal my whereabouts to them! I will duck down my head in the tall grass! Don't reveal my whereabouts to them! I will drop down into the ditches of Arali! Don't reveal my whereabouts to them!"

akk: ud ki-zu ab-pad3-de3-en-na-a ur-zu ḫu-mu-gu7-e  ur gig2 ur nam-sipad-da-zu  ur gir15 ur nam-en-na-zu ur-zu ḫu-mu-gu7-e
en: "If I reveal your whereabouts to them, may your dog devour me! The black dog, your shepherd dog, the noble dog, your lordly dog, may your dog devour me!"

akk: ĝeštug2^?- mu-un-de5-ge [X] X na-ba gu5-li-zu de5-ga  [a šeš-ĝu10] gu5-li dub3-sa  [X] X-gin7 na-[an]-tuku-nam  [X X] X X [mi-ni-in]-/kiĝ2\-kiĝ2-a-ta  X-bi-a inim X [X] u3-mu-ra-ab-dug4
en: She remembered : "…… give your friend instructions about it! O my brother, may you never have a friend or comrade like ……! After the demons have searched for you, ……, if he tells you ……."

akk: gu5-li-ĝu10 saĝ u2-a ga-an-šub ki-ĝu10 na-ab-pad3-de3  saĝ u2 di4-di4-la2 ga-an-šub ki-ĝu10 na-ab-pad3-de3  saĝ u2 gal-gal-la ga-an-šub ki-ĝu10 na-ab-pad3-de3  eg2 a-ra-li ga-an-šub ki-ĝu10 na-ab-pad3-de3
en: "My friend, I will duck down my head in the grass! Don't reveal my whereabouts to them! I will duck down my head in the short grass! Don't reveal my whereabouts to them! I will duck down my head in the tall grass! Don't reveal my whereabouts to them! I will drop down into the ditches of Arali! Don't reveal my whereabouts to them!"

akk: ud ki-zu ab-pad3-de3-en-na-a ur-zu ḫu-mu-gu7-e-en  ur gig2 ur nam-sipad-da-zu  ur gir15 ur nam-en-na-zu ur-zu ḫu-mu-gu7-en
en: "If I reveal your whereabouts to them, may your dog devour me! The black dog, your shepherd dog, the noble dog, your lordly dog, may your dog devour me!"

akk: lugal-ra lu2 mu-<ši>-re7-eš-am3 lu2 ḫi-ḫi-a-me-eš  u2 nu-zu-me-eš a nu-zu-me-eš  zid2 dub-dub-ba nu-gu7-me-eš  a bal-bal-a nu-na8-na8-me-eš  kadra niĝ2 dug3-ga šu nu-gid2-i-me-eš  ur2 dam niĝ2 dug3-ge-eš2 nu-sig9-ge-me-eš  dumu niĝ2 ku7-ku7-da   šum2^sar- niĝ2 sis-am3 zu2 nu-gub-bu-me-eš  lu2 ku6 nu-gu7-me-eš lu2 ga-raš^sar- nu-gu7-me-eš  lugal-ra dumu adab^ki--a 2-am3 mu-un-ši-re7^re--eš  ^ĝiš-kiši16 a šu-ru-ug-ga ^ĝiš-dala2 a ḫab2-ba  šu-ni ^ĝiš-banšur-ra eme-ni e2-gal-la  lugal-ra dumu akšak^ki- 2-am3 mu-un-ši-re7^re--eš  lugal-ra dumu unug^ki--ga 2-am3 mu-un-ši-re7^re--eš  ^ĝiš-tukul saĝ kud-a ur2-ra la2-a  lugal-ra dumu urim2^ki--ma 2-am3 mu-un-ši-re7^re--eš  lugal-ra dumu nibru^ki- 2-am3 mu-un-ši-re7^re--eš  lu2 lu2-ra im2-ma-ni-ib amaš ^e2-tur3-še3 <mu-un>-ši-re7^re--eš  ^d-ĝeštin-an-na-ke4 amaš tur3-še3 mu-ni-in-dab5-be2-ne  id2 a-ba mu-un-na-ba-e-ne šu /nu\-[um]-ma-gid2-de3  a-šag4 še-ba mu-un-/na\-[ba]-e-ne šu [nu]-um-ma-/gid2\-[de3]  gal5-la2 tur-re gal5-la2 gu-la-[ra gu3 mu]-/un\-na-de2-e  gal5-la2 kug-zu gal5-la2 til3-la  gal5-la2 gal-/bi\ murub4-bi til3-la  kug-zu [X ba]-/an\-da-ḫa-lam-ma-gin7  X X X-še3 ba-an-gib-ba-gin7  nin9 ki šeš am3-mu-un-pad3-de3-a
en: Those who come for the king are a motley crew, who know not food, who know not drink, who eat no sprinkled flour, who drink no poured water, who accept no pleasant gifts, who do not enjoy a wife's embraces, who never kiss dear little children, who never chew sharp-tasting garlic, who eat no fish, who eat no leeks. There were two men of Adab who came for the king. They were thistles in dried-up waters, they were thorns in stinking waters -- 'his hand was on the table, his tongue was in the palace' . Then there were two men of Akšak who came for the king, with …… carried on their shoulders. Then there were two men of Unug who came for the king. With head-smashing clubs tied to their waists, there were two men of Urim who came for the king. With {shining} { clean} clothes on the quayside, there were two men of Nibru who came for the king. Crying "Man run after man!", they came to the sheepfold and cow-pen. They caught Ĝeštin-ana at the sheepfold and cow-pen. They offered a river of water, but she wouldn't accept it. They offered her a field of grain, but she wouldn't accept it. The little demon spoke to the big demon, the wise demon, the lively demon, and the big demon who was between them, wise like …… destroying a ……, like …… barring a ……, they spoke:

akk: ud ul^?--la2-ta a-ba-a igi mi-ni-in-du8-a  ĝa2-nam-ma-an-ze2-en gu5-li-ni-ir ga-an-ši-re7-en-de3-en  ud ne gu5-li-ni-ir  id2 a-ba mu-un-na-ba-e-ne šu am3-ma-gid2-de3-«en»  a-šag4 še-ba mu-un-na-ba-e-ne šu am3-ma-gid2-de3  gu5-li-ĝu10 saĝ u2-a ḫe2-en-šub ki-ni ba-ra-zu  [^d-dumu-zid]-de3 saĝ u2-a ḫe2-en-šub ki-ni ba-ra-zu  ^d-dumu-zid-de3 saĝ u2-a mu-ni-in-kiĝ2-kiĝ2-ne nu-mu-un-pad3-de3  saĝ u2 di4-di4-la2 ḫe2-en-šub ki-ni ba-ra-zu  ^d-dumu-zid-de3 saĝ u2 di4-di4-la2 mu-ni-in-kiĝ2-kiĝ2-ne nu-mu-un-pad3-[de3]  saĝ u2 gal-gal-la ḫe2-en-šub ki-ni ba-ra-zu  ^d-dumu-zid-de3 saĝ u2 gal-gal-la mu-ni-in-kiĝ2-kiĝ2-ne [nu-mu-un]-pad3-de3  eg2 a-ra-li-ka ḫe2-en-šub ki-ni ba-ra-zu
en: "Who since the most ancient times has ever known a sister reveal a brother's whereabouts? Come! Let us go to his friend!" Then they offered his friend a river of water, and he accepted it. They offered him a field of grain, and he accepted it. "My friend ducked down his head in the grass, but I don't know his whereabouts { Dumuzid ducked down his head in the grass, but I don't know his whereabouts}." They looked for Dumuzid's head in the grass, but they couldn't find him. "He ducked down his head in the short grass, but I don't know his whereabouts." They looked for Dumuzid's head in the short grass, but they couldn't find him. "He ducked down his head in the tall grass, but I don't know his whereabouts." They looked for Dumuzid's head in the tall grass, but they couldn't find him. "He has dropped down into the ditches of Arali, but I don't know his whereabouts."

akk: ^d-dumu-zid-de3 eg2 a-ra-li-ka mu-ni-in-dab5-be2-ne  ^d-dumu-zid-de3 er2 im-ma-an-pad3 šex(SIG7)-šex(SIG7) i3-ĝa2-ĝa2  iri-a nin9-ĝu10 mu-un-til3-le-en gu5-li-ĝu10 mu-un-ug5-ge-en  dumu nin9-e sila-a ḫe2-en-gub lu2   dumu gu5-li sila-a ḫe2-en-gub lu2
en: They caught Dumuzid in the ditches of Arali. Dumuzid began to weep and was tear-stricken: "In the city my sister saved my life, my friend caused my death. If a sister leaves a child in the street, someone should kiss it. But if a friend leaves a child in the street, no one should kiss it."

akk: lu2 ba-an-niĝin2-niĝin2-ne-eš a-niĝin2 ba-ni-in-du8-uš  gu mu-un-na-sur-ru-ne sa mu-un-na-keše2-/da\-[ne]  gu zi-ip-pa-tum mu-un-na-sur-ru-ne  ^ĝiš-ma-nu mu-un-na-ḫur-ru-ne  lu2 igi-na-ke4 niĝ2 mu-un-ra-ra  lu2 murgu-na-ke4 1 kuš3-gin7 mu-un-bur2-[re]  šu-ni šu-du3-a ba-e-dab5-be2  a2-ni a2-la2-a ba-e-la2-e  ĝuruš-e ^d-utu-ra an-še3 šu-ni ba-ni-in-zig3
en: The men surrounded him and drained the standing waters. They twisted a cord for him, they knotted a net for him. They wove a reed hawser for him, they cut sticks for him. The one in front of him threw missiles at him, the one behind him …… one cubit. His hands were bound in handcuffs, his arms were bound in fetters. The lad raised his hands heavenward to Utu:

akk: ^d-utu murum5-ĝu10-me-en ĝe26-e mussa-/zu\-[me-en]  e2-an-na-še3 u2 gur3-ru-/me\-[en]  unug^ki--še3 niĝ2-mussa ak-a-me-en  nundum kug-ge ]  dub3 kug-ga dub3 ^d-inana-ka ]  šu-ĝu10 šu maš-da3 u3-mu-e-ni-[sig10]  ĝiri3-ĝu10 ĝiri3 maš-da3 u3-mu-e-ni-[sig10]  [gal5-la2]-gal5-la2-ĝu10 ga-ba-da-an-ze2-er  KU-^ĝiš-bir5-re-eš-dil-da-/re\-[eš] zi-ĝu10 ga-ba-ši-de6
en: "Utu, you are my brother-in-law, I am your sister's husband! I am he who carries food to E-ana, I am he who brought the wedding gifts to Unug, I am he who kisses the holy lips, I am he who dances on the holy knees, the knees of Inana. Please change my hands into gazelle hands, change my feet into gazelle feet, so I can evade my demons. Let me escape with my life to Ku-bireš-dildareš."

akk: lu2 arḫuš-a-gin7 arḫuš /ba\-[ni-in-ak]  šu-ni šu maš-da3 u3-mu-ni-in-sig10  ĝiri3-ni ĝiri3 maš-da3 u3-mu-ni-in-sig10  gal5-la2-gal5-la2-e-ne ba-da-an-ze2-er  KU-^ĝiš-bir5-re-eš-dil-da-re-eš zi-ni ba-ši-in-de6  gal5-la2-ne-ne mu-ni-/in\-[kiĝ2-kiĝ2-ne] nu-mu-[un-pad3-de3]
en: Utu accepted his tears { as a gift}. Like a merciful man he showed him mercy. He changed his hands into gazelle hands, he changed his feet into gazelle feet, and so he evaded the demons, and escaped with his life to Ku-bireš-dildareš. The demons searched for him, but didn't find him.

akk: ĝa2-nam-ma-an-ze2-en KU-^ĝiš-bir5-re-[eš] ga-an-ši-re7^re--de3-en  […] X X sa-par3-gin7 […]  ^d-dumu-zid KU-^ĝiš-bir5-re-eš mu-ni-in-dab5-be2-ne  lu2 ba-an-niĝin2-niĝin2-ne-eš a-niĝin2 ba-ni-in-du8-uš  gu zi-ip-pa-tum mu-un-na-sur-ru-ne  ^ĝiš-ma-nu mu-un-na-ḫur-ru-ne  lu2 igi-na-ke4 niĝ2 mu-un-ra-ra  lu2 /murgu-na\-ke4 1 kuš3-gin7 mu-un-bur2-re  šu-ni šu-du3-a ba-e-dab5-be2  a2-ni a2-la2-a ba-e-la2-e  ĝuruš-e ^d-utu-ra an-še3 šu-ni ba-ni-in-zig3
en: "Come, let us go to Ku-bireš." { …… like a net …….} They caught Dumuzid at Ku-bireš. The men surrounded him and drained the standing waters. They twisted a cord for him, they knotted a net for him. They wove a reed hawser for him, they cut sticks for him, the one in front of him threw missiles at him, the one behind him ……. His hands were bound in handcuffs, his arms were bound in fetters. The lad raised his hands heavenward to Utu:

akk: ^d-utu murum5-ĝu10-me-en ĝe26-e mussa-zu-me-en  e2-an-na-še3 u2 gur3-ru-me-en  unug^ki--še3 niĝ2-mussa ak-a-me-en  nundum kug-ge   dub3 kug-ge dub3 ^d-inana-ke4   e2 um-ma ^d-be-li-li zi-ĝu10 ga-ba-ši-in-de6
en: "Utu, you are my brother-in-law, I am your sister's husband! I am he who carries food to E-ana, I am he who brought the wedding gifts to Unug, I am he who kisses the holy lips, I am he who dances on the holy knees, the knees of Inana. Please change my hands into {gazelle} { snake} hands, change my feet into {gazelle} { snake} feet, so I can escape to the house of Old Woman Belili."

akk: ^d-utu er2-na šu ba-ši-in-ti  [gal5-la2-gal5-la2]-e-ne im-ma-da-/an\-[ze2-er]  e2 um-ma ^d-be-li-li zi-ni ba-ši-in-de6  e2 um-ma ^d-be-li-li-še3 ba-an-na-te
en: Utu accepted his tears. He changed his hands into {gazelle} { snake} hands, he changed his feet into {gazelle} { snake} feet, so he evaded the demons and escaped with his life to the house of Old Woman Belili. He approached the house of Old Woman Belili.

akk: um-ma lu2 nu-me-en dam diĝir-ra-me-en  a ub-ta-an-bal-bal a tukum-bi ga-naĝ  zid2 ub-ta-an-dub-dub zid2 tukum-bi ga-gu7
en: "Old woman! I am not just a man, I am the husband of a goddess! Would you pour water -- please -- so I can drink water. Would you sprinkle flour -- please -- so I can eat flour."

akk: a ub-ta-an-bal zid2 ub-ta-an-dub šag4-bi-a ba-an-tuš  um-ma e2-ta ba-ra-e3  um-ma e2-ta ed2-da-ni  gal5-la2-e-ne igi ba-ni-in-du8-uš-am3
en: She poured water, and she sprinkled flour, and he sat down inside the house. The old woman left the house. When the old woman left the house, the demons saw her.

akk: tukum-bi ud-da um-ma ki ^d-dumu-zid til3-la nu-ub-zu  igi ni2 te-a na-bar-bar-re  gu3 ni2 te-a na-de2-de2-e  ĝa2-nam-ma-an-ze2-en e2 um-ma ^d-be-li-li-še3 ga-an-ši-re7-de3-en  ^d-dumu-zid-de3 e2 um-ma ^d-be-li-li-še3 mu-un-dab5-be2-ne  lu2 ba-an-/niĝin2-niĝin2-ne\-eš a-niĝin2 ba-ni-in-du8-uš  gu mu-na-ab-[sur-ru-ne sa] mu-un-na-keše2-da-[ne]  gu /zi\-[ip]-pa-/tum\ [mu-un-na]-sur-[ru-ne]  [^ĝiš-ma-nu] mu-na-an-ḫur-ru-ne  /lu2\ [igi]-/na\-ke4 niĝ2 /mu\-[un-ra-ra]  /lu2\ [murgu-na-ke4 1 kuš3-gin7 mu-un]-/bur2\-re  šu-[ni šu-du3-a ba-e]-dab5-be2  a2-[ni a2-la2-a ba-e-la2]-e  ĝuruš-[e] ^d-utu-ra an-še3 šu-ni ba-ni-in-zig3
en: "Unless the old woman is aware of Dumuzid's whereabouts, she is indeed looking frightened! She is indeed screaming in a frightened way! Come, let us go to the house of Old Woman Belili!" They caught Dumuzid at the house of Old Woman Belili. The men surrounded him and drained the standing waters. They twisted a cord for him, they knotted a net for him. They wove a reed hawser for him, they cut sticks for him, the one in front of him threw missiles at him, the one behind him ……. His hands were bound in handcuffs, his arms were bound in fetters. The lad raised his hands heavenward to Utu:

akk: ^d-utu /murum5-ĝu10-me-en\ ĝe26-e mussa-zu-me-en  e2-an-na-/še3\ [u2 gur3]-/ru\-me-en  unug^ki--še3 niĝ2-mussa(/mi2\-[us2]-/sa2\) ak-me-en  nundum kug-ge   dub3 kug-ge dub3 ^d-inana-[ke4]   šu-ni šu maš-da3 [u3]-mu-ni-in-sig10  ĝiri3-ni ĝiri3 maš-da3 u3-mu-ni-in-sig10  amaš kug amaš nin9-ĝa2-še3 zi-ĝu10 ga-ba-ši-in-de6
en: "Utu, you are my brother-in-law, I am your sister's husband! I am he who carries food to E-ana, I am he who brought the wedding gifts to Unug, I am he who kisses the holy lips, I am he who dances on the holy knees, the knees of Inana. Please change my hands into gazelle hands, change my feet into gazelle feet, so I can escape to the holy sheepfold, my sister's sheepfold."

akk: ^d-utu er2-na šu ba-ši-ni-in-ti  amaš kug amaš nin9-na-še3 zi-ni ba-ši-in-tum3  amaš kug amaš nin9-na-še3 ba-an-na-te  ^d-ĝeštin-an-na-ke4 gu3 an-<še3 ba>-te gu3 ki-še3 ba-te  gu3 šu niĝin2-bi an-ur2-ra tug2-gin7 i-im-dul gada-gin7 i-im-bur2  igi mu-un-na-ḫur giri17 mu-un-na-ḫur  ĝeštug2 ki u6 di mu-un-na-ḫur  ki lu2-da nu-di ḫaš4-gal mu-un-[na-ḫur]
en: Utu accepted his tears. He changed his hands into {gazelle} { snake} hands, he changed his feet into {gazelle} { snake} feet, so he evaded the demons, and escaped with his life to the holy sheepfold, his sister's sheepfold. He approached the holy sheepfold, his sister's sheepfold. Ĝeštin-ana cried toward heaven, cried toward earth. Her cries covered the horizon completely like a cloth, they were spread out like linen. She lacerated her eyes, she lacerated her face, she lacerated her ears in public; in private she lacerated her buttocks.

akk: šeš-ĝu10 sila-a ga-[…]-niĝin2-niĝin2 ĝe26-e […]  tukum-bi ^d-ĝeštin-an-na-ke4 ki [^d-dumu-zid] til3-la nu-[ub-zu]  igi ni2 te-a na-bar-bar-[re]-«en»  gu3 ni2 te-[a] na-de2-de2-e  ĝa2-nam-ma-an-ze2-en amaš tur3-še3 [ga-ba]-ši-ĝen  gal5-la2 1 amaš tur3-še3 kur9-ra-ni  ^ĝiš-gag-ga-ra izi /ba\-[ni]-in-ra  ĜIŠ NI X gu3 ba-ni-ra  2-kam-ma amaš tur3-še3 kur9-ra-ni  ^ĝiš-ma-nu izi ba-ni-ra  3-kam-ma amaš tur3-še3 kur9-ra-ni  ^dug-šakir3 kug-ga-a TUN3-bi [ba]-ra-[ba9-re6]
en: "My brother, I will go round in the streets ……."  "Unless Ĝeštin-ana is aware of Dumuzid's whereabouts, she is indeed looking frightened! She is indeed screaming in a frightened way! Come, let us go to the sheepfold and cow-pen!" When the first demon entered the sheepfold and cow-pen, {he set fire to the bolt} { he shouted ……}. When the second entered the sheepfold and cow-pen, he set fire to the shepherd's stick. When the third entered the sheepfold and cow-pen, he removed the cover of the holy churn.

akk: 4-kam-ma amaš tur3-še3 kur9-ra-ni  an-za-am ^ĝiš-gag-ta la2-a ^ĝiš-gag-ta ba-ra-ab-si-ig  5-kam-ma amaš tur3 kur9-ra-ni  ^dug-šakir3 i3-dur2-dur2 ga nu-un-de2  ki-izi kug-ĝa2 a mu-da-an-de2  5-kam-ma amaš tur3-še3 kur9-ra-ni  an-za-am kug ^ĝiš-gag-ta la2-ĝu10 ^ĝiš-gag-ta ba-ra-ab-si-ig  6-kam-ma amaš tur3-še3 kur9-ra-ni  ^dug-šakir3 i3-dur2-dur2 ga nu-un-de2  7-kam-ma amaš tur3-še3 kur9-ra-ni  an-za-am i3-dur2-dur2 ^d-dumu-zid nu-un-til3 amaš lil2-la2 al-du3
en: {When the fourth entered the sheepfold and cow-pen, he tore down the drinking cup from the peg where it hung. When the fifth entered the sheepfold and cow-pen, the churns lay on their sides, no milk was poured, the drinking cups lay on their sides, Dumuzid was dead, the sheepfold was haunted.} { When the fourth entered the sheepfold and cow-pen, he poured water on my holy brazier. When the fifth demon entered the sheepfold and cow-pen, he tore down my holy drinking cup from the peg where it hung. When the sixth demon entered the sheepfold and cow-pen, the churns lay on their sides, and no milk was poured. When the seventh demon entered the sheepfold and cow-pen, the drinking cups lay on their sides, Dumuzid was dead, the sheepfold was haunted.}
261-999. A šir-kalkal for the dead Dumuzid.

akk: [edin-na ^d-dumu-zid-ĝu10 i-lu za-ra i-lu za-ra i-lu] balaĝ^?- mu-un-da-sa2-/sa2\  [e2] [a]-/ra\-li mu-un-<da-sa2-sa2>  bad3-tibira^ki- mu-un-<da-sa2-sa2>  du6-šuba-a mu-un-<da-sa2-sa2>  ki nam-sipad-da mu-un-da-sa2-sa2 amaš ^d-dumu-zid-da-ka […]
en: She can make the lament for you, my Dumuzid, the lament for you, the lament, the lamentation, reach the desert -- she can make it reach the house Arali; she can make it reach Bad-tibira; she can make it reach Du-šuba; she can make it reach the shepherding country, the sheepfold of Dumuzid …….

akk: sipad lu2 […]  […] ^d-dumu-[zid]  […]-mu-un  […]  […] giri17-zal-ĝu10  […] ĝar-ra  […] UG  […] KA^?-  […]-la mu-da-[…]-ba-e i-si-iš […] MU […]  […]  […] giri17-zal-la-ke4 […]
en: …… she broods on it:

akk: […] NE […] ad-e-eš […] gi4  [^d-dumu]-/zid\ ka kug igi sag9-sag9 i-si-iš-bi mu-un-kuš2-u3  /ka\ kug <igi sag9-sag9 i-si-iš-bi mu-un-kuš2-u3>  {/ĝuruš^?-\} {(or read:)  /DAG^?-\} nitalam  u3-/mu\-un  zu2^?--lum  […] ^d-dumu-zid-de3 mu-un-kuš2-u3 [i-si-iš-bi] mu-un-kuš2-u3
en: "O Dumuzid of the fair-spoken mouth, of the ever kind eyes," she sobs tearfully, "O you of the fair-spoken mouth, of the ever kind eyes," she sobs tearfully. "Lad, husband, lord, sweet as the date, …… O Dumuzid!" she sobs, she sobs tearfully.

akk: kug ^d-inana-ke4 […]  ŠID ĜAR nam MUNUS […] NE […] ĜAR nam-[…]  in-nin lu2 ĝar-ra […] ĝar-[ra …]  ki-sikil ^d-inana lu2 ĝar-ra <…>  e a-ra-zu sun5-sun5 mu-un-na-su8-ug
en: Holy Inana …… 1 line fragmentary The goddess ……. The maiden Inana ……. She was pacing to and fro in the chamber of her mother who bore her, in prayer and supplication, while they stood in attendance on her respectfully:

akk: a […] ama-ĝu10  da-[…]-dib  amaš-še3 {ga-ma-e-da-ĝen} {(or read:)  BI X X  da-DU }  ama-ĝu10  ga-ša-an-gal-e da-[…-dib]  <amaš-še3 ga-ma-e-da-ĝen>  a-a-ĝu10 ma-ra-bu7 sun5-na {ga-da-[…]-dib} {(or read:)  BI  da-[…]-DU }  ^d-suen ma-ra-bu7 sun5-na {ga-da-[…]-dib} {(or read:)  BI  da-[…]-DU }
en: "O my mother …… with your permission let me go to the sheepfold! O my mother Ningal …… with your permission let me go to the sheepfold! My father has shone forth for me in lordly fashion …… Suen has shone forth for me in lordly fashion ……."

akk: dumu ama ugu-ni kiĝ2-gi4-a-gin7 ama5-ta im-ma-ta-e3  ama  ga-ša-an-gal-e  kiĝ2-gi4-a-gin7 <ama5-ta im-ma-ta-e3>  nin-ĝu10 gal mu-un-zu gal in-ga-an-tum2-mu  kug ^d-inana-ke4 gal mu-un-zu <gal in-ga-an-tum2-mu>  kaš ud re ud su3-ra2 dur2-ru-na-bi-a
en: Like a child sent on an errand by its own mother, she went out from the chamber; like one sent on an errand by Mother Ningal, she went out from the chamber. Full knowledgeable my lady was, and also she was full apt, full knowledgeable holy Inana was, and also she was full apt. Beer stored in remote days, in long past days …….

akk: […] amaš-ta […]  [e2 um]-/ma\ ^d-bi-lu-lu(source: be-li-li)-še3 […]  ki-bi-a sipad saĝ-a ra […]  ^d-dumu-zid saĝ-a ra  ^d-ama-ušumgal-an-na saĝ-a ra
en: …… from the sheepfold. 1 line missing …… to the house of old woman Bilulu . There the shepherd, head beaten in, ……, Dumuzid, head beaten in, ……; Ama-ušumgal-ana, head beaten in, …….

akk: udu lugal-ĝa2 ^d-dumu-zid-da-ke4 edin-na […]  ^d-inana ^lu2-sipad nu-me-a  udu lugal-ĝa2 zag-ba mu-un-gi4-gi4
en: "The sheep of my master, of Dumuzid, in the desert ……. O Inana, a man who was not the shepherd was returning beside my master's sheep!"

akk: nin-e nitalam-ni-ir šir3 mu-un-ši-ib2-u3-tud šir3 mu-un-ši-ib-dim2-e  [kug] [^d-]/inana\-ke4 ^d-dumu-zid-ra <šir3 mu-un-ši-ib2-u3-tud šir3 mu-un-ši-ib-dim2-e>
en: The lady created a song for her young husband, fashioned a song for him, holy Inana created a song for Dumuzid, fashioned a song for him:

akk: [mu]-/lu\  nu2  su8-ba mu-lu  nu2 en-nu-uĝ3-ba me-gub  ^d-dumu-zid  mu-lu  nu2 en-<nu-uĝ3-ba me-gub>  ^d-ama-ušumgal-an-na  mu-<lu>  <nu2 en-nu-uĝ3-ba me-gub>  ^d-utu-da gub-ba DI-ĝa2 en-<nu-uĝ3-ba me-gub>  ĝi6-da nu2-nu2 DI-ĝa2 en-nu-uĝ3-ba me-gub
en: "O you who lie at rest, shepherd, who lie at rest, you stood guard over them! Dumuzid, you who lie at rest, you stood guard over them! Ama-ušumgal-ana, you who lie at rest, you stood guard over them! Rising with the sun you stood guard over my sheep , lying down by night only, you stood guard over my sheep !"

akk: ud-bi-a um-ma ^d-bi-lu-lu  bur-šu-ma nin ni2-te-na-ka  dumu-ni ĝir2-ĝir2-e lu2 dili-am3  ul4-ul4-e am3-tum2 lu2 i3-zu-am3  gud dab5-ba-ni tur3 amaš-e am3-si  guru7-du6-ra-ni gu2 am3-gur-gur  ul4-ul4-la šita2 tag-ga-na sag2 mu-un-ne-dug4  dumu na(source: ni) gu5-li na šir3-ru edin-lil2-la2  igi-ni-še3 i3-tuš inim mu-un-da-ab-be2
en: Then the son of old woman Bilulu, matriarch and her own mistress, -- Ĝirĝire, a man on his own, fit for prospering and a knowledgeable man -- was filling pen and fold with his captured cattle, and was stacking his stacks and piles of grain. He quickly left scattered his victims struck down with the mace. Širru of the haunted desert, no one's child and no one's friend, sat before him and held converse with him.

akk: ud-bi-a nin-e šag4-ga-ni a-na am3-de6  kug ^d-inana-ke4 šag4-ga-ni a-na am3-/de6\  um-ma(source: u3-mu-un) ^d-bi-lu-lu ug5-/ge\-[de3] šag4-ga-ni /am3\-[de6]  nitalam ki aĝ2-ĝa2-ni ^d-dumu-zid-^d-ama-/ušumgal\-[an-na-ra]  ki-nu2 dug3-dug3-ge-de3 šag4-ga-ni nam-[de6]  nin-ĝu10 ^d-bi-lu-lu edin-lil2-la2 ba-an-[…]  dumu-ni ĝir2-ĝir2-e lil2-la2-a-bi bi2-/in\-[…]  dumu na gu5-li na šir3-ru edin-lil2-la2 […]
en: That day what was in the lady's heart? What was in holy Inana's heart? To kill old woman Bilulu was in her heart! To make good the resting place for her beloved young husband, for Dumuzid-ama-ušumgal-ana -- that was in her heart! My lady went to Bilulu in the haunted desert. Her son Ĝirĝire like the wind there did …… Širru of the haunted desert, no one's child and no one's friend, …….

akk: kug ^d-inana-ke4 eš2-dam-ma ba-ni-in-kur9 […]  ki-tuš-a ba-e-gub nam mu-ni-ib-tar-re  ĝen-na ba-ug5-ge-en na-nam-ma-am3 mu-zu ga-ba-da-ḫa-lam-e  ^kuš-ummud a sed niĝ2 edin-na ḫe2-me-en  dumu-ni ĝir2-ĝir2-re e-ne-bi-da  ^d-udug edin-na ^d-lamma edin-na ḫe2-em-ma-da-me-eš-am3  dumu na gu5-li na šir3-ru /edin\-lil2-la2  edin-na ḫa-mu-ni-ib2-du zid2 ḫu-mu-ni-ib2-ŠID-e  ĝuruš edin-na du a ub-ta-an-bal-bal zid2 ub-ta-an-dub-dub  ^d-udug edin-na ^d-lamma edin-na  […] sed-a ḫu-mu-ni-ib-be2 dub-a ḫu-mu-ni-ib-be2  ki sa-ḫa-a-na [edin]-/na\ ḫu-mu-un-ĝal2  um-ma ^d-bi-lu-lu šag4-ga-ni ḫu-mu-ḫul2-le
en: Holy Inana entered the alehouse, stepped into a seat, began to determine fate: "Begone! I have killed you; so it is indeed, and with you I destroy also your name: May you become the waterskin for cold water that is used in the desert! May her son Ĝirĝire together with her become the protective god of the desert and the protective goddess of the desert! May Širru of the haunted desert, no one's child and no one's friend, walk in the desert and keep count of the flour, and when water is libated and flour sprinkled for the lad wandering in the desert, let the protective god of the desert and the protective goddess of the desert call out: "Libate!", call out: "Sprinkle!", and thereby cause him to be present in the place from which he vanished, in the desert! Let old woman Bilulu gladden his heart!"

akk: i3-ne-eš2 ^d-utu ud ne ur5 ḫe2-en-na-/nam\  ^kuš-ummud [a sed niĝ2 edin-na i3-me]  dumu-ni [ĝir2]-/ĝir2\-re e-ne-bi-da  [^d-]udug edin-na ^d-lamma edin-na im-ma-an-da-an-me-eš-am3  [dumu] /na\ gu5-li na šir3-ru edin-lil2-la2  [edin]-/na\ mu-ni-ib2-ĝen zid2 mu-ni-ib-ŠID-e  [ĝuruš edin]-na du a ub-ta-an-bal-bal zid2 ub-ta-<an-dub-dub>  ^d-udug edin-na [^d-]lamma edin-na  […] sed-a mu-ni-ib-be2 dub-[a mu-ni-ib-be2]  ki sa-ḫa-a-na edin-na [mu-un-ĝal2 …]  um-ma ^d-bi-lu-lu šag4-ga-[ni mu-ḫul2-e]  ^d-inana-ke4 ĝuruš ki-e šu /mu\-[…]  ^d-dumu-zid ki-[e šu mu-…]  šu du3-a-[ni …]
en: And immediately, under the sun of that day, it truly became so. She became the waterskin for cold water that is used in the desert. Her son Ĝirĝire together with her became the protective god of the desert and the protective goddess of the desert. Širru of the haunted desert, no one's child and no one's friend, walks in the desert and keeps count of the flour, and when water is libated and flour sprinkled for the lad wandering in the desert, the protective god of the desert and the protective goddess of the desert call out: "Libate!", call out: "Sprinkle!", and thereby cause him to be present in the place from which he vanished, in the desert. Old woman Bilulu gladdens his heart. Inana put out her hand to the lad on the ground, put out her hand to Dumuzid on the ground, his death-bound hands ……

akk: […] ŠE3 […] mu-na-/il2\  […]-ba-še3 buru5-ḫabrud^mušen--e nam /il2\  ki-ulutim2 ^d-dumu-zid-da-še3 buru5-ḫabrud^mušen--e […]  tum12^mušen--gin7 ab-lal3-ba ni2-bi-a ad-e-eš ba-ni-ib2-gi4  buru5-ḫabrud^mušen--e a2-bur2-ba ad-e-eš ba-ni-ib-gi4  lugal-ĝu10 ama-ni ^d-dur7-/tur\-ra-am3 i3-ḫul2-le  ^d-dumu-zid-de3 ama-ni <^d-dur7-tur-ra-am3 i3-ḫul2-le>  in-nin-ĝu10 u3-tud-da kuara^ki-  ki-sikil amar sig7-ga men-bi  u6 di niĝ2-me-ĝar saĝ gig2-ga   i-lu akkil dug4-dug4  nam-šita dug4-dug4 lugal-la […]  ^d-ĝeštin-an-na-ke4 nin […]
en: The francolin …… to the …… of its ……. The francolin …… to the birthplace of Dumuzid. Like a pigeon on its window ledge it took counsel with itself; the francolin in its shelter took counsel. Only his mother Durtur can gladden my master! Only his mother Durtur can gladden Dumuzid! My goddess, born in Kuara, the maiden who is the crown of all ……, the admiration and acclaim of the black-headed people, the playful one who also voices laments and the cries, who intercedes before the king -- Ĝeštin-ana, the lady, did …….

akk: A AN SUD KID […]  ki-sikil u6 di […]  ^d-ĝeštin-an-na-ke4 […] mi-ni-[…]  nu-gig-e šu […]-/ne\-ne šu-a mi-ni-/TUR^?-\  […] NI […]-ba teš2-bi ba-ra-ĝa2-ĝa2  […] ka NI […] ba-an-ta-gi4-gi4
en: The maiden …… the admiration. Ĝeštin-ana ……. The sacred one, Inana …… in her hand. …… together. …… replied:

akk: [i]-/lu\ za-ra i-lu za-ra [i-lu]  du5-mu-ri-ib-dug4   […] šeš-e ĝe26 i-lu za-ra <i-lu  du5-mu-ri-ib-dug4 >  […] i-lu za-ra <i-lu  du5-mu-ri-ib-dug4 >  [e2] [a-ra-li]-/a\ i-lu za-ra <i-lu  du5-mu-ri-ib-dug4 >  [du6-šuba]-/a\ i-lu za-ra <i-lu  du5-mu-ri-ib-dug4 >  [bad3]-/tibira^ki--a\ i-lu za-ra <i-lu  du5-mu-ri-ib-dug4 >  [ki nam]-sipad-da [i-lu za-ra i]-/lu\  du5-mu-ri-/ib\-[dug4]
en: "Let me utter the lament for you, the lament for you, the lament! Brother, let me utter the lament for you, the lament! …… let me utter the lament for you, the lament! Let me utter the lament for you, the lament in the house Arali! Let me utter the lament for you, the lament in Du-šuba! Let me utter the lament for you, the lament in Bad-tibira! Let me utter the lament for you, the lament in the shepherding country!"

akk: [in]-/nin\  mu-ud-na-ni  ne-nam ib2-/da\-[sa2]  [kug]  [ga]-/ša\-an-an-na su8-ba  ^d-[dumu-zid] [ne]-nam ib-<da-sa2>  [ki]-/nu2\  ze2-ze2-ba  [in-nin]-ra  [šu] /ĝar\ gi4-a  ga-ša-an-an-na-ra^?-  /šu\-[a ba]-/na\-an-si
en: How truly the goddess proved the equal of her betrothed, how truly holy Inana proved the equal of the shepherd Dumuzid! It was granted to Inana to make good his resting place, it was granted to the goddess to avenge him!

akk: [i-lu za]-ra i-lu za-ra i-lu  du5-/mu\-[ri]-/ib\-dug4   [i]-lu za-ra i-lu za-ra <i-lu  du5-mu-ri-ib-dug4 >  [ki]-ulutim2 i-lu za-ra <i-lu  du5-mu-ri-ib-dug4 >  edin-na ^d-dumu-zid i-lu za-ra <i-lu  du5-mu-ri-ib-dug4 >  e2 a-ra-li-a i-lu za-ra <i-lu  du5-mu-ri-ib-dug4 >  du6-šuba-a [i-lu] za-ra <i-lu  du5-mu-ri-ib-dug4 >  bad3-tibira^ki--a i-[lu za-ra] <i-lu  du5-mu-ri-ib-dug4 >  ki nam-sipad-da i-lu za-ra i-lu  /du5\-[mu-ri-ib-dug4]
en: "Let me utter the lament for you, the lament for you, the lament! Let me utter the lament for you, the lament for you, the lament! In the birthplace let me utter the lament for you, the lament! In the desert, O Dumuzid, let me utter the lament for you, the lament! In the house Arali let me utter the lament for you, the lament! In Du-šuba let me utter the lament for you, the lament! In Bad-tibira let me utter the lament for you, the lament! In the shepherding country let me utter the lament for you, the lament!"

akk: ^d-dumu-zid ne-nam ib2-da-sa2-e šu [ĝar gi4-a]  ^d-bi-lu-lu ug5-[ga]  ^d-inana ib2-da-/sa2\
en: How truly she proved the equal of Dumuzid, avenging him; by killing Bilulu, Inana proved equal to him!
177. An ulila song of Inana.

akk: ^d-nanna-^d-suen-e /ĝeštug2\-[ga-ni na-an-gub]  ^d-suen-e iri ama-/na\-[še3]  ^d-aš-im2-babbar-re ĝeštug2-[ga-ni na-an-gub]  iri ama-na-še3 a-a-[na-še3]  ^d-nanna-^d-suen-e ĝeštug2-ga-ni na-[an-gub]  ^d-en-lil2-la2-še3 ^d-nin-lil2-[la2-še3]  ^d-aš-im2-babbar-e ĝeštug2-ga-ni na-an-gub
en: The heroic Nanna-Suen fixed his mind on the city of his mother. Suen Ašimbabbar fixed his mind on the city of his mother. Nanna-Suen fixed his mind on the city of his mother and his father. Ašimbabbar fixed his mind on the city of Enlil and Ninlil:

akk: ur-saĝ-me-en ĝe26-e iri-ĝu10-še3 ga-ĝen  ĝe26-e iri-ĝu10-še3 ga-ĝen a-a-ĝu10-še3 ga-an-ši-ĝen  ^d-suen-me-en ĝe26-e iri-ĝu10-še3 ga-ĝen  ĝe26-e iri-ĝu10-še3 ga-ĝen a-a-ĝu10-še3 ga-an-ši-ĝen  a-a-ĝu10 ^d-en-lil2-la2-še3 ga-an-ši-ĝen  ĝe26-e iri-ĝu10-še3 ga-ĝen ama-ĝu10-še3 ga-an-ši-ĝen  ama-ĝu10 ^d-nin-lil2-la2-še3 ga-an-ši-ĝen  a-a-ĝu10-še3 ga-an-ši-ĝen
en: "I, the hero, will set off for my city. I will set off for my city, I will set off to my father. I, Suen, will set off for my city. I will set off for my city, I will set off to my father. I will set off to my father Enlil. I will set off for my city, I will set off to my mother. I will set off to my mother Ninlil. I will set off to my father."

akk: iri šen-šen-na ki sikil-la […]  [… e3 gal]-/gal\-la-am3  [… e3 gal]-/gal\-la-am3  […] e3 gal-gal-la2-am3  […] e3 gal-gal-la2-am3
en: "The shining city, the pure place ……. 6 lines missing …… very great, …… very great, …… very great, …… very great."

akk: [nibru^ki-]-/ĝu10\ ĝiš-kin2 ĝiš gig2 ki dug3-ge mu2-a  [eš3] [nibru^ki-]-/ĝu10\ ĝiš-kin2 ĝiš babbar ki sikil-e mu2-a  [nibru^ki--ĝu10] ki dug3-ga barag-bi ša-mu-un-du3  eš3 nibru^ki- mu-bi mu dug3-ga-am3  nibru^ki--ĝu10 ki dug3-ga barag-bi ša-mu-un-du3  eš3 nibru^ki- mu-bi mu dug3-ga-am3  iri-ĝu10 ^kur-dilmun^ki- nu-me-a ^ĝiš-ĝišnimbar ba-mu2  nibru^ki- ^kur-dilmun^ki- nu-me-a ^ĝiš-ĝišnimbar ba-mu2  ama gal ^d-nin-lil2-le šag4 gada ba-ni-in-la2
en: "My Nibru, where black birch trees grow in a good place, my sanctuary Nibru, where white birch trees grow in a pure place -- my Nibru's shrine is built in a good place. The sanctuary Nibru's name is a good name. My Nibru's shrine is built in a good place. The sanctuary Nibru's name is a good name. Before Dilmun existed, palm trees grew in my city. Before Dilmun existed, palm trees grew in Nibru and the great mother Ninlil was clothed in fine linen."
Suen set about constructing a barge. He set about constructing a barge and sent for reed matting.

akk: ^ĝiš-ma2-gur8-ra gi-bi tum-ma-al^ki--še3  ^d-nanna-^d-suen-e lu2 im-ši-in-/gi4\-[gi4]  ^ĝiš-ma2-gur8-ra esir-bi abzu-še3  ^d-aš-im2-babbar-re lu2 im-ši-in-gi4-gi4  ^d-nanna-^d-suen-e lu2 im-ši-in-gi4-gi4  ^ĝiš-mi-ri2-za-bi tir ḫa-šu-ur2-ra-še3  ^d-aš-im2-babbar-e lu2 im-ši-in-gi4-gi4  ^ĝiš-eme-sig-bi tir kug-nun-na-še3  [^d-nanna-^d-]/suen\-e [lu2 im-ši-in-gi4]-/gi4\
en: Nanna-Suen despatched people to Tummal for the barge's reeds. Ašimbabbar despatched people to the abzu for the barge's pitch. Nanna-Suen despatched people to Du-ašaga for its rushes. Ašimbabbar despatched people to the cypress forest for its strakes . Nanna-Suen despatched people to the forests of Kug-nuna for its ribbing . { Ašimbabbar despatched people to the mountain of fragrant cedar for its beams.}

akk: [^ĝiš-a-da-ma2-bi kur šim ^ĝiš-erin-na-še3]  [^d-aš-im2-babbar-e lu2 im-ši-in-gi4-gi4]  [^ĝiš-u3-bi tir] [eb2-la-ka]-/še3\  [^d-aš-im2-babbar-e lu2 im-ši-in-gi4-gi4]  [^ĝiš-u3-suḫ5-bi ^ĝiš-tir šim ^ĝiš-erin-na-še3]  [^d-nanna-^d-suen-e lu2 im-ši-in-gi4-gi4]  [u2 X X-bi ^ĝiš-li la-an-gi4-še3]  [^d-aš-im2-babbar-e lu2 im-ši-in-gi4-gi4]  […]-bi […-še3]  ^d-aš-/im2-babbar\-re /lu2\ [im-ši-in-gi4-gi4]  […]-/bi\ DUL u2 X-/še3\  ^d-nanna-^d-suen-e lu2 im-ši-in-gi4-[gi4]
en: Ašimbabbar despatched people to the forests of Ebla for its planking. Nanna-Suen despatched people to the fragrant cedar forest for its fir wood. Ašimbabbar despatched people to the junipers of Langi for its ……. Ašimbabbar despatched people to …… for its ……. Nanna-Suen despatched people to the mound of …… for its …….

akk: [^ĝiš-]ma2-gur8-ra gi-bi tum-ma-al[^ki--ta]  [^d-]/nanna\-^d-suen-ra mu-na-da-/ri\-[a]  /^ĝiš-\ma2-gur8-ra esir-bi abzu-[ta]  ^d-aš-im2-babbar-ra mu-na-da-ri-a  ^d-nanna-^d-suen-ra mu-na-da-an-ri-a  ^ĝiš-mi-ri2-za-bi tir ḫa-šu-ur2-ra-ta  ^d-aš-im2-babbar-ra mu-na-da-an-ri-a  ^ĝiš-eme-sig-bi tir kug-nun-na-ta  ^d-nanna-^d-suen-ra mu-na-da-an-ri-a  ^ĝiš-a-da-ma2-bi kur šim ^ĝiš-erin-na-ta  ^d-aš-im2-babbar-e mu-na-da-an-ri-am3  ^ĝiš-u3-bi tir eb2-la-ta  ^d-aš-im2-babbar-ra mu-na-da-an-ri-a  ^ĝiš-u3-suḫ5-bi ^ĝiš-tir šim ^ĝiš-erin-na-ta  ^d-nanna-^d-suen mu-na-da-an-ri-a  u2 X X-bi ^ĝiš-li la-an-gi4-ta  ^d-aš-im2-babbar-ra mu-na-da-an-ri-a  […-bi …-ta]  [^d-aš-im2-babbar-ra mu-na-da-an-ri-a]  […-bi DUL u2 X-ta]  [^d-nanna-^d-suen-ra mu-na-da-an-ri-a]  […]-/ni\-in-ri  /^d-\utu mu-un-da-ḫul2  […] /bi2\-in-ĝar  ^d-gibil6 mu-un-da-ḫul2
en: When the barge's reeds were brought to Nanna-Suen from Tummal, when the barge's pitch was brought to Ašimbabbar from the abzu, when its rushes were brought to Nanna-Suen from Du-ašaga, when its strakes were brought to Ašimbabbar from the cypress forest, when its ribbing was brought to Nanna-Suen from the forests of Kug-nuna, { when its beams were brought to Ašimbabbar from the mountain of fragrant cedar,} when its planking was brought to Ašimbabbar from the forests of Ebla, when its fir wood was brought to Nanna-Suen from the fragrant cedar forest, when its …… was brought to Ašimbabbar from the junipers of Langi, when its …… was brought to Ašimbabbar from ……, when its …… was brought to Nanna-Suen from the mound of ……, 1 line fragmentaryUtu rejoiced at him and put ……. Gibil rejoiced at him. lines 83-146 missing or fragmentary

akk: […] X ba-ni-ib-be2-e  […] ba-ni-in-dug4  […] X-nu2  […] X-bi bi2-in-du8  [… mu]-/un\-da-ḫul2  […] X  [… mu]-/un\-da-ḫul2  […] X  […] X  X […]  ^d-suen […]  aškud2-/zu\ […]  ^d-suen-e ^ĝiš-ma2 X […]  ^d-suen-e ^ĝiš-ma2 a-a X […]  ^d-suen-e ^ĝiš-ma2-gur8-ra X […]  ^d-suen-e a-u3-a […]  ^d-suen-e a-[u3-a …]  a-[u3-a …]  a-u3-[a …]  a-u3-a […]  a-u3-a ^d-aš-[im2-babbar-e] […]  a-u3-a ur2 […]  a-u3-a ^d-/nanna\-[^d-suen-e] […]  a-u3-a dumu [^d-en-lil2-la2 …]  a-[u3-a …]  a-u3-[a …]  a-u3-a […]  a-u3-a ^d-nanna-[^d-suen-e] […]  lugal-zu a-a-ni […]  ^d-nanna šul ^d-suen-e […]  ^d-suen-e a-a […]  ^d-aš-im2-babbar-e […]  ^d-suen-[e] […]  X […] a-u3-a-ba […]  a-u3-a-ba […] X X X […]  a-u3-a-ba […] a-u3-a ^d-[…]  X […] X […] a-u3-a X X X […]  […] BI […] lugal-zu a-a-ni ^d-en-lil2-ra  nesaĝ mu-un-na-ab-tum3 […] MU […] X  […] saĝ us2 mu-na-dur2-ru-ne-eš  a-u3-a-ba dumu X X X ^d-nanna-ar X gi4 X  mu-na-dur2-ru-ne-[eš …] X […]  [^d-nanna-^d-suen]-me-en […]-en  [e2] [^d-en-lil2-la2]-še3 X [(X) zag im]-/la2\-la2-e-en  ^d-aš-im2-babbar^ar--me-en e2 ^d-en-lil2-la2-še3  X X […] zag im-la2-la2-e-en
en: "I am Nanna-Suen, I ……, I will …… to the house of Enlil. I am Ašimbabbar, and I will …… to the house of Enlil." 6 lines missing

akk: [gud-da tur3-re gu2 bi2-ib-gur-gur-re]  [^d-nanna-^d-suen-e e2 ^d-en-lil2-la2-še3]  [udu niga šag4 mu-da-ab-la2-e]  [^d-aš-im2-babbar-e e2 ^d-en-lil2-la2-še3]  [tur3-e ib2-da-ab-luḫ-luḫ-e]  [^d-nanna-^d-suen-e e2 ^d-en-lil2-la2-še3]  [ud5-de3 niĝ2-ar3-ra bi2-ib2-gu7-e]  [^d-aš-im2-babbar-e e2 ^d-en-lil2-la2-še3]  [ze2-da-niĝ2-bar-bar-sur-ra …]  [^d-nanna-^d-suen-e e2 ^d-en-lil2-la2-še3]
en: Nanna-Suen will gather bulls for the cow-pen for the house of Enlil. Ašimbabbar will collect fattened sheep for the house of Enlil. Nanna-Suen will purify the cow-pen for the house of Enlil. Ašimbabbar will feed meal to the goats for the house of Enlil. Nanna-Suen will …… porcupines for the house of Enlil.

akk: [peš2-ĝiš-gi niĝ2 kun sud kun sud-da]  [šag4 am3-mi-ni-ib2-gul-gul]  [^d-aš-im2-babbar-e e2 ^d-en-lil2-la2-še3]  [kud-da mušen tur-re šu bi2-ib2-zu-zu]  [^d-nanna-^d-suen-e e2 ^d-en-lil2-la2-še3]  [u5-bi2^mušen- tur tul2-ta ba-ra-an-tum2-mu]  ^d-aš-im2-babbar-[e] [e2 ^d-en-lil2-la2-še3]  a-zag-gun3^mušen- tur X-ta ba-ra-an-tum2-mu  ^d-nanna-^d-suen-e e2 ^d-en-lil2-la2-še3
en: Ašimbabbar will …… long-tailed bush-rats for the house of Enlil. Nanna-Suen will gather turtles and small birds for the house of Enlil. Ašimbabbar will bring small ubi birds from the pond for the house of Enlil. Nanna-Suen will bring small azagun birds from the …… for the house of Enlil.

akk: suḫur^ku6--e šag4 mu-da-ab-sur-re  ^d-aš-im2-babbar-re e2 ^d-en-lil2-la2-še3  eštub^ku6--e <…>-bi zag im-la2  ^d-nanna-^d-suen-e e2 ^d-en-lil2-la2-še3  ^d-aš-im2-babbar-re e2 ^d-en-lil2-la2-še3  nunuz ĝir3-lam-ma mu-un-/sig9\-[sig9-ge]  ^d-nanna-^d-suen-e e2 [^d-en-lil2-la2-še3]  gi sumun gi ḫenbur mud [ĝal2 im-me]  ^d-aš-im2-babbar-re e2 ^d-[en-lil2-la2-še3]
en: Ašimbabbar will …… suḫur carp for the house of Enlil. Nanna-Suen will …… eštub carp for the house of Enlil. Ašimbabbar will pour the oil of rushes onto the water for the house of Enlil. Nanna-Suen will fill baskets with eggs for the house of Enlil. Ašimbabbar will cause old reed and fresh reed to thrive for the house of Enlil.

akk: u8 600-am3 sila4 im-mi-in-tu-ud  udu-utua2-bi šag4-ba šu ba-ni-in-ba-ba  gu2 ^id2-surungal-la im-mi-in-ba  ^d-nanna-^d-suen-e e2 ^d-en-[lil2-la2-še3]  ud5 600-am3 maš2 im-mi-in-tu-[ud]  maš2-ud5-da šag4-ba šu ba-ni-in-ba-ba  gu2 ^id2-surungal-la im-mi-in-ba  ^d-aš-im2-babbar-re e2 ^d-en-lil2-[la2-še3]  ab2 600-am3 amar im-mi-in-tu-[ud]  gud-ab2-ba šag4-ba šu ba-ni-in-ba-ba  gu2 ^id2-surungal-la im-mi-in-ba  ^d-nanna-^d-suen-e e2 ^d-/en\-[lil2-la2-še3]
en: Nanna-Suen will cause six hundred ewes to give birth to lambs for the house of Enlil, for he will cause their rams to be let loose among them, and he will distribute them along the banks of the Surungal canal. Ašimbabbar will cause six hundred she-goats to give birth to kids for the house of Enlil, for he will cause their bucks to be let loose among them, and he will distribute them along the banks of the Surungal canal. Nanna-Suen will cause six hundred cows to give birth to calves for the house of Enlil, for he will cause their bulls to be let loose among them, and he will distribute them along the banks of the Surungal canal.

akk: nidba-a saĝ-bi enegir^ki--a eĝer-/bi\ [urim2^ki--ma]  e2-ta nu-e3 e2-ta nu-e3 e2-ta nam-ta-ab-e3  ^d-nin-girid2-da e2-ta nu-e3 e2-ta nam-ta-ab-e3  silim-ma ḫe2-me-en silim-ma ḫe2-me-en ^ĝiš-ma2 silim-ma ḫe2-me-en  ^ĝiš-ma2 ^d-suen-na silim-ma ḫe2-me-en ^ĝiš-ma2 silim-ma ḫe2-me-en
en: Enegir lay ahead of the offerings, Urim lay behind them. She brought out of the house what should not come out of the house, what should not come out of the house -- Ningirida brought out of the house what should not come out of the house: "Welcome, welcome, welcome, O boat! O boat of Suen, welcome, welcome, O boat!"

akk: ^ĝiš-/ma2\-[gur8]-/ra\ zid2 im-ma-ab-gub-be2 duḫ im-ma-ab-sal-e  ĝiri3-/ni gakkul\ zabar-ra im-ma-an-šu2-šu2  šu-si-ni bulug ^ĝiš-taškarin mu-na-an-bur12-bur12-re  aškud2-bi i3-ḫe-nun-na-ka šu ga-am3-ma-ni-ib-ur3  šag4-zu-a i3-nun lal3 ĝeštin niĝ2 ḫe2-ni-ib-gu-ul-gu-ul-e  si ^ĝiš-ma2-saĝ-ĝa2-zu suḫur^ku6- eštub^ku6- /ul-ul\ ḫu-mu-ni-ib-/dug4\  ^ĝiš-ma2-e gu2-bi nu-mu-na-ab-šum2-mu nibru^ki--še3 ba-du-[un]
en: She laid out flour before the barge and spread bran. At her feet stood a covered bronze gakkul vat. { With her fingers she pulled out the boxwood bung for him :} "I shall rub precious oil on this peg. May ghee, syrup and wine be abundant in your midst, may the suḫur carp and the eštub carp rejoice at the prow of your boat!" But the boat did not give her its cargo: "I am going to Nibru!"

akk: nidba-a saĝ-bi larsam^ki--ma eĝer-bi enegir^ki--a  e2-ta nu-e3 e2-ta nu-e3 e2-ta nam-ta-ab-e3  ^d-še-ri5-da sag9-ga e2-<ta> nu-e3 e2-ta nam-ta-ab-e3  silim-ma ḫe2-me-en silim-ma ḫe2-me-en ^ĝiš-ma2 silim-ma ḫe2-me-en  ^ĝiš-ma2 a-a-ĝu10 silim-ma ḫe2-me-en ^ĝiš-ma2 silim-ma ḫe2-me-[en]
en: Larsam lay ahead of the offerings, Enegir lay behind them. She brought out of the house what should not come out of the house, what should not come out of the house -- the lovely Šerida brought out of the house what should not come out of the house: "Welcome, welcome, welcome, O boat! O boat of my father, welcome, welcome, O boat!"

akk: ^ĝiš-ma2-gur8-ra zid2 im-ma-ab-gub-be2 duḫ im-ma-ab-[sal-e]  ĝiri3-ni gakkul zabar-ra im-ma-an-šu2-šu2  šu-si-ni ^ĝiš-bulug ^ĝiš-taškarin mu-na-bur12-bur12-re  aškud2-bi i3-ḫe-nun-na-ka šu ga-am3-ma-ni-ib-ur3  šag4-zu-a i3-nun lal3 ĝeštin niĝ2 ḫe2-ni-ib-gu-ul-gu-[ul-e]  si ^ĝiš-ma2-saĝ-ĝa2-zu suḫur^ku6- eštub^ku6- ul-ul ḫu-mu-ni-/ib\-[dug4]  ^ĝiš-ma2-e gu2-bi nu-mu-na-ab-šum2-mu nibru^ki--še3 ba-du-[un]
en: She laid out flour before the barge and spread bran. At her feet stood a covered bronze gakkul vat. { With her fingers she pulled out the boxwood bung for him :} "I shall rub precious oil on this peg. May ghee, syrup and wine be abundant in your midst, may the suḫur carp and the eštub carp rejoice at the prow of your boat!" But the boat did not give her its cargo: "I am going to Nibru!"

akk: nidba-a saĝ-bi ki unug^ki--ga eĝer-bi larsam/^ki-\-[ma]  e2-ta nu-e3 e2-ta nu-e3 e2-ta nam-ta-/ab\-[e3]  kug ^d-inana-ke4 e2-ta nu-e3 e2-ta nam-ta-ab-e3  silim-ma ḫe2-me-en silim-ma ḫe2-[me-en] ^ĝiš-ma2 silim-ma ḫe2-me-en  ^ĝiš-ma2 a-a-ĝu10 silim-ma ḫe2-me-en ^ĝiš-/ma2\ [silim-ma ḫe2]-/me\-en
en: Unug lay ahead of the offerings, Larsam lay behind them. She brought out of the house what should not come out of the house, what should not come out of the house -- holy Inana brought out of the house what should not come out of the house: "Welcome, welcome, welcome, O boat! O boat of my father welcome, welcome, O boat! { O boat of Suen welcome, welcome, O boat!}"
