akk: um-ma kur me sikil-še3 du-a-ni  ki-sikil ud-da-na til-la-gin7 im-ma-na-ta-e3  šembi2-zid-da igi-na mu-un-gun3  [tug2] babbar-ra zag mu-ni-in-keše2  [aga] zid-da iti6-gin7 mu-un-e3  [X] X X saĝ   [nitalam]-a-ni en-me-er-kar2 barag-ge4 mu-un-da-ab-si  […] um-mi-in-zi-zi  [ga-nam] im-da-lu-lu aratta^ki--aš u8-da sila4-bi  [ga-nam im]-da-lu-lu aratta^ki--aš ud5-da maš2-bi  [ga-nam im]-da-lu-lu aratta^ki--aš ab2-da amar-bi  [ga-nam] /im\-da-lu-lu aratta^ki--aš eme5 dur3^ur3- kaš4 gig2-ga-<bi>  aratta^ki--a na-an-da-be2-a  [guru7-še3] ḫe2-em-dub-dub gu2 ḫe2-em-ĝar-ĝar  [ḫe2]-/ĝal2\ za-a ḫe2-ĝal2-zu  […] en aratta^ki--ra u3-mu-ni-in-ak  […] X X X RA ḫe2-en-[X (X)]  […] mu-un-di-ni-ib-X-e  […] mu-un-ta-e3  […]
en: When the old woman came to the mountain of the shining me, she went up to him like a maiden who in her day is perfect, painted her eyes with kohl, wrapped herself in a white garment, came forth with the good crown like the moonlight. She arranged the …… on her head. She made Enmerkar, her spouse, occupy the throne-dais with her. She raised up ……, and indeed, for Aratta, the ewes and their lambs now multiply; indeed, for Aratta, the mother goats and their kids multiply; indeed, for Aratta, the cows and their calves multiply; indeed, for Aratta, the donkey mares and their black, swift-footed foals multiply. In Aratta, they say together: "Let them heap up and pile up for the grain piles; the abundance is truly your abundance." After having made …… for the lord of Aratta, let him ……. He will ……. He came forth ……, he set right for her. 3 lines missing

akk: […] me-te-aš […] ĝal2  […] X SI i-lu šag4-[ga …] X  […]-ni-a ḫe2-ĝal2-zu AN […]  […] ^d-en-lil2-le saĝ-eš mu-ri-in-rig7 [X]-/la\-la-ĝa2 ḫe2-zu-zu  […] kar2 a-a-ni nu-lam-lam a nu-un-de2  ^d-en-[lil2] [lugal] /kur\-kur-ra-ke4 ḫu-mu-un-kar2^?--re ni2-ba  eš2-gar3 /im\-ma-an-du3-a-gin7  nam-lu2-u18-[lu] aratta^ki--a-ke4  kug-sig17 kug ^na4-[za]-gin3 bal ak-de3 eš2-gar3 X (X) X  lu2 gurun kug-sig17 gurun ĝiš gub-bu-de3  ^ĝiš-peš3 ĝeštin-ba niĝ2-ta ub4-ba-gin7 guru7 gal-še3 [u3]-mu-un-dub  ^na4-za-gin3 duru5 ur2-ba mu-un-bur2-re-ne  ^gi-ušub pa-ba mu-un-ta-bal-e-ne  ^d-inana nin e2-an-na-ra  kisal e2-an-na^ki--ka guru7-še3 mu-un-dub-bu-ne
en: "…… befitting ……, …… the ilu song of the heart, …… your abundance in his ……. Enlil has granted you ……, and may …… be made known. …… his father was not luxuriantly fertile, and poured forth no semen. Enlil, king of all the lands ……. In accordance with the tasks which he has now established, the people of Aratta …… their task of plying gold, silver and lapis lazuli; the men who …… golden fruit, fruit trees, with their figs and grapes, shall heap the fruit up in great mounds ……; and shall dig out the flawless lapis lazuli from the roots of the trees, and shall remove the succulent part of the reeds from the crowns of the trees, and then shall heap them up in a pile in the courtyard of E-ana for Inana, the lady of E-ana."

akk: lugal-ĝu10 ĝa2-nu na ga-e-de5 na de5-ĝu10 ḫe2-e-dab5  inim ga-ra-ab-dug4 ĝizzal ḫe2-e-ak  lu2 X /BI^?- E\ kur-kur-ra uĝ3-e u3-/un\-pad3  [nam-lu2]-/ulu3\ aratta^ki--[ke4]  [X]-me-eš2 i-im-da ḫe2-em-me-ne  ĝe26-e gu2-e-ta du-a-ĝu10-ne  /nam-lugal\-ĝu10 nin mul-mul-e ma-an-šum2  ^d-ĝeštin-an-na […]  iri-ba lil2 […]  ezen nu-mu-[…]  ud šu2-uš nam-[…]
en: "Come, my king, I shall offer you advice: let my counsel be heeded. I shall speak words to you; let them be heard. Let the people choose a man …… of the foreign lands, and let the people of Aratta speak ……. When I go from here, the ever-sparkling lady gives me my kingship. Ĝeštin-ana ……. In that city ……, festivals were not ……. Daily ……." approx. 6 lines missing

akk: kul-aba4^ki- iri^ki- an ki-da mu2-a  unug^ki--ga mu-bi ^d-tir-an-na-gin7  an-ne2 us2-sa-bi si-muš3 gun3-a  an-na gub-ba-bi ud-sakar gibil na-nam
en: Brickwork rising out {from the pristine mountain} { of the shining plain} -- Kulaba, city which reaches from heaven to earth; Unug, whose fame like the rainbow reaches up to the sky, a multicoloured sheen, as the new moon standing in the heavens.

akk: me gal-[gal] nam-nun-na du3-a  kur sikil-la ud dug3-ga ki ĝar-ra  iti6-gin7 kalam-ma e3-a  ud zalag-gin7 kalam-ma   ab2-ur3 ab2-saḫarx(NE)-gin7 ḫe-nun-ta e3-a  unug^ki--ga ka tar-ra-bi kur-ra ba-te  me-lem4-bi kug-me-a zid-da-am3  aratta^ki--a tug2-gin7 ba-e-dul gada-gin7 ba-e-bur2
en: Built in magnificence with all the great powers, lustrous mount founded on a favourable day, like moonlight coming up over the land, like bright sunlight radiating over the land, the rear cow and …… cow coming forth in abundance: all this is Unug, the glory of which reaches the highland and its radiance, genuine refined silver, covers Aratta like a garment, is spread over it like linen.

akk: ud-ba ud en-na-am3 ĝi6 barag-ga-am3 ^d-utu lugal-am3  sukkal en aratta^ki--ka sukkal an-sig7-ga-ri-a mu-ni ḫe2-en-na-nam  sukkal en-me-er-kar2 en kul-aba4^ki--ke4 nam-en-na-tum2-ma mu-ni  en uru e-ne nun uru e-ne  en MI uru e-ne nun MI uru e-ne  en MI-MI uru e-ne nun MI-MI uru e-ne  lu2 diĝir-še3 tu-ud e-ne  lu2 diĝir-še3 pa e3 e-ne  en unug^ki--ga en kul-aba4^ki--ra ur5-bi a-da-min3 na-e-de3  en aratta^ki- en-suḫ-gir11-an-na-ke4  igi-bi igi unug^ki--še3 kiĝ2-gi4-a-ar inim mu-na-ni-ib2-be2
en: At that time the day was lord, the night was sovereign, and Utu was king. Now the name of the lord of Aratta's minister was minister Ansiga-ria. The name of the minister of Enmerkar, the lord of Kulaba, was Namena-tuma. He with the …… lord, he with the …… prince; he with the …… lord, he with the …… prince; he with the …… lord, he with the …… prince; he with the man born to be a god; he with a man manifest as a god, with the lord of Unug, the lord of Kulaba -- En-suḫgir-ana, the lord of Aratta, is to make a contest with him, saying first to the messenger concerning Unug:

akk: e-ne ĝa2-a-ra gu2 ḫa-ma-an-ĝa2-ĝa2 ^ĝiš-šudul4 ḫa-ma-ab-il2-e  ud-da gu2 ma-an-ĝar gu2 na-ma-an-ĝar u3 e-ne u3 ĝe26-e  [e-ne] ^d-inana-da e2-ĝar8-a-ka ḫu-mu-da-an-til3  [ĝe26]-/e\ ^d-inana-da e2-za-gin3 aratta^ki--ka ḫu-mu-da-an-til3-e-en  ĝiš-nu2 girin-a-ka ḫu-mu-un-de3-nu2  še-er-kan2 dug4 u3 dug3 ku-ku-de3 ḫu-mu-de3-nu2-en  e-ne ^d-inana-da ĝi6-a ma-mu2-da igi ḫu-mu-ni-in-du8  ĝe26-e ^d-inana-da ĝiri3 babbar-ra-na inim mu-da-bal-e  e-ne kur-gi4^mušen- še ḫe2-bi2-ib2-gu7-e  ĝe26-e kur-gi4^mušen- še ba-ra-bi2-ib2-gu7-e  ĝe26-e kur-gi4^mušen- nunuz-bi ĝir3-lam-ma amar-[bi ĜAR la2-e]  tur-tur-bi utul2-ĝu10-še3 gal-gal šen maḫ-[ĝu10-še3]  kur-gi4^mušen- ki-a ba-ra-ab-taka4-[a-bi]  ensi2 kur-ra-ke4 gu2 mu-un-ĝar-[re-eš-a] mu-da-an-gu7-[u3-ne]  en-me-er-kar2-ra ur5-gin7 inim mu-na-ab-[be2]
en: "Let him submit to me, let him bear my yoke. If he submits to me, indeed submits to me, then as for him and me -- he may dwell with Inana within a walled enclosure , but I dwell with Inana in the E-zagin of Aratta; he may lie with her on the splendid bed, but I lie in sweet slumber with her on the adorned bed, he may see dreams with Inana at night, but I converse with Inana awake. He may feed the geese with barley, but I will definitely not feed the geese with barley. I will …… the geese's eggs in a basket and …… their goslings. The small ones into my pot, the large ones into my kettle, and the rulers of the land who submitted will consume, together with me, what remains from the geese." This is what he said to Enmerkar.

akk: kiĝ2-gi4-a du-ni šeg9-bar-ra-am3 im2-mi-da-ni sur2-du3^mušen--am3  ud-dam i3-e3 an-u2-sa11-an-na-am3 i3-gi4-gi4  buru5^mušen- ud zal-le-da-gin7 gaba ki zag im-gub  buru5^mušen- ĝi6 MAŠ-gin7 kur-šag4-ge im-si  ^ĝiš-ilar-gin7 zag im-gub-gub-be2  dur3^ur3- uru16 gal-gin7   dur3^ur3- sal-la kaš4-e kiĝ2-ĝa2 du-ru-uš bur2  ur-maḫ a-šag4-ga ud zal-la mur-ma-ra mu-un-ša4  ur-bar-ra sila4 šu ti-a-gin7 ul4-ul4-e im-ĝen  ki tur-tur-bi /mu\-un-ĝen-na-a DUL3-a mu-na-ab-si  ki gal-gal-/bi\ mu-un-ĝen-na-a bulug-ga mu-na-ab-be2
en: The messenger runs like a wild ram and flies like a falcon. He leaves in the morning and returns already at dusk, like small birds at dawn, he …… over the open country, like small birds at midnight, he hides himself in the interior of the mountains. Like a throw-stick, he stands at the side. Like a solitary donkey of Šakkan, he {runs over} { cuts through} the mountains, he dashes like a large, powerful donkey. A slim donkey, eager to run, he rushes forth. A lion in the field at dawn, he lets out roars; like a wolf which has seized a lamb, he runs quickly. The small places he has reached, he fills with …… for him; the large places he has reached, he …… boundary .

akk: en-me-er-kar2 <ki> kug-kug-ga-ni-še3 im-ma-ši-in-ku4-ku4  za-e-še3 lugal-ĝu10 mu-e-ši-in-gi4-gi4  en aratta^ki- en-suḫ-gir11-an-na-ke4 mu-e-ši-in-gi4-gi4  lugal-zu dug4-ga-ni nam-ĝu10 taḫ-a-ni nam-ĝu10  en-suḫ-gir11-an-na-ke4 dug4-<ga>-ni nam-ĝu10 taḫ-a-ni nam-ĝu10  lugal-ĝu10 a-na bi2-in-dug4 a-na bi-in-taḫ-am3  en-suḫ-gir11-an-na-ke4 a-na bi2-in-dug4 a-na bi2-in-taḫ-am3  lugal-ĝu10 na-ab-be2-a  e-ne ĝa2-a-ra gu2 ḫa-ma-an-ĝa2-ĝa2 ^ĝiš-šudul4 ḫa-ma-ab-il2-e  ud-da gu2 ma-an-ĝar gu2 [na-ma-an-ĝar u3 e]-/ne\ u3 ĝe26-e  e-ne ^d-inana-da e2-/ĝar8\-[a-ka ḫu-mu-da]-an-til3  ĝe26-e ^d-inana-da e2-za-gin3 [aratta^ki--ka ḫu-mu]-da-an-til3-en  ĝiš-nu2 girin-a-ka ḫu-mu-un-[de3-nu2]  še-er-kan2 dug4 u3 dug3 ku-ku-da [ḫu-mu-de3-nu2-en]  e-ne ^d-inana-da ĝi6-a ma-/mu2\-[da igi ḫu-mu-ni-in-du8]  ĝe26-e ^d-inana-da ĝiri3 babbar-ra-na inim [mu-da-bal-e]  e-ne kur-gi4^mušen- še ḫe2-bi2-[ib2-gu7-e]  ĝe26-e kur-gi4^mušen- še ba-ra-bi2-[ib2-gu7-e]  ĝe26-e kur-gi4^mušen- nunuz-bi ĝir3-lam-[ma amar-bi ĜAR la2-e]  tur-tur-bi utul2-ĝu10-še3 gal-gal šen maḫ-ĝu10-še3  kur-gi4^mušen- ki-a ba-ra-ab-taka4-bi  ensi2 kur-ra /gu2\ [mu]-/un\-ĝar-re-eš-am3 [mu-da]-gu7-u3-ne
en: He entered the presence of the lord in {his holy ĝipar} { in his most holy place}. { He entered the presence of Enmerkar in his most holy place.} "My king has sent me to you. The lord of Aratta, En-suḫgir-ana, has sent me to you." {  "What does your king have to tell me, what does he have to add to me? What does En-suḫgir-ana have to tell me, what does he have to add to me?" "This is what my king said, what he added, this is what En-suḫgir-ana said, what he added."} "This is what my king says: "Let him submit to me, let him bear my yoke. If he submits to me, indeed submits to me, then as for him and me -- he may dwell with Inana within a walled enclosure , but I dwell with Inana in the E-zagin of Aratta; he may lie with her on the splendid bed, but I lie in sweet slumber with her on the adorned bed, he may see dreams with Inana at night, but I converse with Inana awake. He may feed the geese with barley, but I will definitely not feed the geese with barley. I will …… the geese's eggs in a basket and …… their goslings. The small ones into my pot, the large ones into my kettle, and the rulers of the land who submitted will consume, together with me, what remains from the geese.""

akk: en unug^ki--ga [X] si^?--muš3-bi X-da ^ĝiš-zi-gan-bi-im  […] ^ĝiš-rab3 šu ri-bi  […] ki us2-sa-a-ba  sur2-[du3]^mušen- an-na dal-e-da-bi gu mušen-na-bi-[im]  /šeg12\ [e2] gal aratta^ki--ka sur-sur maḫ ḫe2-[…]-/im^?-\  […] /gal\-gal aratta^ki--a /nam\ […] maḫ-bi-im  […] ba^?--DU-a-aš […] ĝal2
en: The lord of Unug …… he is their ……, he is their rudder. …… he is the neck-stock which clamps down upon them, …… to the place of its foundation. He is their falcon which flies in the sky, he is their bird-net. The brickwork of the great temple of Aratta ……. …… in Aratta …… great ……. …… bring …….

akk: [im]-gin7 šu bi2-in-ra im-gin7 igi i-ni-in-bar  [e-ne] ^d-inana-da e2-za-gin3 aratta-ka ḫu-mu-da-an-til3  ĝe26-e [X] /an\-ta ki-a gub-ba-ni ḫu-mu-da-an-til3-en  še-er-kan2-na dug4 u3 dug3 ku-ku-da ḫu-mu-un-de3-nu2-en  ĝe26-e ĝiš-nu2 gi-rin ^d-inana-ka u2 za-gin3 barag-ga-a-ba  eĝer-bi-še3 ug-am3 saĝ-bi-še3 piriĝ-am3  ug-e piriĝ im-sar-re  piriĝ-e ug [im]-sar-re  ug-e piriĝ im-[sar]-re-da-bi  piriĝ-e ug im-[sar]-re-da-bi  ud nu-um-zal ĝi6 [u3-na] nu-ru-gu2  ĝe26-e ^d-inana-da kaskal danna [15]-/am3\ šu ḫu-mu-un-da-[niĝin2-niĝin2]  ^d-utu suḫ kug-ĝa2 igi nu-mu-un-[bar]  ĝi6-par4 kug-ĝa2 ba-e-ši-in-[ku4-ku4]  ^d-en-lil2-le aga zid /ĝidru\ […]  ^d-nin-urta dumu ^d-en-lil2-la2-ke4  ĝiš ^kuš-ummud-da-gin7 ur2 mu-un-/tal2\-[tal2]  ^d-a-ru-ru nin9 ^d-en-lil2-la2-ke4  ubur zid-da-ni ma-an-la2 ubur gab2-bu-[ni ma-an-la2]  eš3 gal-še3 ed3-de3-da-ĝu10-ne  nu-gig-e anzud^mušen- amar-ra-gin7 mur /mu\-[ša4]  2-kam-ma-še3 ed3-de3-da-ĝu10-ne  uz amar-ra nu-me-en-na šeg11 mu-un-[gi4]  iri^ki- tud-da-ni-ta NE im-ta-[…]  iri^ki- du3-gin7 iri^ki- na-me ba-ra-dim2  ^d-inana unug^ki--ga ḫe2-en-til3 aratta^ki--aš a-na me-a-bi  šeg12 kul-aba4^ki--ka ḫe2-en-til3 kur me sikil-še3 a-na-am3 ab-ak-e  mu 5-am3 mu 10-am3 aratta^ki--aš ba-ra-ĝen  ud aratta^ki--aš in-ga-an-du-a-ba  kug gal nin e2-an-na-ke4  e-ne nu-tuku-da-am3 kur-gi4^mušen- še ba-ra-bi2-ib2-gu7-e  ĝe26-e kur-gi4^mušen- še ḫe2-bi2-ib2-gu7-e  ĝe26-e kur-gi4^mušen- nunuz-bi ĝir3-lam-ma amar-bi ĜAR la2-e  tur-tur-bi utul2-ĝu10-še3 gal-gal šen maḫ-ĝu10-še3  kur-gi4^mušen- ki-a ba-ra-ab-taka4-a-bi
en: He patted it like a lump of clay, he examined it like a clay-tablet: "He may dwell with Inana in the E-zagin of Aratta, but I dwell with her …… as her earthly companion . He may lie with her in sweet slumber on the adorned bed, but I lie on Inana's splendid bed strewn with pure plants. Its back is an ug lion, its front is a piriĝ lion. The ug lion chases the piriĝ lion, the piriĝ lion chases the ug lion. As the ug lion chases the piriĝ lion and the piriĝ lion chases the ug lion, the day does not dawn, the night does not pass. I accompany Inana for a journey of 15 leagues and yet Utu the sun god cannot see my holy crown, when she enters my holy ĝipar. Enlil has given me the true crown and sceptre. Ninurta, the son of Enlil, held me on his lap as the frame holds the waterskin. Aruru, the sister of Enlil, extended her right breast to me, extended her left breast to me. When I go up to the great shrine, the Mistress screeches like an Anzud chick, and other times when I go there, even though she is not a duckling, she shrieks like one. She …… from the city of her birth. No city was made to be so well-built as the city of Unug . It is Unug where Inana dwells and as regards Aratta, what does it have to do with this? It is brick-built Kulaba where she lives, and as regards the mount of the lustrous me, what can it do about this? For five or 10 years she will definitely not go to Aratta. Since the great holy lady of the E-ana took counsel with me about whether to go also to Aratta, since she {let me know} { told me} about this matter, I know that she will not go to Aratta. He who has nothing shall not feed the geese with barley, but I will feed the geese with barley. I will …… the geese's eggs in a basket and …… their goslings. The small ones into my pot, the old ones into my kettle, and the rulers {of the Land} { of Sumer} who submitted will consume, together with me, what remains from the geese."

akk: kiĝ2-gi4-a en-me-er-kar2 en-suḫ-gir11-an-na-ke4  ĝi6-par4 kug ki kug-kug-ga-ni-še3  ki kug-kug-ga ba-da-an-KU-a DAĜAL-bi ba-na-te  en-suḫ-gir11-an-na-ke4 a2 aĝ2-ĝa2 gu3 ba-an-de2 inim im-kiĝ2-kiĝ2-e  išib lu2-maḫ gudug ĝiri3-sig10-ga ĝi6-par4-ra til3-la  gu2 X mu-ni-in-ĝar šag4 mu-da-ab-kuš2-u3  a-na ga-an-na-ab-be2 a-na ga-an-na-ab-be2  en unug^ki--ga en kul-aba4^ki--ra a-na ga-an-na-ab-be2  [gud]-da-ni gud-ĝu10-da /lirum^?-\ im-da-ab-zig3  gud unug^ki--ga-ke4 a2 bi2-ib-ĝar  lu2-ni lu2-ĝu10-da usu im-da-ab-ra2  lu2 unug^ki--ga-ke4 a2 bi2-ib-ĝar  ur-ra-ni ur-ĝu10-da usu im-da-ab-ra
en: The messenger of Enmerkar reached En-suḫgir-ana, reached his holy ĝipar, his most holy place, the most holy place where he was sitting, its ……. En-suḫgir-ana asked for instructions, he searched for an answer. He summoned the išib priests, the lumaḫ priests, the gudug priests, and girsiga attendants who dwell in the ĝipar and took counsel with them. "What shall I say to him? What shall I say to him? What shall I say to the lord of Unug, the lord of Kulaba? His bull stood up to fight my bull and the bull of Unug has defeated it. His man has been struggling with my man and the man of Unug has defeated him. His warrior has been struggling with my warrior and the warrior of Unug …… him."

akk: unken ĝar-ra  mu-un-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4  za-e-me-en unug^ki--ga-še3 dub-saĝ-ta  niĝ2 gal-gal en-me-er-kar2-ra kiĝ2-gi4-a-aš mu-un-gi4  en-me-er-kar2 la-ba-du3-e-en za-e-me-en ba-e-du3-e-en  zi gi4-ba šag4-zu niĝ2 na-me na-an-tum3 en-na ba-e-zu-zu  iri-ĝu10 dul ḫe2-a ĝe26-e šika-bi ḫe2-me-en  en unug^ki--ga en kul-aba4^ki--ra gu2 ba-ra-na-an-ĝa2-ĝa2
en: The convened assembly answered him straightforwardly: "It was you who first sent a boastful message to Unug for Enmerkar. You cannot hold back Enmerkar, you have to hold back yourself. Calm down; your heart will prompt you to achieve nothing, as far as can be known ." "If my city becomes a ruin mound, then I will be a potsherd of it, but I will never submit to the lord of Unug, the lord of Kulaba."

akk: maš-maš dim2-ma-ni dumu ḫa-ma-zu-ke4  ur-ĝiri3-nun-na dim2-ma-ni dumu ḫa-ma-zu-ke4  ḫa-ma-zu ḫul-a-ta aratta^ki--aš bal-a  e2-ĝi6-par4 nam-maš-maš-e da^?--ga^?--na na-mu-un-KU  sukkal an-sig7-ga-ri-a gu3 mu-un-na-de2-e  lugal-ĝu10 ad-da gal-gal iri^ki--ke4-ne  [libir-ra uš] /ki\ ĝar-ra-ke4-ne  […] X-ka a-na-aš-am3 nu-um-ĝa2-ĝa2-ne ad nu-um-gi4-gi4-ne  [ĝe26-e id2] unug^ki--ga-ke4 ga-am3-ba-al  [itima] aratta^ki--ka gu2 ga-mu-ni-ib2-ĝar  [inim] [unug]^ki--ga-ke4 KA×X um-mi-in-tag  [erin2 gal-ĝu10 sig]-ta igi-nim-še3 ab-ta kur ^ĝiš-erin-še3  igi-nim-[ta kur] šim ^ĝiš-erin-na-še3 gu2 ga-mu-ni-ib-ĝar  unug^ki--ge niĝ2-gur11 ni2-ba-ke4 ^ĝiš-ma2 [ḫe2]-em-da-gid2-de3  ^ĝiš-ma2 ḫe2-em-da-la2-e e2-za-gin3 aratta^ki--še3  sukkal an-sig7-ga-ri-a iri^?--na mu-ni-zig3 KIŠI4-na mu-ni-šub
en: A sorcerer whose skill was that of a man of Ḫamazu, Ur-ĝiri-nuna, whose skill was that of a man of Ḫamazu, who came over to Aratta after Ḫamazu had been destroyed, practised sorcery in the inner chamber at the E-ĝipar. He said to minister Ansiga-ria: "My lord, why is it that the great fathers of the city, the founders in earlier times , do not ……, do not give advice. I will make Unug dig canals. I will make Unug submit to the shrine of Aratta. After the word of Unug ……, I will make the territories from below to above, from the sea to the cedar mountain, from above to the mountain of the aromatic cedars, submit to my great army. Let Unug bring its own goods by boat, let it tie up boats as a transport flotilla towards the E-zagin of Aratta." The minister Ansiga-ria rose up in his city, he …….

akk: [X] lu2 […] an-sig7-ga-ri-a na-mu-ni-X-/dug4\-X  […] X-e^?- nu-uš-ma-ab-X-[X]  lugal-ĝu10 ad-da gal-gal iri^ki--ke4-[ne]  libir-ra uš ki ĝar-ra-ke4-ne  ki /sukkal\ e2-gal-la a-na-aš-am3 [nu-um-ĝa2-ĝa2-ne] ad nu-um-[gi4-gi4-ne]  ĝe26-e id2 unug^ki--ga-ke4 ga-am3-ba-al  /itima\ aratta^ki--ka gu2 ga-mu-ni-ib-ĝar  inim unug^ki--ga-ke4 KA×X um-mi-in-tag  erin2 gal-ĝu10 sig-ta igi-nim-še3 ab-ta kur ^ĝiš-erin-še3  igi-nim-še3 kur šim ^ĝiš-erin-na-še3 gu2 ga-mu-ni-ib-ĝar  unug^ki--ga niĝ2-gur11 ni2-ba-ke4 ^ĝiš-ma2 ḫe2-em-da-gid2-de3  ^ĝiš-ma2 ḫe2-em-da-la2-e e2-za-gin3 aratta^ki--še3
en: …… Ansiga-ria ……, if only ……. "My lord, why is it that the great fathers of the city, the founders in earlier times , do not ……, do not give advice. I will make Unug dig canals. I will make Unug submit to the shrine of Aratta. After the word of Unug ……, I will make the territories from below to above, from the sea to the cedar mountain, from above to the mountain of the aromatic cedars, submit to my great army. Let Unug bring its own goods by boat, let it tie up boats as a transport flotilla towards the E-zagin of Aratta."

akk: en-ra ḫul2-la-gin7 im-ma-na-ni-ib-ĝar  5 ma-na kug-sig17 mu-na-ab-šum2-mu  5 ma-na kug-babbar mu-na-ab-šum2-mu  u2 nir-<ĝal2> gu7 ba-bi mu-na-ab-be2  a nir-<ĝal2> naĝ ba-bi mu-na-ab-be2  ud nam-ra-aš lu2-bi ak-am3  zi-zu niĝ2-ĝa2 a-la šu-zu ḫe2-ĝal2 mu-na-ab-be2
en: This made the lord extremely happy, so he gave five minas of gold to him, he gave five minas of silver to him. He promised him that he would be allotted fine food to eat, he promised him that he would be allotted fine drink to drink. "When their men are taken captive, your life …… happiness in your hand prosperity ," he promised to him.

akk: maš-maš engar numun saĝ-ĝa2-ke4  ereš2^ki- iri^ki- ^d-nisaba-še3 ĝiri3 im-ma-ab-gub-be2-en  ^e2-/tur3\-ra e2 ab2 dur2-ru-na-aš ba-te  ab2-[e] tur3-ra saĝ mu-da-ab-sag3  ab2-e inim bi2-in-dug4 lu2-ulu3-gin7 inim mu-da-ab-bal-e  ab2 i3-zu a-ba-a i3-gu7-e ga-zu a-ba-a i3-na8-na8  i3-ĝu10 i3-gu7-e ^d-nisaba-ke4  [ga]-ĝu10 i3-na8-na8 ^d-nisaba-ke4  [ga-ar3-ĝu10] suḫ10 kug galam dug4-ga  [unu6 gal] unu6 ^d-nisaba-ke4 me-te-a-aš im-mi-ib-ĝal2  i3-/ĝu10\ [tur3 kug]-ta en-na ga-mu-de6-a-aš  ga-ĝu10 [amaš] kug-ta en-na ga-mu-de6-a-aš  u3-sumun2 zid ^d-nisaba dumu-saĝ ^d-en-lil2-la2-ke4 lu2 nu-um-mi-in-zi-zi  ab2 i3-zu si-muš3-zu-še3 ga-zu murgu-[zu-še3]  ab2 i3-bi si-muš3-bi-še3 ba-ab-[BU] ga-bi murgu-bi-še3 ba-ab-BU ĝiri3 […]
en: The sorcerer, farmer of the best seeds, directed his steps towards Ereš, the city of Nisaba, and reached the animal pen, the house where the cows live. The cow trembled with fear at him in the animal pen. He made the cow speak so that it conversed with him as if it were a human being: "Cow, who will eat your butter? Who will drink your milk?" "My butter will be eaten by Nisaba, my milk will be drunk by Nisaba. My cheese, skilfully produced bright crown, was made fitting for the great dining hall, the dining hall of Nisaba. Until my butter is delivered from the holy animal pen, until my milk is delivered from the holy byre, the steadfast wild cow Nisaba, the first-born of Enlil, will not impose any levy on the people." "Cow, your butter to your shining horn; your milk to your back." So the cow's butter was …… to its shining horn; its milk was …… to its back …….

akk: amaš kug amaš ^d-nisaba-še3 ba-[te]  /ud5-de3\ amaš-a saĝ mu-da-ab-[sag3]  ud5-de3 inim bi2-in-dug4 lu2-[ulu3]-gin7 inim mu-un-da-ab-bal-[e]  /ud5\ i3-zu a-ba-a i3-gu7-e ga-zu a-ba-a [i3-na8]-/na8\  i3-ĝu10 i3-gu7-e ^d-nisaba-ke4  ga-ĝu10 i3-na8-na8 ^d-nisaba-ke4  ga-ar3-ĝu10 suḫ10 kug galam dug4-ga  unu6 gal unu6 ^d-nisaba-ke4 me-te-a-aš im-mi-ib-ĝal2  i3-ĝu10 tur3 kug-ta en-na ga-mu-un-de6-a-aš  ga-ĝu10 amaš [kug-ta] en-na ga-mu-un-de6-a-aš  u3-sumun2 zid ^d-nisaba dumu-saĝ ^d-en-lil2-la2-ke4 lu2 nu-um-mi-in-zi-zi  ud5 i3-zu si-muš3-zu-še3 ga-zu murgu-zu-še3  ud5 i3-bi si-muš3-bi-še3 ba-ab-BU ga-bi murgu-bi-še3 ba-ab-e3
en: He reached the holy byre, the byre of Nisaba. The goat trembled with fear at him in the byre. He made the goat speak so that it conversed with him as if it were a human being. "Goat, who will eat your butter? Who will drink your milk?" "My butter will be eaten by Nisaba, my milk will be drunk by Nisaba. My cheese, skilfully produced bright crown, was made fitting for the great dining hall, the dining hall of Nisaba. Until my butter is delivered from the holy animal pen, until my milk is delivered from the holy byre, the steadfast wild cow Nisaba, the first-born of Enlil, will not impose any levy on the people." "Goat, your butter to your shining horn, your milk to your back." So the goat's butter was …… to its shining horn; its milk was made to depart to its back.

akk: ud-bi-a tur3 amaš-a e2 sig9-ga ba-ab-du7 niĝ2 ḫa-lam-ma ba-ab-ak  ubur ab2-ka ga nu-un-ĝal2 amar-e ud bi2-/in\-šu2  amar tur-bi šag4-sug4-ga mu-un-ĝal2 er2 gig i3-še8-/še8\  ubur ud5-ka ga nu-un-[ĝal2 maš2-e ud bi2-in-šu2]  maš2-ud5-da-bi šag4-ka-tab-[ba ba-an-nu2] zi-bi mi-ni-[…]  ab2-e amar-bi-še3 inim gig [bi-ib2-be2]  ud5-de3 maš2-bi mu-na-ab-[…]  ^dug-šakir3 kug-ga sig9-si-ig X […] šag4-sug4-ga mu-un-ĝal2 šag4-ka-[tab-ba ba-an-nu2]
en: On that day the animal pen and the byre were turned into a house of silence; they were dealt a disaster. There was no milk in the udder of the cow, the day darkened for the calf, its young calf was hungry and wept bitterly. There was no milk in the udder of the goat; the day darkened for the kid. The buck-goat lay starving, its life ……. The cow spoke bitterly to its calf. The goat …… to its kid. The holy churn was empty, …… was hungry, …… lay starving.

akk: ud-bi-a tur3 amaš-a e2 sig9-ga ba-ab-dug4 niĝ2 ḫa-lam-ma ba-ab-ak  unud(UNU3)-de3 ešgiri2 šu-na bi2-in-taka4 igi-ni i3-sag3-ge  sipad-de3 šibir zag-ga-na bi2-in-la2 er2 gig i3-še8-še8  kab-bar tur amaš tur3-še3 la-ba-X ĝiri3 kur2 ba-ra-an-dab5  ga-il2-bi ad gal-eš2 nu-mu-ed3 sila kur2 ba-ra-an-dab5  /unud(UNU3)\ sipad ^d-nisaba-ke4-ne  dumu tud-da ama dili-me-eš  tur3 amaš-a a2 e3-a-me-eš  1-kam-ma maš2-gu-la mu-ni ḫe2-en-na-nam  2-kam-ma ur-edin-na mu-ni ḫe2-en-na-nam  2-na-ne-ne kan4 maḫ igi ^d-utu e3-a ki u6 di kalam-ma  saḫar-tu11-saḫar-tu11-ba ba-an-dur2-ru-ne-eš ^d-utu an-ta i-im-gi4-gi4-ne  maš-maš-e lu2 aratta^ki--ka ^e2-tur3-ra mu-un-kur9  ^e2-tur3-ra gara2 ba-an-kal amar tur la-ba-an-ri-ri  […] X-bi i3-šub-šub niĝ2 ḫa-lam-ma ba-ab-ak
en: On that day the animal pen and the byre were turned into a house of silence; they were dealt a disaster. The cow-herd dropped his staff from his hand: he was shocked. The shepherd hung the crook at his side and wept bitterly. The shepherd boy did not enter the byre and animal pen, but took another way; the milk carrier did not sing loudly, but took another road. The cow-herd and shepherd of Nisaba, sons born of the same mother, were brought up in the animal pen and byre. The name of the first one was Maš-gula, the name of the second one was Ur-edina. At the great gate, facing sunrise, the place marvelled at by the land, both of them crouched in the debris and appealed to Utu for help: "The sorcerer from Aratta entered the animal pen. He made the milk scarce, so the young calves could not get any. {In the animal pen and the byre he caused distress; he made the butter and milk scarce} { …… diminished ……, …… he made the milk of the goat scarce}. He threw its ……, …… was dealt a disaster."

akk: […] KA-bi ba-an-na-te  […] ĝal2-la-am3 igi mu-un-na-niĝin2  […] ereš2^ki- […]-X-an-gur  [gu2] /^id2-\buranun-na id2 NA^?- maḫ^?- KA ĝal2-la id2 diĝir-re-e-ne  [iri^ki- nam] tar-ra an ^d-en-lil2-la2 […] ĝiri3 bi2-in-gub  um-ma saĝ-bur-ru šu mu-un-na-/an\-[…]
en: …… approached. …… caused damage ……. …… turned toward Ereš. …… the Euphrates …… the river of the gods. She made her way to the city whose destiny was decreed by An and Enlil ……. Wise Woman Saĝburu …… hand …… for him.

Both of them threw fish spawn into the river. The sorcerer made a giant carp {come out} { arise} from the water. Wise Woman Saĝburu, however, made an eagle {come out} { arise} from the water. {The eagle seized the giant carp and fled to the mountains} { The eagle seized the giant carp out of the waves and went up to the sky}.

akk: 2-kam-ma-aš agargara id2-da i-ni-in-šub-bu-uš  ur-bar-ra u8 sila4^!--/bi\ in-kar edin daĝal-še3 ba-an-ur3
en: A second time they threw fish spawn into the river. The sorcerer made a ewe and its lamb {come out} { arise} from the water. Wise Woman Saĝburu, however, made a wolf {come out} { arise} from the water. The wolf seized the ewe and its lamb and dragged them to the wide desert.

A third time they threw fish spawn into the river. The sorcerer made a cow and its calf {come out} { arise} from the water. Wise Woman Saĝburu, however, made a lion {come out} { arise} from the water. The lion seized the cow and its calf and {took} { dragged} them to the reedbeds.

A fourth time they threw fish spawn into the river. The sorcerer made an ibex and a wild sheep {come out} { arise} from the water. Wise Woman Saĝburu, however, made a mountain leopard {come out} { arise} from the water. The leopard seized the ibex and the wild sheep and took them to the mountains.

akk: 5-kam-ma-aš agargara id2-da i-ni-in-šub-bu-uš  maš-maš-e amar maš-da3 a-ta im-ta-an-e3  um-ma saĝ-bur-ru ur-šub5 ur-nim-e a-ta im-ta-an-e3  maš-maš-e igi-ni ba-ku10-ku10 dim2-ma-ni ba-suḫ3
en: A fifth time they threw fish spawn into the river. The sorcerer made a gazelle kid come out from the water. Wise Woman Saĝburu, however, made a tiger and a …… lion come out from the water. The tiger and the …… lion seized the gazelle kid and {took} { dragged} them to the forest. What happened made the face of the sorcerer darken, made his mind confused.

akk: um-ma saĝ-bur-ru gu3 mu-na-de2-e  maš-maš nam-maš-maš-zu ḫe2-ĝal2 dim2-ma-zu me-a  a-na-gin7-nam ereš2^ki- iri ^d-nisaba-še3  iri^ki- nam tar-ra an ^d-en-lil2-la2  iri^ki- ul iri ki aĝ2 ^d-nin-lil2-la2  nam-maš-maš ak-de3 a-gin7 im-da-ĝen-ne-en
en: Wise Woman Saĝburu said to him: "Sorcerer, you do have magical powers, but where is your sense? How on earth could you think of going to do sorcery at Ereš, which is the city of Nisaba, a city whose destiny was decreed by An and Enlil, the primeval city, the beloved city of Ninlil?"

akk: /maš\-maš-e mu-un-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4  nu-zu-a-ĝu10-ne i-im-ĝen-ne-en  nam-gur4-ra-zu i3-zu nam-ba-an-sis-e-de3-en  šu giri17-na i-ni-in-ĝal2 šudu3 mu-un-na-an-ša4-aš  šu ba-mu-u8 nin-ĝu10 šu ba-mu-u8  silim-ma-bi iri^ki--ĝu10-še3 ga-ĝen  aratta^ki- kur me sikil-la-še3 zi-ĝu10 ga-ba-ši-de6  aratta^ki- kur me sikil-la-ka ka tar-zu ga-si-il
en: The sorcerer answered her: "I went there without knowing all about this. I acknowledge your superiority -- please do not be bitter." He pleaded, he prayed to her: "Set me free, my sister; set me free. Let me go in peace to my city. Let me return safely to Aratta, the mount of the lustrous me. I will {make known} { declare} your greatness in all the lands. I will sing your praise in Aratta, the mount of the lustrous me."

akk: um-ma saĝ-bur-ru mu-un-na-ni-ib-gi4-gi4  tur3 amaš-a niĝ2-gig-ga bi2-ak i3 ga ba-e-ni-kal  ^ĝiš-banšur an-bar7 ^ĝiš-banšur kiĝ2-[nim kiĝ2]-sig mu-e-sud  kiĝ2-sig unu6 gal-la i3 ga ba-e-kud niĝ2-gig-bi X DU  nam-tag-zu i3 ga […] nu-mu-e-tum3  ^d-nanna lugal X amaš-/a^?-\ MU X GA ba-e-šum2-mu  šer7-da i3-ĝa2-ĝa2 zi /nu-mu\-ra-ab-šum2-mu  um-ma saĝ-bur-ru maš-maš-e unken^?--ni inim-ma-ni mu-ni-in-sag3  šaĝa-a-ni gu2 ^id2-buranun-na-[ka] i-ni-in-šub  zi nam-til3-la ba-da-an-kar iri^ki--ni ereš2^ki--še3 ba-e-gur
en: Wise Woman Saĝburu answered to him: "You have caused distress in the animal pen and the byre; you have made the butter and milk scarce there. You have removed the lunch-table, the morning- and evening-table. You have cut off butter and milk from the evening meal of the great dining hall, ……… distress ……. Your sin that butter and milk …… cannot be forgiven. Nanna the king …… the byre …… milk; …… established that it was a capital offence and I am not pardoning your life." Wise Woman Saĝburu …… her decision about the sorcerer in the assembly . She threw her prisoner from the bank of the Euphrates. She seized from him his life-force and then returned to her city, Ereš.

akk: en-suḫ-gir11-an-na-ke4 inim-bi ĝiš ba-an-tuku-a-ta  en-me-er-kar2-ra lu2 mu-un-ši-in-gi4-gi4  za-e-me-en en ki aĝ2 ^d-inana-me-en dili-zu-ne maḫ-me-en  ^d-inana-ke4 ur2 kug-ga-ni-še3 zid-de3-eš mu-un-pad3-de3-en ki /aĝ2-ĝa2\-ni-me-en  sig-ta igi-nim-še3 en gal-bi za-e-me-en ĝe26-e us2-sa-zu-me-en   gaba-ri-zu nu-me-en šeš-gal za-e-me-en  ĝe26-e nu-mu-da-sa2-e-en ud da-ri2-še3
en: Having heard this matter, En-suḫgir-ana sent a man to Enmerkar: "You are the beloved lord of Inana, you alone are exalted. Inana has truly chosen you for her holy lap, you are her beloved. From the south to the highlands, you are the great lord, and I am only second to you; from the moment of conception I was not your equal, you are the older brother. I cannot match you ever."

akk: en-me-er-kar2 en-suḫ-gir11-an-na a-da-min3 dug4-ga  en-me-er-kar2 en-suḫ-gir11-an-na dirig-ga-a-ba  ^d-nisaba za3-mi2  […] BI SI  […]-ta  […]-an-dug4  [maš-maš-e] ki en-na-še3 lu2 mu-un-ni-in-ku4-ku4  ur-ĝiri3-nun-na ki en-na-še3 lu2 mu-ni-in-ku4-ku4  [maš]-maš-e sukkal ĜA2 an-sig7-ga-ri-a na-mu-un-ne-dug4-ga  [X]-bi-še3 nu-uš-[…]
en: In the contest between Enmerkar and En-suḫgir-ana, Enmerkar proved superior to En-suḫgir-ana. Nisaba, be praised!
3 lines unclear The sorcerer ……. Ur-ĝiri-nuna ……. The sorcerer …… minister Ansiga-ria. 1 line unclear

en: After the kingship descended from heaven, the kingship was in Eridug. In Eridug, Alulim became king; he ruled for 28800 years. Alalĝar ruled for 36000 years. 2 kings; they ruled for 64800 years. Then Eridug fell and the kingship was taken to Bad-tibira. In Bad-tibira, En-men-lu-ana ruled for 43200 years. En-men-gal-ana ruled for 28800 years. Dumuzid, the shepherd, ruled for 36000 years. 3 kings; they ruled for 108000 years. Then Bad-tibira fell and the kingship was taken to Larag. In Larag, En-sipad-zid-ana ruled for 28800 years. 1 king; he ruled for 28800 years. Then Larag fell and the kingship was taken to Zimbir. In Zimbir, En-men-dur-ana became king; he ruled for 21000 years. 1 king; he ruled for 21000 years. Then Zimbir fell and the kingship was taken to Šuruppag. In Šuruppag, Ubara-Tutu became king; he ruled for 18600 years. 1 king; he ruled for 18600 years. In 5 cities 8 kings; they ruled for 241200 years. Then the flood swept over.

akk: eĝer a-ma-ru ba-ur3-ra-ta  nam-lugal an-ta ed3-de3-a-ba  kiš^ki- nam-lugal-la  lugal-am3  mu 1200 i3-ak  kul2-la-si2-na-/be\-el  na-an-ĝiš-li-iš-ma  en-taraḫ-an-na-ke4  ba-bu-um X [(X)]  ka3-li2-bu-um  zu2-qa2-qi4-ip  ar-wi-u2-um dumu maš-da3-ke4  mu 720 i3-ak  e-ta-na sipad lu2 an-še3  ba-ed3-de3  lu2 kur-kur mu-un-gen6-na  ba-li-iḫ  dumu e-ta-na-ke4  me-lem4-kiš^ki- dumu en-me-nun-na-ke4  mu 900 i3-ak  1560 mu bal en-me-nun-na-kam  mu 1200 i3-ak  zamug(DUB)^za-mug- dumu bar-sal-nun-na-ke4  mu 140 i3-ak  ti-iz-qar dumu zamug(DUB)^za-mug--ke4  mu 305^!- i3-ak  1620^?- + X X [X X] X MU^?-  il-ku-u2 mu 900 i3-ak  il-ta-sa-du-um  mu 1200 i3-ak  en-me-en-barag-ge-si  lu2 ma-da elam^ki--ma  ^ĝiš-tukul-bi ib2-ta-an-gam  lugal-am3 mu 900 i3-ak  ag-ga3  dumu en-me-en-barag-ge-si-ke4  mu 625 i3-ak  /1525 mu\ [bal]  en-me-/barag\-[ge4-e-si]  23 lugal  mu-bi 24510 itid 3  ud 3 ud 1/2 ib2-ak  kiš^ki- ^ĝiš-tukul ba-an-sag3  nam-lugal-bi e2-an-na-še3 ba-de6
en: After the flood had swept over, and the kingship had descended from heaven, the kingship was in Kiš. In Kiš, Ĝušur became king; he ruled for 1200 years. Kullassina-bēl ruled for {960} { 900} years. Nanĝišlišma ruled for  {670} years. En-taraḫ-ana ruled for  {420} years ……, 3 months, and 3 1/2 days. Babum …… ruled for  {300} years. Puannum ruled for {840} { 240} years. Kalibum ruled for {960} { 900} years. Kalūmum ruled for {840} { 900} years. Zuqāqīp ruled for {900} { 600} years.  {Atab} { A-ba} ruled for 600 years. Mašda, the son of Atab, ruled for {840} { 720} years. Arwium, the son of Mašda, ruled for 720 years. Etana, the shepherd, who ascended to heaven and consolidated all the foreign countries, became king; he ruled for {1500} { 635} years. Baliḫ, the son of Etana, ruled for {400} { 410} years. En-me-nuna ruled for {660} { 621} years. Melem-Kiš, the son of En-me-nuna, ruled for 900 years. { 1560 are the years of the dynasty of En-me-nuna.} {Barsal-nuna, the son of En-me-nuna,} { Barsal-nuna} ruled for 1200 years. Zamug, the son of Barsal-nuna, ruled for 140 years. Tizqār, the son of Zamug, ruled for 305 years. { 1620 + X …….} Ilku ruled for 900 years. Iltasadum ruled for 1200 years. En-me-barage-si, who made the land of Elam submit, became king; he ruled for 900 years. Aga, the son of En-me-barage-si, ruled for 625 years. { 1525 are the years of the dynasty of En-me-barage-si.} 23 kings; they ruled for 24510 years, 3 months, and 3 1/2 days. Then Kiš was defeated and the kingship was taken to E-ana.

akk: e2-an-na-ka  meš3-ki-aĝ2-ga-še-er  dumu ^d-utu en-am3  meš3-ki-aĝ2-ga-še-er  ab-ba ba-an-kur9  ḫur-saĝ-še3 ba-an-ed3  en-me-er-kar2 dumu meš3-ki-aĝ2-ga-še-er  lugal unug^ki--ga lu2 unug^ki-  lugal-am3  745 mu [bal] meš3-ki-in-ga-še^?--[er]  ^d-lugal-ban3-da sipad  mu 1200 i3-ak  ^d-dumu-zid šu-KU6  iri^ki--ni kuara^ki-  šu dili en^?--me-barag-ge4-e-si  nam-ra /i3^?-\-ak^?-  ^d-gilgameš3  ab-ba-ni lil2-la2  en kul-ab-ba-ke4  mu 126 i3-ak  ur-^d-nun-gal  dumu ^d-gilgameš2  mu 30 i3-ak  u-dul3-kalam-ma  mu 15 i3-ak  la-ba-/a’^?--šum^?-\  mu 9 i3-ak  en-nun-taraḫ-an-na  mu 8 i3-ak  /meš3^?-\-ḫe2 simug mu 36 i3-ak  12 lugal  unug^ki- ^ĝiš-tukul ba-an-sag3  nam-lugal-bi urim2^ki--še3 ba-de6
en: In E-ana, Meš-ki-aĝ-gašer, the son of Utu, became lord and king; he ruled for {324} { 325} years. Meš-ki-aĝ-gašer entered the sea and disappeared. Enmerkar, the son of Meš-ki-aĝ-gašer, the king of Unug, {who built Unug} { under whom Unug was built}, became king; he ruled for {420} { 900 + X} years. { 745 are the years of the dynasty of Meš-ki-aĝ-gašer.} { ……; he ruled for 5 + X years.} Lugalbanda, the shepherd, ruled for 1200 years. Dumuzid, the fisherman whose city was Kuara, ruled for {100} { 110} years. { He captured En-me-barage-si single-handed.} Gilgameš, whose father was a phantom , the lord of Kulaba, ruled for 126 years. Ur-Nungal, the son of Gilgameš, ruled for 30 years. Udul-kalama, the son of {Ur-Nungal} { Ur-lugal}, ruled for 15 years. Lā-ba’šum ruled for 9 years. En-nun-taraḫ-ana ruled for 8 years. Meš-ḫe, the smith, ruled for 36 years. {Melem-ana} { Til-kug ……} ruled for {6} { 900} years. Lugal-kitun ruled for {36} { 420} years. 12 kings; they ruled for {2310} { 3588} years. Then Unug was defeated and the kingship was taken to Urim.

akk: urim2^ki--ma  meš3-an-ne2-pad3-da  lugal-am3 mu 80 i3-ak  dumu meš3-an-ne2-pad3-da  lugal-am3  urim2^ki- [^ĝiš-tukul] ba-an-sag3  nam-lugal-[bi]  a-wa-an^ki--[še3] [ba-de6]
en: In Urim, Meš-Ane-pada became king; he ruled for 80 years. {Meš-ki-aĝ-Nanna} { Meš-ki-aĝ-nuna}, the son of Meš-Ane-pada, became king; he ruled for {36} { 30} years. Elulu ruled for {25} years. Balulu ruled for {36} years. {4} kings; they ruled for {171} years. Then Urim was defeated and the kingship was taken to Awan.

en: In Awan, …… became king; he ruled for …… years. …… ruled for …… years. …… ruled for 36 years. 3 kings; they ruled for 356 years. Then Awan was defeated and the kingship was taken to Kiš.

en: In Kiš, Susuda, the fuller, became king; he ruled for 201 + X years. Dadasig ruled for  {81} years. Mamagal, the boatman, ruled for {360} { 420} years. Kalbum, the son of {Mamagal} { Magalgal}, ruled for {195} { 132} years. Tuge ruled for 360 years. Men-nuna {, the son of Tuge ,} ruled for 180 years.  …… ruled for 290 years. Lugalĝu ruled for {360} { 420} years. 8 kings; they ruled for {3195} { 3792} years. Then Kiš was defeated and the kingship was taken to Ḫamazi.

en: In Ḫamazi, Hadaniš became king; he ruled for 360 years. 1 king; he ruled for 360 years. Then Ḫamazi was defeated and the kingship {was taken} { was returned a second time} to Unug.

akk: unug^ki--ga en-šakkan2-ša4-an-na  lugal-am3 mu 1 šu-ši i3-ak  ar-ga-an-de2-a 7 mu i3-ak  /nam\-lugal-bi /urim2\-[še3] [ba-de6]
en: In Unug, En-šag-kuš-ana became king; he ruled for 60 years. {Lugal-ure} { Lugal-kiniše-dudu } ruled for 120 years. Argandea ruled for 7 years.  {3} kings; they ruled for  {187} years. Then Unug was {defeated} { destroyed} and the kingship was taken to Urim.

en: In Urim, Nanni became king; he ruled for { 120 + X} { 54 + X} years. Meš-ki-aĝ-Nanna, the son of Nanni, ruled for {48} years. {……, the son of ……, ruled for {2} years. {3} kings; they ruled for { 582} { 578} years.} { 2 kings; they ruled for 120 + X years.} Then Urim was {defeated} { destroyed} and the kingship was taken to Adab.
In Adab, Lugal-Ane-mundu became king; he ruled for {90} years. {1} king; he ruled for {90} years. Then Adab was {defeated} { destroyed} and the kingship was taken to Mari.

akk: «AN» ba-zi ^lu2-ašgab mu 30 i3-ak  zi-zi ^lu2-azlag2 mu 20 i3-ak  /li^?-\-im-er gudug mu 30 i3-ak  6 lugal  nam-lugal-bi  kiš^ki--še3 ba-de6
en: In Mari, Anbu became king; he ruled for {30} { 90} years. Anba , the son of Anbu , ruled for {17} { 7} years. Bazi, the leatherworker, ruled for 30 years. Zizi, the fuller, ruled for 20 years. Limer, the gudug priest, ruled for 30 years. Šarrum-īter ruled for {9} { 7} years. 6 kings; they ruled for {136} { 184} years. Then Mari was {defeated} { destroyed} and the kingship was taken to Kiš.

akk: kiš^ki--a kug-^d-ba-u2  ^f-lu2-kurun-na  suḫuš kiš^ki- mu-un-gen6-na  lugal-am3 mu 100 i3-ak  1 lugal  mu-bi 100 i3-ak  nam-lugal-bi akšak^ki--<še3> ba-de6
en: In Kiš, Kug-Bau, the woman tavern-keeper, who made firm the foundations of Kiš, became king; she ruled for 100 years. 1 king; she ruled for 100 years. Then Kiš was {defeated} { destroyed} and the kingship was taken to Akšak.

akk: akšak^ki--a un-zi  lugal-am3 mu 30 i3-ak  nam-lugal-bi  kiš^ki--še3 ba-de6
en: In Akšak, Unzi became king; he ruled for 30 years. Undalulu ruled for {6} { 12} years. Urur {ruled for} { was king for} 6 years. Puzur-Niraḫ ruled for {20} years. Išu-Il ruled for {24} years. Šu-Suen, the son of Išu-Il, ruled for { 7} { 24} years. { {6} kings; they ruled for { 99} { 116} years} { 5 kings; they ruled for {87} years}. {Then Akšak was defeated} { Then the reign of Akšak was abolished} and the kingship was taken to Kiš.

akk: kiš^ki--a puzur4-^d-suen  dumu kug-^d-ba-u2-ke4  lugal-am3 mu 25 i3-ak  ur-^d-za-ba4-ba4  dumu puzur4-^d-suen-/na\-ke4  131^?- mu /bal\ kug-ba-u2-/kam\  iš-me-^d-šamaš mu 11 i3-ak  šu-i3-li2-šu  15 mu i3-ak
en: In Kiš, Puzur-Suen, the son of Kug-Bau, became king; he ruled for 25 years. Ur-Zababa, the son of Puzur-Suen, ruled for {400} { 6} { 4 + X} years. { 131 are the years of the dynasty of Kug-Bau.} {Zimudar} { Ziĝu-iake} ruled for {30} { 30 + X} years. Usi-watar, the son of {Zimudar} { Ziĝu-iake}, ruled for {7} { 6} years. Eštar-muti ruled for {11} { 17 } years. Išme-Šamaš ruled for 11 years. { Šu-ilīšu ruled for 15 years.} {Nanniya, the jeweller,} { Zimudar} { ……} ruled for {7} { 3} years. {7 kings; they ruled for {491} { 485} years} { 8 kings; they ruled for {586} years}. {Then Kiš was defeated} { Then the reign of Kiš was abolished} and the kingship {was taken} { was returned a third time} to Unug.

akk: unug^ki--ga lugal-zag-ge-si  1 lugal  nam-lugal-bi  a-ga-de3^ki--še3 ba-de6
en: In Unug, Lugal-zage-si became king; he ruled for {25} { 34} years. 1 king; he ruled for {25} { 34} years. {Then Unug was defeated} { Then the reign of Unug was abolished} and the kingship was taken to Agade.

akk: a-ga-de3^ki--a šar-ru-ki-in  ab-ba-ni nu-kiri6  sagi ur-^d-za-ba4-ba4  lugal a-ga-de3^ki- lu2 a-ga-de3^ki-  ri2-mu-uš dumu šar-ru-ki-in  ma-ni-iš-ti-iš-šu  šeš-gal ri2-mu-uš  dumu šar-ru-ki-in  na-ra-am-/^d-\[suen]  dumu ma-ni-iš-ti-iš-[šu]  šar-ka3-li2-šar-ri2  dumu na-ra-am-^d-suen  /157\ mu [bal]  /šar\-ru-ki2-nim  ir-gi4-gi4 lugal  i-mi lugal  na-nu-um lugal  i-lu-lu lugal  du-du mu 21 i3-ak  šu-dur-ul3 dumu du-du-ke4  nam-lugal-bi unug^ki--še3 ba-de6
en: In Agade, Sargon, whose father was a gardener, the cupbearer of Ur-Zababa, became king, the king of Agade, {who built Agade} { under whom Agade was built}; he ruled for {56} { 55} { 54} years. Rīmuš, the son of Sargon, ruled for {9} { 7} { 15} years. Man-ištiššu, the older brother of Rīmuš, the son of Sargon, ruled for {15} { 7} years. Narām-Suen, the son of Man-ištiššu, ruled for {56} years. Šar-kali-šarrī, the son of Narām-Suen, ruled for { 25} { 24} years. { 157 are the years of the dynasty of Sargon.} Then {who was the king? Who was not the king?} { who was the king? Who indeed was the king?} Irgigi was king, Imi was king, Nanûm was king , Ilulu was king, and the {4} of them ruled for only {3} years. Dudu ruled for 21 years. Šu-Durul, the son of Dudu, ruled for {15} { 18} years. {11 kings; they ruled for 181 years} { 12 kings; they ruled for {197} years} { 9 kings; they ruled for { 161} { 177} years}. {Then Agade was defeated} { Then the reign of Agade was abolished} and the kingship was taken to Unug.

akk: unug^ki--ga ur-niĝin3 lugal-am3  ur-^ĝiš-gigir dumu ur-niĝin3-ke4  kud-da mu 6 i3-ak  nam-lugal-bi
en: In Unug, Ur-niĝin became king; he ruled for {7} { 3} { 15} { 30} years. Ur-gigir, the son of Ur-niĝin, ruled for {6} { 7} { 15} { 7} years. Kuda ruled for 6 years. Puzur-ilī ruled for {5} { 20} years. {Ur-Utu ruled for 6} { Ur-Utu, the son of Ur-gigir, ruled for 25} { Lugal-melem, the son of Ur-gigir, ruled for 7} years. {5 kings; they ruled for {30} { 43} { 26} years} { 3 kings; they ruled for {47} years}. {Unug was defeated} { Then the reign of Unug was abolished} and the kingship was taken to the {army} { land} of Gutium.

en: In the {army} { land} of Gutium, at first {no king was famous; they were their own kings and ruled thus for 3 years} { they had no king; they ruled themselves for 5 years}. Then {Inkišuš} { ……} ruled for {6} { 7} years. Zarlagab ruled for 6 years. {Šulme} { Yarlagaš} ruled for 6 years. {Silulumeš} { Silulu} ruled for {6} { 7} years. {Inimabakeš ruled for 5} { Duga ruled for 6} years. {Igešauš ruled for 6} { Ilu-an ruled for 3} years. Yarlagab ruled for {15} { 5} years. Ibate ruled for 3 years. {Yarla} { Yarlangab } ruled for 3 years. {Kurum} { ……} ruled for {1} { 3} years. Apilkin ruled for 3 years. Lā-erabum ruled for 2 years. Irarum ruled for 2 years. Ibranum ruled for 1 year. Ḫablum ruled for 2 years. Puzur-Suen, the son of Ḫablum, ruled for 7 years. Yarlaganda ruled for 7 years. …… ruled for 7 years. Tirigan ruled for 40 days. 21 kings; they ruled for { 124 years and 40 days} { 25 years}. Then the army of Gutium was {defeated} { destroyed} and the kingship was taken to Unug.

akk: unug^ki--ga ^d-utu-ḫe2-ĝal2 [lugal]-am3  1 lugal  unug^ki- ^ĝiš-tukul ba-an-sag3  nam-lugal-bi urim2^ki--še3 ba-de6
en: In Unug, Utu-ḫeĝal became king; he ruled for {427 years, …… days} { 26 years, 2 + X months, and 15 days} { 7 years, 6 months, and 15 days} { 7 years, 6 months, and 5 days}. 1 king; he ruled for {427 years, …… days} { 7 years, 6 months, and 15 days} { 7 years, 6 months, and 5 days}. Then Unug was defeated and the kingship was taken to Urim.

akk: urim2^ki--ma ur-^d-namma lugal-am3  mu 18 i3-ak  ^d-šul-gi dumu ur-^d-namma-ke4  ^d-amar-^d-suen-na dumu ^d-šul-gi-ke4  šu-^d-suen dumu ^d-amar-^d-suen-na-ke4  i-bi2-^d-suen dumu šu-^d-suen-ke4  suḫuš /ki\-[en-gi-ra] mu-/un\-[bu]  nam-lugal-bi i3-si-in^ki--še3 ba-de6
en: In Urim, Ur-Namma became king; he ruled for 18 years. Šulgi, the son of Ur-Namma, ruled for {46} { 48} { 58} years. Amar-Suena, the son of Šulgi, ruled for {9} { 25} years. Šu-Suen, the son of Amar-Suena, ruled for {9} { 7} { 20 + X} { 16} years. Ibbi-Suen, the son of Šu-Suen, ruled for {24} { 25} { 15} { 23 } years. {4 kings; they ruled for 108 years} { 5 kings; they ruled for { 117} { 120 + X} { 123} years}. {Then Urim was defeated} { Then the reign of Urim was abolished}. { The very foundation of Sumer was torn out .} The kingship was taken to Isin.

akk: i3-si-in^ki--na iš-bi-^d-er3-ra lugal-am3  šu-i3-li2-šu dumu iš-bi-^d-er3-ra-ke4  i-din-^d-da-gan dumu šu-i3-li2-šu-ke4  iš-me-^d-da-gan dumu i-din-^d-da-gan-ke4  ^d-bur-^d-suen dumu ^d-ur-^d-nin-urta-ke4  mu 21 i3-ak  ^d-li-pi2-it-^d-en-lil2  dumu bur-^d-suen-ke4 mu 5 i3-ak  /DA^?-\ [X X X] (X) X itid 6 /in\-[ak]  ^d-en-lil2-ba-ni mu 24 i3-ak  ^d-za-am-bi-ia mu 3 i3-ak  ^d-i-te-er-pi4-ša mu 4 i3-ak  ^d-ur-du6-kug-ga mu 4 i3-ak  ^d-suen-ma-gir mu 11 i3-ak  da-/mi\-iq-i3-li2-šu dumu ^d-suen-ma-gir mu 23 [in-ak]  14(source: 13) lugal
en: In Isin, Išbi-Erra became king; he ruled for {33} { 32} years. Šu-ilīšu, the son of Išbi-Erra, ruled for {20} { 10} { 15} years. Iddin-Dagan, the son of Šu-ilīšu, ruled for {21} { 25} years. Išme-Dagan, the son of Iddin-Dagan, ruled for { 20} { 18} years. Lipit-Eštar, the son of {Išme-Dagan} { Iddin-Dagan}, ruled for {11} years. Ur-Ninurta { , the son of Iškur -- may he have years of abundance, a good reign, and a sweet life --} ruled for {28} years. Būr-Suen, the son of Ur-Ninurta, ruled for 21 years. Lipit-Enlil, the son of Būr-Suen, ruled for 5 years. Erra-imitti ruled for {8} { 7} years. { …… ruled for …… 6 months.} Enlil-bāni ruled for 24 years. Zambiya ruled for 3 years. Iter-piša ruled for 4 years. Ur-du-kuga ruled for 4 years. Suen-magir ruled for 11 years. { Damiq-ilišu, the son of Suen-magir, ruled for 23 years.} 14 kings; they ruled for {203 years} { 225 years and 6 months}.

akk: šu-niĝin2 40^!--la2-[1 lugal]  mu-bi /14400\ + [X] + 9 mu [3 itid 3 1/2 ud] ib2-ak  a-ra2 4-[kam]  šag4 kiš[^ki-]  /šu-niĝin2\ 22 /lugal\  mu-bi 2610 + [X] 6 itid 15 ud ib2-ak  a-ra2 5-kam  šag4 unug^ki--ga  šu-niĝin2 12 lugal  mu-bi 396 mu ib2-ak  /a-ra2\ 3-kam  [šag4] urim2^ki--ma  /šu-niĝin2\ 3 lugal  mu-bi 356 mu ib2-ak  a-ra2 1-kam  šag4 a-wa-an^ki-  [šu]-niĝin2 1 lugal  mu-bi 420 mu [i3]-ak  a-ra2 1-[kam]  šag4 /ḫa^?-\-[ma]-/zi\^ki--a  [šu-niĝin2 12] lugal  [mu-bi 60] + 137 [mu] ib2-ak  [a]-/ra2\ 1-kam  [šag4] /a\-ga-de3^ki-  a-ra2 1-kam  /šag4\ ugnim  /gu\-ti-um^ki-  [šag4] [i]-/si-in\^ki--na  11 iri^ki-  [iri]/^ki-\ nam-lugal-la /ib2\-ak-ka3  [šu]-niĝin2  /21\
en: A total of 39 kings ruled for 14409 + X years, 3 months and 3 1/2 days, 4 times in Kiš. A total of 22 kings ruled for 2610 + X years, 6 months and 15 days, 5 times in Unug. A total of 12 kings ruled for 396 years, 3 times in Urim. A total of 3 kings ruled for 356 years, once in Awan. A total of 1 king ruled for 420 years, once in Ḫamazi. 16 lines missing A total of 12 kings ruled for 197 years, once in Agade. A total of {21} { 23} kings ruled for {125 years and 40 days} { 99 years}, once in the army of Gutium. A total of {11} { 16} kings ruled for {159} { 226} years, once in Isin. There are 11 cities, cities in which the kingship was exercised. A total of {134} { 139} kings, who altogether ruled for {28876 + X} { 3443 + X} years. 21.

akk: [eĝer a]-/ma\-ru ba-ur3-ra-ta  [u3]  /gel\-le-eĝ3  kur-ra-ke4 ba-an-ĝar-ra-ta  /nam-lu2\-ulu3 da-re-eš i-ak-a-ba  numun nam-lu2-/ulu3\ im-mi-in-taka4-a-ba  uĝ3 saĝ gig2-ga ni2-bi-a im-mi-in-il2-la-a-ba  ud an-ne2 ^d-en-lil2-le  nam-lu2-ulu3 mu-bi sa4-a-ta  u3 nam-ensi2 in-/ĝar-ra\-ta  nam-/lugal\ aga /iri-am3\  an-/ta\ [nu]-ub-ta-an-e3-[a-ba]  ^d-/nin-ĝir2\-su ^ĝiš-al ^ĝiš-[mar]  ^gi-dusu ^ĝiš-apin-e zi-šag4-ĝal2 /kalam\-[ma]  uĝ3 sig10-ga šar2-a nu-ĝar-re-eš-a-ba  ud-ba lu2-tur dan3-dan3-na-ka  mu 100 i3-ak  nam-buluĝ3-ĝa2-ni-ta mu 100 bi2-in-ak
en: After the flood had swept over and brought about the destruction of the countries; when mankind was made to endure, and the seed of mankind was preserved and the black-headed people all rose; when An and Enlil called the name of mankind and established rulership, but kingship and the crown of the city had not yet come out from heaven, and Ninĝirsu had not yet established for the multitude of well-guarded people the pickaxe, the spade, the earth basket and the plough, which mean life for the Land -- in those days, the carefree youth of man lasted for 100 years and, following his upbringing, he lasted for another 100 years.

akk: kiĝ2-gi4-a li-bi2-ib2-gi4-gi4  i3-tur i3-tur-tur i3-ĝal2 ama-a-ni  udu^?--a-ni tur3-re im-ma-an-/ri-ri\  ud-ba a lagaš^ki- du3 […]  ĝir2-su^ki- šag4-ĝar [i3-ĝal2-am3]  id2 nu-un-dun-[na-am3]  eg2 pa5-re šu-/luḫ\ nu-ak-[am3]  a-gar3 gal-gal-e X [(X)]-na nu-un-[X]  /gan2\-ne2 gana2 zid-/de3\ [a] /ḫe2\-ĝal2-la [nu-un-de2]  nam-lu2-ulu3 igi-bi /im\ šeĝ3-šeĝ3-[ĝa2 in-bar]  ^d-ezina2 še /gu\-nu nu-/ub-ta\-[an-mu2]  ab-sin2-na [ka-bi nu-un-du8]  gu2 nu-mu-/un\-[il2]  an-edin-na [nu-un-ur11-ru]  gu2 nu-mu-/un\-[il2]
en: However, he did not do any work. He became smaller and smaller, ……; his sheep died in the sheepfold. In those days, because the water of Lagaš was held back, there was famine in Ĝirsu. Canals were not dug, the levees and ditches were not cleaned. The large arable tracts were not ……, there was no water to irrigate abundantly all the cultivated fields: the people relied on rain; Ezina did not make dappled barley grow, furrows were not yet opened, they bore no yield; the high plain was not tilled, it bore no yield.

akk: kur-kur uĝ3 lu-a /diĝir\-[re-ne-er] (between lines 32 and 33 above the 2nd sign of line 33 there is a small sign written which is probably U2)   /&kaš;\ulušin /kurun\ […]  /kurun\ dug3 X X […]  [nu]-mu-/un\-[ne-eb2-bal-bal]  /a-šag4\ gal /^ĝiš-\[apin-ta]  [nu-mu]-/un-ne-eb^?-\-[ur11-ru]  /id2\ […]  a-šag4-/bi\ […]
en: None of the countries with numerous people libated emmer beer, liquor, ……, sweet liquor or …… for the gods. They did not till large fields for them with the plough. 10 lines missing …… the canal. …… its fields.

akk: id2 dun-/ne\-[de3]  eg2 pa5-re /šu^!-\-[luḫ ak-de3]  a-gar3 gal-gal-e X […]  gan2-ne2 gana2 zid-/de3\ […] im-[…]  ^ĝiš-al ^ĝiš-mar ^gi-[dusu ^ĝiš-apin-e]  zi-šag4-ĝal2 /kalam\-[ma]  uĝ3-še3 im-ta-an-[ĝar-re-eš]  /ud\-bi-a še ed3-/de3\-[da]  /ĝeštug2\-ga-a-ni na-/an\-[gub]  [ki]-/sikil\-še3 igi-ni-še3 ba-/ši\-in-gub-ba-/aš\  ud ĝi6-bi-ta /ki\-ulutim-/bi\-[še3]  saĝ-ba ba-/ši-in-il2\  ^d-ezina2 še-numun-bi mu-/mu2\-a  ki-a /bi2\-in-za-za-aš im-/mi-ni\-in-ed3-[de3-eš]  ^d-[ezina2] [še] gu-nu mu-[mu2]-/a\  […] KU^?- […]-eš
en: In order to dig canals, to clean the levees and ditches, to …… the large arable tracts, to …… all the cultivated fields, he established for the people the pickaxe, the spade, the earth basket, and the plough, which mean life for the Land. Then he turned his attention to making barley sprout. He made the people stand before the maiden, and they raised their heads day and night, at the appointed times. Before Ezina who makes the seeds grow, they prostrated themselves and she made them grow . Before Ezina who makes the dappled barley grow, they …… 33 lines missing or uncertain

akk: […]-/in-il2\  […] /DU\  mu [X i3-ak]  igi ḫuš X X […]  ^id2-PU3 /mu\-[un-dun]  mu 2760 i3-[ak]
en: …… acted for …… years. …… dug the canal ……, he acted for 2760 years.

akk: en-a2-ki-gal-la-[gub-ba]  diĝir-ra-ni ^d-X […]  ^id2-niĝin6^ki--ĝiš-tuku-am3 [mu-un-dun]  mu 1200 i3-/ak\  ud-ba /mu sar\ nu-me-a X […]  id2 nu-un-dun ^gi-dusu [nu-un-il2]  ud-bi-a a2 UR3 lugal […]  uĝ3 ĝiš tag-ga kug-sig17   ed3-de3-ra ḫuš-na ḫuš-a  ba-ni-in-ĝar  X tag-ga kabar zid-[de3]  kalam-še3 im-ta-an-e3  a suḫur ab-ba abrig UR3-ra  saĝ-eš2 mu-ni-rig7  en-^d-nin-ĝir2-su-ki-aĝ2  dumu en-a2-ki-gal-la-gub-ba  mu 1320 i3-ak  en-^d-en-lil2-le-ki-aĝ2  dumu en-^d-nin-ĝir2-su-ki-aĝ2  mu 1800 i3-/ak\  ur-^d-ba-u2 dumu en-^d-en-/lil2-le\-/ki-aĝ2\  mu 900 i3-ak
en: En-akigalaguba: his personal god was ……, he dug the canal Niĝin-ĝiš-tukuam, he acted for 1200 years. In those days there was no writing, ……, canals were not dug, earth baskets were not carried. In those days, ……, the people …… offerings of refined gold 2 lines uncertain a good shepherd rose over the Land; he gave them …… as a gift. En-Ninĝirsu-ki-aĝ, the son of En-akigalaguba: he acted for 1320 years. En-Enlile-ki-aĝ, the son of En-Ninĝirsu-ki-aĝ: he acted for 1800 years. Ur-Bau the son of En-Enlile-ki-aĝ: he acted for 900 years.

akk: a2-gal diĝir-ra-ni ^d-ig-alim  mu 660 i3-/ak\  KU-e dumu a2-gal-la-ke4  mu 1200 i3-/ak\  ama-alim /dumu\ /KU\-[e] […]  mu 600 /i3\-[ak]
en: A-gal: his personal god was Ig-alim, he acted for 660 years. Kue , the son of A-gal: he acted for 1200 years. Ama-alim, son of Kue : ……, he acted for 600 years.

akk: /da\-an-X […]  [mu X i3-ak]  X […]  /mu\ [X i3-ak]  A X […]  /mu\ [X i3-ak]  /GAN2^?-\ […]  /UN\ […]  ^id2-[… mu-un-dun]  mu [X i3-ak]
en: 12 lines unclear or missing

akk: /^id2-maḫ\ [^id2-…]  ^id2-piriĝ3-/gin7\-ĝen [^id2-…]  ^id2-piriĝ3 ka ^id2-/lugal^?-\-[ka]  ^id2-gana2-/ḫi\-li-an-na ^id2-/TE\-[X]  ^id2-^ d-nanše-pad3-da mu-un-[dun]  a-gar3 gal-gal 1(AŠ)-e ]  mu 2220 i3-ak  ur-^d-nanše /dumu\ X X-ma-ke4  /e2\-sirara6^!- e2 šag4 ḫul2-la-ni  niĝin6^ki- iri ki aĝ2-ĝa2-ni mu-du3-a  /mu\ 1080 i3-ak  an-ne2-tum2 dumu ur-^d-nanše-ke4  ki alim-/ma\-na diĝir-re-e-ne  mu-un-gub-ba saĝ-tun3^?- ^d-en-lil2 gal DE2  diĝir-ra-ni ^d-šul-utul10^?-  /mu\ 690 i3-ak  […] /NE\ dumu an-ne2-tum2  mu [X] + 360 i3-ak
en: 2 lines missing he dug the Maḫ canal, the …… canal, the Piriĝgin-ĝen canal, the …… canal, the Piriĝ canal at the mouth of the Lugal canal, the Gana-hili-ana canal, the …… canal, and the Nanše-pada canal. To care, single-handedly, for the great arable lands, he dug irrigation ditches and ……, he acted for 2220 years. Ur-Nanše, the son of ……, who built the E-Sirara, her temple of happiness and Niĝin, her beloved city, acted for 1080 years. Ane-tum, the son of Ur-Nanše, in whose …… place the gods stood, who …… the land register of great Enlil: his personal god was Šul-utul, he acted for 690 years. ……, the son of Ane-tum: he acted for X + 360 years.

akk: [en]-en3-tar-zid diĝir-ra-ni ^d-meš3-an-DU  /numun\ ud re-a iri-da mu2-a  mu 990 i3-ak  [X]-/en\-da-in-si dumu en-en3-tar-zid  [^id2-ur]-/maḫ\-ban3-da ^id2-tab-ta^?--ku3-ĝal2  [mu-un-dun] diĝir-a-ni ^d-meš3-an-DU  [lugal-a-ni] ^d-nin-ĝir2-su  [e2-a-ni du3-da] mu-un-na-dug4  /mu\ 960 i3-ak
en: En-entar-zid: his god was Meš-an-du , of the seed of ancient days, who had grown together with the city, he acted for 990 years. ……, the son of En-entar-zid: he dug the canal Urmaḫ-banda, and the canal Tabta-kug-ĝal, his personal god was Meš-an-du ; his master Ninĝirsu commanded him to build his temple; he acted for 960 years.
En-Enlile-su: he acted for 600 years. ……, the son of En-Enlile-su: his personal god was Ninazu; he acted for 660 years.
……: he acted for 1110 years.

akk: […]-/du8 mu\ 1110 i3-ak  [puzur4]-[^d-nin]-/lil2\ /mu\ [X šu]-ši + 1 i3-ak  [en-^d-meš3-an-DU dumu] /puzur4\-^d-/nin-lil2\-la2  [diĝir-ra-ni AN … mu] 2 šu-ši i3-ak  /da\-du /dumu\ en-^d-meš3-/an-DU\ /mu\ 160 <i3-ak>  tug2-gur dumu da-du mu 160 i3-/ak\
en: Puzur-Ninlil: he acted for X × 60 + 1 years. En-Meš-an-du , the son of Puzur-Ninlil: his personal god was ……, he acted for 120 years. Dadu, the son of En-Meš-an-du : he acted for 160 years. Tuggur, the son of Dadu: he acted for 160 years.
……: he acted for 120 years.

akk: LA X mu 120 i3-ak  puzur4-^d-ma-ma dub-sar [^d-]/nin-ki\  diĝir-ra-ni ^d-za-za-ru mu [X] i3-ak  lu2 bad3 ĝir2-/su\^ki- AŠ2^?--[a]-ni  /e2\-gal ti-ra-aš2 /ki\ lagaš^ki- mu-du3-a  /mu\ 280 i3-ak  [diĝir-ra-ni] ^d-pa4^?--bil-saĝ mu 140 <i3-ak>  […] dumu ḫe2-en-ĝal2 mu 144 <i3-ak>
en: Puzur-Mama, the scribe of Ninki: his personal god was Zazaru; he acted for …… years. Lamku-niĝgena , the administrator of Puzur-Mama, who built the wall of Ĝirsu, his ……, and the Tiraš palace in Lagaš: he acted for 280 years. Ḫenĝal, the son of Lamku-niĝgena : his god was Pabilsaĝ , he acted for 140 years. ……, the son of Ḫenĝal: he acted for 144 years.

akk: [ur]-^d-nin-mar-ki-ka dub-sar um-/mi\-a  [X X] KAL saĝ dur2-ra /diĝir-ra-ni\ ^d-ḫa-ia3 ^d-nisaba  [mu X] + 20 i3-ak  [ur]-[^d-]nin-ĝir2-su dumu ur-^d-/nin\-[mar-ki-ka] [mu X] /šu\-ši <i3-ak>  [ur]-[^d-]ba-u2 dub-sar ur-^d-[nin-ĝir2-su-ka] /X\  […] X unken-na [… mu X] + 30 <i3-ak>  gu3-de2^!--a šeš-ban3-da ur-^d-ba-u2-/ka\ […]  dumu ama-na dumu ad-da nu-me-a [mu X i3-ak]
en: Ur-Ninmarki, the scribe and scholar: ……, his personal gods were Ḫaya and Nisaba, he acted for X + 20 years. Ur-Ninĝirsu, the son of Ur-Ninmarki: he acted for X × 60 years. Ur-Bau, the scribe of Ur-Ninĝirsu, who …… in the assembly: he acted for X + 30 years. Gudea, the younger brother of Ur-Bau, ……, who was not the son of his mother nor the son of his father: he acted for …… years.
Written in the school. Nisaba be praised!

akk: en-me-barag-ge4-e-si lugal-e  iri-na-nam e2 ^d-en-lil2-la2 in-du3  ag-ga dumu en-me-barag-ge4-e-si-ke4  tum-ma-al^ki--e pa bi2-i-e3  ^d-nin-lil2 tum-ma-al^ki--še3 in-tum3  a-ra2 1-a-kam tum-ma-al^ki- ba-šub
en: En-me-barage-si, the king, built the Iri-nanam in Enlil's temple. Aga, son of En-me-barage-si, made the Tummal flourish and brought Ninlil into the Tummal. Then the Tummal fell into ruins for the first time.

akk: tum-ma-al^ki--e pa bi2-i-e3  ^d-nin-lil2 tum-ma-al^ki--še3 in-tum3  a-ra2 2-a-kam tum-ma-al^ki- ba-šub
en: Meš-Ane-pada built the Bur-šušua in Enlil's temple. Meš-ki-aĝ-nuna, son of Meš-Ane-pada, made the Tummal flourish and brought Ninlil into the Tummal. Then the Tummal fell into ruins for a second time.

akk: ^d-gilgameš3-e numun2-bur-ra barag ^d-en-lil2-la2 in-du3  ^m-ur-lugal dumu ^d-gilgameš3-ke4  tum-ma-al^ki--e pa bi2-i-e3  ^d-nin-lil2 tum-ma-al^ki--še3 in-tum3  a-ra2 3-a-kam tum-ma-al^ki- ba-šub
en: Gilgameš built the Numunbura in Enlil's shrine. Ur-lugal, son of Gilgameš, made the Tummal flourish and brought Ninlil into the Tummal. Then the Tummal fell into ruins for a third time.

akk: tum-ma-al^ki--e pa bi2-i-e3  ^d-nin-lil2 tum-ma-al^ki--še3 in-tum3  a-ra2 4-a-kam tum-ma-al^ki- ba-šub
en: Nanni built the Lofty Garden in Enlil's temple. Meš-ki-aĝ-Nanna, son of Nanni, made the Tummal flourish and brought Ninlil into the Tummal. Then the Tummal fell into ruins for a fourth time.

akk: tum-ma-al^ki--e pa bi2-i-e3  ^d-nin-lil2 tum-ma-al^ki--še3 in-tum3  a-ra2 5-a-kam tum-ma-al^ki- ba-šub
en: Ur-Namma, built the E-kur. Šulgi, son of Ur-Namma, made the Tummal flourish and brought Ninlil into the Tummal. Then the Tummal fell into ruins for a fifth time.

akk: mu ^d-amar-^d-suen-ka-ta  ^d-šu-^d-suen-ta  en-na mu ^d-i-bi2-^d-suen lugal-e  ^d-nin-lil2 tum-ma-al^ki--še3 i-ĝen-ĝen
en: From the years of {Amar-Suena} { Šu-Suen} until King Ibbi-Suen chose {En-am-gal-ana} { En-me-gal-ana} by extispicy as the high priest of Inana of Unug, Ninlil came regularly to the Tummal.
Written according to the words of Lu-Inana the chief leatherworker of Enlil.

akk: inim lu2-^d-inana ašgab gal ^d-en-lil2-la2-še3 sar-re  ^d-iš-bi-er3-ra e2-kur igi ĝal2-la2  ^e2-šutum ^d-en-lil2-la2 in-du3
en: Išbi-Erra, who looks after the E-kur, built the storehouse of Enlil.

akk: eš3 ma2-/gur8-gin7\ […]  gir4 maḫ-bi X […]  id2-bi a ḫul2-la da-[ri2 …]  a-gar3-bi ^ĝiš-al-e ri-e-de3 /gana2\ […]  e2 kiš^ki--a iri lil2-la-gin7 maš-gana2 gi4-[gi4-de3]  lugal-bi sipad ur-^d-za-ba4-/ba4\  e2 kiš^ki--a-ka ^d-utu-gin7 am3-e3  nam-lugal-la-na bal-bi šu kur2-ru-de3 e2-gal-/la\ LAM-bi su3-ra2-X-[(X)]  an ^d-en-lil2 inim kug-ga-ne-ne-a zid-de3-eš X [X X]
en: To …… the sanctuary like a cargo ship; to …… its great furnaces; to see that its canals …… waters of joy, to see that the hoes till the arable tracts and that …… the fields; to turn the house of Kiš, which was like a haunted town, into a living settlement again -- its king, shepherd Ur-Zababa, rose like Utu over the house of Kiš. An and Enlil, however, authoritatively decided by their holy command to alter his term of reigning and to remove the prosperity of the palace.

akk: ki ud-bi šar-ru-um-ki-in iri-ni /iri\ […]  ad-da-ni la-i-bu-um ama-/ni\ […]  šar-ru-um-ki-in šag4 dug3-ga mu-[…]  mu im-ta-tu-ud-da-aš X […]  ud ne ud te-en-e um-ma-te-a-ta  ^m-šar-ru-um-ki-in sa2-dug4 e2-gal-še3 im-de6-a-ba  itima kug ki-tuš kug-ga-ni-a im-ma-da-an-nu2  šag4-ga-ni-še3 mu-un-zu eme-na nu-ĝa2-ĝa2 lu2-da nu-mu-un-da-ab-be2  ^m-šar-ru-um-ki-in sa2-dug4 e2-gal-še3 šu ba-ab-te-a-ta  kug ^d-inana-ke4 da-bi-a   ud 5-am3 ud 10-am3 ba-zal-la-ta  lugal ^d-ur-^d-za-ba4-ba4 im-da-la2 ki-tuš-bi-ta mi-ni-ib-ḫu-luḫ  piriĝ-gin7 šag4 pap-ḫal-la-na kaš3 biz^!--biz šag4-ba uš2 lugud si-a-ba  i3-/kuš2\ ku6 a mun lug-ga-gin7   ^m-šar-ru-um-ki-in u3-sa2-gin7 la-ba-nu2 ma-mu2-de3 ba-nu2
en: Then Sargon -- his city was the city of ……, his father was La’ibum, his mother …… -- Sargon …… with happy heart. Since he was born ……. unknown no. of lines missing

One day, after the evening had arrived and Sargon had brought the regular deliveries to the palace, Ur-Zababa was sleeping in the holy bed-chamber, his holy residence. He realised what the dream was about, but did not put into words, did not discuss it with anyone. After Sargon had received the regular deliveries for the palace, Ur-Zababa appointed him cupbearer, putting him in charge of the drinks cupboard. Holy Inana did not cease to stand by him.

After five or 10 days had passed, King Ur-Zababa …… and became frightened in his residence. Like a lion he urinated, sprinkling his legs, and the urine contained blood and pus. He was troubled, he was disturbed like a fish living in brackish water.

akk: kug ^d-inana-ke4 ma-mu2 id2 mud-še3 mu-un-gir5-gir5  ^m-šar-ru-um-ki-in dum-dam-ma-na zu2 ki-/še3\ ba-da-ab-ra-/aḫ\  dum-dum-bi lugal ^d-ur-^d-za-ba4-ba4 ĝiš tuku-tuku-da-ni  lugal-ra ki kug-ga-ni-še3 im-ma-da-an-/sun5\-ne-eš  ^m-šar-ru-um-ki-in ki ^d-ur-^d-za-ba4-ba4-še3 im-ma-da-an-sun5-ne  ^m-šar-ru-um-ki-in lugal-a-ni im-ma-ni-ib-gi4-gi4  lugal-ĝu10 ma-mu2-ĝu10 u3-mu-ri-dug4-ga  ^lu2-ki-sikil 1-am3 an-gin7 sukud-da-ni ki-gin7 daĝal-la-ni  /suḫuš^?-\ bad3-da-gin7 ĝar-ĝar-ra  [id2] /maḫ id2 mud\-še3 ĝa2-ra mu-un-gir5-re-de3-en
en: It was then that the cupbearer of Ezina's wine-house, Sargon, lay down not to sleep, but lay down to dream. In the dream, holy Inana drowned Ur-Zababa in a river of blood. The sleeping Sargon groaned and gnawed the ground. When King Ur-Zababa heard about this groaning, he was brought into the king's holy presence, Sargon was brought into the presence of Ur-Zababa "Cupbearer, was a dream revealed to you in the night?" Sargon answered his king: "My king, this is my dream, which I will tell you about: There was a young woman who was as high as the heavens and as broad as the earth. She was firmly set as the base of a wall. For me, she drowned you in a great river, a river of blood."

akk: [(X)] X [^d-]/ur\-[^d-za]-/ba4\-ba4 nundum KA bi2-in-/gu7\ ni2 šag4-/še3\ ba-gid2  […] X NA /AN\ [X] sukkal-a-ni /gu3\ mu-na-de2-e  […] /nin9\ e-ĝu10 kug ^d-inana-ke4  […] X X mud-še3 u-ĝu10 mu-un-kur9-re  ^m-be-li2-iš-ti-kal2 gal:simug lu2 šag4-ga de6-a-ĝu10 im sar-sar  inim ga-ra-ab-dug4 /inim-ĝu10\ [ḫe2]-dab5  /na de5-ga\-ĝu10 /ĝizzal ḫe2-em-ši\-ak  e2-[sikil]-/la\ e2 nam tar-ra-ka alan-gin7 /kuš3-kuš3-a\ sig10-bi2-ib
en: Ur-Zababa chewed his lips, he became seriously afraid. He spoke to ……, his chancellor: "My royal sister, holy Inana, is going to change my finger into a …… of blood; she will drown Sargon, the cupbearer, in the great river. Beliš-tikal, chief smith, man of my choosing, who can write tablets, I will give you orders, let my orders be carried out! Let my advice be followed! Now then, when the cupbearer has delivered my bronze hand-mirror to you, in the E-sikil, the fated house, throw them into the mould like statues."

akk: ^m-be-li2-iš-ti-kal2 inim lugal-la-na-še3 saĝ keše2 ba-ši-in-ak  e2-sikil e2 nam tar-ra-ka kuš3-kuš3-a   lugal-e ^m-šar-ru-um-ki-in gu3 mu-na-de2-e  ĝen-na zabar-šu-ĝa2 gal:simug-še3 tum2-mu-na-ni-ib  ^m-šar-ru-um-ki-in e2-gal ^d-ur-^d-za-ba4-ba4 im-ma-da-ra-ab-e3 (inserted here from the edge)   kug ^d-inana-ke4 /zag zid-da\-ni   e2-sikil-la e2 nam tar-ra-ka 5 nindan 10 nindan nu-te-a-na  kug ^d-inana-ke4 igi mu-/un-na\-ni10-ni10 ĝiri3-ni im-da-RU  e2-sikil-la e2 kug-ga na-nam lu2 mud nu-mu-un-kur9-re  kan4 e2 nam tar-ra-ka gal:/simug^!-\ lugal-la-/ke4 gaba\ mu-un-da-ri  zabar-šu lugal-la-ke4 gal:simug-/še3\ mu-un-de6-a-ta  ^m-be-li2-iš-/ti\-kal2 gal:simug im-/da\-la2 alan-gin7 kuš3-kuš3-a ba^!--da-ab-sig10-ga-bi
en: Beliš-tikal heeded his king's words and prepared the moulds in the E-sikil, the fated house. The king spoke to Sargon: "Go and deliver my bronze hand-mirror to the chief smith!" Sargon left the palace of Ur-Zababa. Holy Inana, however, did not cease to stand at his right hand side, and before he had come within five or 10 nindan of the E-sikil, the fated house, holy Inana turned around toward him and blocked his way, "The E-sikil is a holy house! No one polluted with blood should enter it!" Thus he met the chief smith of the king only at the gate of the fated house. After he delivered the king's bronze hand-mirror to the chief smith, Beliš-tikal, the chief smith, …… and threw it into the mould like statues.

akk: ^m-šar-ru-um-ki-in ud 5-am3 ud 10-am3 ba-zal-la-ta  ki ^d-ur-^d-za-ba4-ba4 lugal-la-na-še3 im-ma-da-an-ku4-ku4  šag4 e2-gal kur gal-gin7 /ki us2\-sa im-/ma-da\-an-ku4-ku4  lugal ^d-ur-^d-za-ba4-ba4 im-da-la2 ki-tuš-/bi\-ta mi-ni-ib-ḫu-luḫ  šag4-ga-ni-še3 mu-un-zu eme-na nu-ĝa2-ĝa2 lu2-da nu-mu-un-da-ab-be2  itima-ka ki-tuš kug-ga-ni ^d-ur-^d-za-ba4-ba4 mi-ni-ib-ḫu-luḫ  šag4-ga-ni-še3 mu-un-zu eme-na nu-ĝa2-ĝa2 lu2-da nu-mu-un-da-ab-be2
en: After five or 10 days had passed, Sargon came into the presence of Ur-Zababa, his king; he came into the palace, firmly founded like a great mountain. King Ur-Zababa …… and became frightened in his residence. He realised what was it about, but did not put into words, did not discuss it with anyone. Ur-Zababa became frightened in the bed-chamber, his holy residence. He realised what was it about, but did not put into words, did not discuss it with anyone.

akk: ud-bi-ta <inim> im-ma /gub-bu ḫe2-ĝal2\ im /sig9-sig9-ge\ ba-ra-ĝal2-la-am3  lugal ^d-ur-^d-za-ba4-ba4 ^m-šar-ru-um-ki-in diĝir-re-e-ne šu dug4-ga-ar  im-ma gub-bu niĝ2 ni2 ba-ug7-a-ta  unug^ki--ga lugal-zag-ge4-e-si šu ba-ni-ib-da13-da13  dam^!- lugal-zag-ge4-si-/da\ /im\-[…]  nam-munus an-dul3-eš2 mu-ni-ba X […]  lugal-zag-ge4-si kiĝ2-gi4-a nu-[…]  ĝa2-nam-ma šeg12^!- e2-an-na-še3 ĝiri3 mu-un-/gub\  lugal-zag-ge4-si šag4-ga-ni nu-un-/zu\ ugu kiĝ2-gi4-a nu-mu-un-dug4-dug4  en-na ugu kiĝ2-gi4-a na-mu-un-dug4-dug4 igi dumu nun ba-an-da-bad  en-e u8 bi2-in-dug4 saḫar-ra ba-an-da-tuš  lugal-zag-ge4-si kiĝ2-gi4-a-ar im-ši-in-gi4  kiĝ2-gi4-a šar-ru-ki-in gu2 nu-mu-un-/sig10-sig10\  gam-gam-ma-ni šar-ru-ki-in /lugal-zag^?-\-[ge4-si …]  šar-ru-ki-in lugal-/zag\-[ge4-si] […]  a-na-aš-am3 /šar\-[ru-ki-in] […]
en: In those days, although writing words on tablets existed, putting tablets into envelopes did not yet exist. King Ur-Zababa despatched Sargon, the creature of the gods, to Lugal-zage-si in Unug with a message written on clay, which was about murdering Sargon. unknown no. of lines missing

With the wife of Lugal-zage-si ……. She …… her feminity as a shelter. Lugal-zage-si did not …… the envoy. "Come! He directed his steps to brick-built E-ana!" Lugal-zage-si did not grasp it, he did not talk to the envoy. But as soon as he did talk to the envoy ……. The lord said "Alas!" and sat in the dust.
Lugal-zage-si replied to the envoy: "Envoy, Sargon does not yield."After he has submitted,Sargon …… Lugal-zage-si ……. Sargon …… Lugal-zage-si ……. Why …… Sargon ……?

akk: kiš^ki- gud an-na-gin7 im-ug5-ga-ta  e2 ki unug^ki--ga gud maḫ-gin7 saḫar-ra mi-ni-ib-gaz-a-ta  ki ud-ba šar-ru-gen6 lugal a-ga-de3^ki--ra  sig-ta igi-nim-še3 ^d-en-lil2-le  nam-en nam-lugal-la mu-un-na-an-šum2-ma-ta  ud-ba eš3 a-ga-de3^ki- kug ^d-inana-ke4  ama5 maḫ-a-ni-še3 im-ma-an-du3-du3  ul-maš^ki--a ^ĝiš-gu-za ba-ni-in-gub
en: After Enlil's frown had slain Kiš as if it were the Bull of Heaven, had slaughtered the house of the land of Unug in the dust as if it were a mighty bull, and then Enlil had given the rulership and kingship from the south as far as the highlands to Sargon, king of Agade -- at that time, holy Inana established the sanctuary of Agade as her celebrated woman's domain; she set up her throne in Ulmaš.

akk: lu2-tur gibil-bi e2 du3-u3-gin7  dumu ban3-da ama5 ĝa2-ĝa2-gin7  e2 niĝ2-gur11-ra niĝ2 sa2 di-de3  iri^ki--bi dur2 ki ĝar šum2-mu-de3  uĝ3-bi u2 nir-ĝal2 gu7-u3-de3  uĝ3-bi a nir-ĝal2 na8-na8-de3  saĝ a tu5-a kisal ḫul2-le-de3  ki ezem-ma uĝ3 sig7-ge-de3  lu2 zu-u3-ne teš2-bi gu7-u3-de3  lu2 bar-ra mušen nu-zu-gin7 an-na ni10-ni10-de3  mar-ḫa-ši^ki- le-um-ma gur-ru-de3  ^ugu-ugu4-bi am-si maḫ ab2-za-za u2-ma-am ki ba9-ra2  šag4 sila daĝal-la-ke4 teš2-bi tag-tag-ge-de3  kug ^d-inana-ke4 u3 nu-um-ši-ku-ku
en: Like a young man building a house for the first time, like a girl establishing a woman's domain, holy Inana did not sleep as she ensured that the warehouses would be provisioned; that dwellings would be founded in the city; that its people would eat splendid food; that its people would drink splendid beverages; that those bathed for holidays would rejoice in the courtyards; that the people would throng the places of celebration; that acquaintances would dine together; that foreigners would cruise about like unusual birds in the sky; that even Marhaši would be re-entered on the tribute rolls; that monkeys, mighty elephants, water buffalo, exotic animals, as well as thoroughbred dogs, lions, {mountain ibexes} { mountain beasts } { horses}, and alum sheep with long wool would jostle each other in the public squares.

akk: ud-ba a-ga-de3^ki- e2 ziz2-a-ba kug-sig17 mi-ni-in-si  e2 ziz2 babbar-ra-ba kug-babbar mi-ni-in-si  araḫ4 še-ba urud nagga ^na4-lagab za-gin3-na sa2 im-mi-in-dug4-dug4  guru7-bi bar-ta im ba-an-ur3  um-ma-bi ad gi4-gi4 ba-an-šum2  ab-ba-bi ka-inim-ma ba-an-šum2  ĝuruš-bi a2 ^ĝiš-tukul-la ba-an-šum2  di4-di4-la2-bi šag4 ḫul2-la ba-an-šum2  ^ĝiš-al-ĝar-sur9-da   iri^ki- šag4-bi tigi-a bar-bi-ta gi-gid2 za-am-za-am-ma  kar ^ĝiš-ma2 us2-bi mud5-me-ĝar-ra  kur-kur u2-sal-la i-im-nu2  uĝ3-bi ki sag9-ga igi bi2-ib-du8
en: She then filled Agade's stores for emmer wheat with gold, she filled its stores for white emmer wheat with silver; she delivered copper, tin, and blocks of lapis lazuli to its granaries and sealed its silos from outside. She endowed its old women with the gift of giving counsel, she endowed its old men with the gift of eloquence. She endowed its young women with the gift of entertaining, she endowed its young men with martial might, she endowed its little ones with joy. The nursemaids {who cared for} { of} the general's children played the drumsticks. Inside the city tigi drums sounded; outside it, flutes and zamzam instruments. Its harbour where ships moored was full of joy. All foreign lands rested contentedly, and their people experienced happiness.

akk: lugal-bi sipad ^d-na-ra-am-^d-suen-e  barag kug a-ga-de3^ki--še3 ud-de3-eš2 im-e3  kug ^d-inana-ke4 ka-bi ĝal2 bi2-in-taka4  ki-en-gi-ra niĝ2-gur11 ni2-ba-ta ^ĝiš-ma2 im-da-gid2-de3  mar-tu kur-ra lu2 še nu-zu  gud du7 maš2 du7-da mu-un-na-da-an-ku4-ku4  me-luḫ-ḫa^ki- lu2 kur gig2-ga-ke4  elam^ki- su-bir4^ki- anše barag la2-gin7 niĝ2 mu-na-ab-la2-la2  saĝ-tun3 gu2-edin-na-ke4-ne  nidba itid-da zag-mu-bi   abula a-ga-de3^ki--ka a-gin7 kuš2 mi-ni-ib-ĝal2  nidba-bi kug ^d-inana-ke4 šu teĝ3-ĝe26 nu-zu
en: Its king, the shepherd Naram-Suen, rose as the daylight on the holy throne of Agade. Its city wall {, like a mountain,} { , a great mountain,} reached the heavens. It was like the Tigris {going to} { flowing into} the sea as holy Inana opened the portals of its city-gates and made Sumer bring its own possessions upstream by boats. The highland Martu, people ignorant of agriculture, brought spirited cattle and kids for her. The Meluḫans, the people of the black land, brought {exotic wares} { wares of foreign countries} up to her. Elam and Subir loaded themselves with goods for her as if they were packasses. All the governors, the {temple administrators} { generals}, and the accountants of the Gu-edina regularly supplied the monthly and New Year offerings. What a weariness all these caused at Agade's city gates! Holy Inana could hardly receive all these offerings. As if she were a citizen there, she could not restrain the desire to prepare the ground for a temple.

akk: inim e2-kur-ra me-gin7 ba-an-ĝar  a-ga-de3^ki- tuku4-e mu-un-na-la2-la2  ul-maš^ki--a ni2 im-ma-ni-in-te  iri^ki--ta dur2-ra-ni ba-ra-ĝen  ki-sikil ama5-na šub-bu-gin7  kug ^d-inana-ke4 eš3 a-ga-de3^ki- mu-un-šub  ur-saĝ ^ĝiš-tukul-a saĝ ĝa2-ĝa2-gin7  lu2-kur2-ra-ra gaba ba-ni-in-ri
en: But the statement coming from the E-kur was disquieting. Because of Enlil all Agade was reduced to trembling, and terror befell Inana in Ulmaš. She left the city, returning to her home. Holy Inana abandoned the sanctuary of Agade like someone abandoning the young women of her woman's domain. Like a warrior hurrying to arms, she {removed} { tore away} the gift of battle and fight from the city and handed them over to the enemy.

akk: ud nu-5-am3 ud nu-10-am3  sa nam-en-na aga nam-lugal-la  ma-an-si-um ^ĝiš-gu-za nam-lugal-la šum2-ma  ^d-nin-urta-ke4 e2-šu-me-ša4-na ba-ni-in-kur9  iri^ki- ka-inim-ma-bi ^d-utu ba-an-de6  ĝeštug2-bi ^d-en-ki-ke4 ba-an-de6  me-lem4 an-ne2 im-us2-sa-a-bi  ^ĝiš-dimgul kug im-du3-du3-a-bi  ^d-en-ki-ke4 abzu-a mi-ni-in-bu  ^ĝiš-tukul-bi ^d-inana-ke4 ba-an-de6
en: Not even five or 10 days had passed and Ninurta brought the jewels of rulership, the royal crown, the emblem and the royal throne bestowed on Agade, back into his E-šu-me-ša. Utu took away the eloquence of the city. Enki took away its wisdom. An took {up} { out} { away} into the midst of heaven its fearsomeness that reaches heaven. Enki tore out its well-anchored holy mooring pole from the abzu. Inana took away its weapons.

akk: eš3 a-ga-de3^ki- zi-bi suḫur^ku6- tur-ra-gin7 engur-ra ba-an-til  iri^ki- teš2-bi igi-bi am3-da-ĝal2  am-si maḫ-gin7 gu2 ki-še3 mi-ni-ib-ĝar  gud maḫ-gin7 si am3-da-il2-il2  ušumgal uš2-a-gin7 saĝ am3-ma-ze2-re  me3-gin7 nam-dugud-ba am3-da-ab-laḫ4-laḫ4-e
en: The life of Agade's sanctuary was brought to an end as if it had been only the life of a tiny carp in the deep waters, and all the cities were watching it. Like a mighty elephant, it bent its neck to the ground while they all raised their horns like mighty bulls. Like a dying dragon, it dragged its head on the earth and they jointly deprived it of honour as in a battle.

akk: nam-lugal a-ga-de3^ki- ki-tuš gen6-na dug3 nu-tuš-u3-de3  eĝer-bi niĝ2 na-me nu-sag9-ge-de3  ^d-na-ra-am-^d-suen maš2-ĝi6-ka igi ba-ni-in-du8-a  šag4-ga-ni-še3 mu-un-zu eme-na nu-um-ĝa2-ĝa2 lu2-da nu-mu-un-da-ab-be2  /e2 tuku4\ […]  e2-ni maš2 […]  nam e2-kur-ra-še3 tug2-mu-dur7-ra ba-an-mur10  ^d-na-ra-am-^d-suen mu 7-am3 mu-un-ge-en  lugal mu 7-am3 šu saĝ-ĝa2 dug4-ga a-ba igi im-mi-in-du8-a
en: Naram-Suen saw in a nocturnal vision that Enlil would not let the kingdom of Agade occupy a pleasant, lasting residence, that he would make its future altogether unfavourable, that he would make its temples shake and would {scatter its treasures} { destroy its treasuries}. He realised what the dream was about, but did not put into words, and did not discuss it with anyone. { …… temples shake ……, …… perform extispicy regarding his temple …….} Because of the E-kur, he put on mourning clothes, {covered his chariot with a reed mat} { pulled out the outside pin of his chariot}, tore the reed canopy off {his ceremonial barge} { the prow of his ceremonial barge} { the cabin of his ceremonial barge}, and gave away his royal paraphernalia. Naram-Suen persisted for seven years! Who has ever seen a king burying his head in his hands for seven years? { He realised what the dream was about, but did not put into words, and did not discuss it with anyone.}

akk: šag4-ga-ni-še3 mu-un-zu eme-na nu-ĝa2-ĝa2 lu2-da nu-mu-un-da-[ab-be2]  e2-še3 maš2-am3 ši-gid2-de3  e2 du3-a maš2-a nu-mu-un-de3-ĝal2  2-kam-ma-še3 e2-še3 maš2-am3 ši-gid2-de3  e2 du3-a maš2-a nu-mu-un-de3-ĝal2  i3-sig10-ga-na šu-a bal-e-de3  ^d-en-lil2 niĝ2-dug4-ga-ni ba-en-de3-kur2
en: Then he went to perform extispicy on a kid regarding the temple, but the omen had nothing to say about the building of the temple. For a second time he went to perform extispicy on a kid regarding the temple, but the omen again had nothing to say about the building of the temple. In order to change what had been inflicted upon him, he tried to to alter Enlil's pronouncement.
