akk: lugal ^ĝiš-al šid-da us2-a ud zal-la  ur-saĝ ^d-nin-urta ki-bal-a ^ĝiš-al-tar ba-an-gub  iri en-še3 nu-še-ga šu-še3 al-ĝa2-ĝa2  an-še3 ud-dam šeg11 al-gi4-gi4  ki-še3 ušumgal-am3 al-ĝa2-ĝa2  niĝ2 al-dug4-ga-ni mu-na-da-ab-šum2-mu  ^d-dumu-zid al-lum-lum-ma igi-nim-ma-ka  ^d-gibil6 ^ĝiš-al-a-ni saĝ an-še3 mi-ni-il2  ^ĝiš-al-e kug-ga-am3 izi nam-mi-in-la2  ^d-a-nun-na al-ḫul2-ḫul2-le-de3-eš
en: The king who measured up the hoe and who passes his time in its tracks, the hero Ninurta, has introduced working with the hoe into the rebel lands. He subdues any city that does not obey its lord. Towards heaven he roars like a storm, earthwards he strikes like a dragon . Šara {sat down on} { got onto} Enlil's knees, and Enlil gave him what he had desired : {he had mentioned the mace, the club, arrows and quiver, and the hoe } { he desired the mace, the club, arrows and quiver}. Dumuzid is the one who makes the upper land fertile . Gibil made his hoe raise its head towards the heavens -- he caused the hoe , sacred indeed, to be refined with fire. The Anuna were rejoicing .

akk: e2 ^d-ĝeštin-an-na-ka ^ĝiš-al-ĝar-surx(UZ3×BALAĜ)-ra-am3  ama ^d-ĝeštin-an-na-ka ^ĝiš-al-ĝar-surx(UZ3×BALAĜ) gu3 dug3-ga-ka  en-e ^ĝiš-al-a-ni gud-gin7 mur im-ša4  irigal-am3 ^ĝiš-al saĝ ki-a tum2-ma  šul idim an-na šeš-ban3-da ^d-nergal-ka-kam  ur-saĝ ^d-gilgameš2 ^ĝiš-al-e sa-par4-am3  ^ĝiš-al-e id2-da kindagal-am3  ḫul-ĝal2 ud nu2-a dumu ^ĝiš-al-me-eš  u4-sa2 dug4-ga-ta an-ta u3-tud-de3-eš
en: The temple of Ĝeštin-ana resembled the drumsticks, the drumsticks of Mother Ĝeštin-ana that make a pleasant sound. The lord bellowed at his hoe like a bull. As for the grave : the hoe buries people, but dead people are also brought up from the ground by the hoe . With the hoe , the hero honoured by An, the younger brother of Nergal, the warrior Gilgameš is as powerful as a hunting net. The { sage} son of Ninsumun is pre-eminent with oars . With the hoe he is the great barber of the watercourses. In the {chamber} { place} of the shrine, with the hoe he is the minister . The wicked …… are sons of the hoe ; they are born in sleep from heaven.

akk: an-še3 al-ti-ri2-gu7 mušen diĝir-ra-am3  ki-še3 ^ĝiš-al-am3 ĝiš-gi-a ur-ra tir-ra ušumgal-am3  ki me3-ka dur10-al-lub-am3  ki bad3-ka ^ĝiš-al-lu5-ḫab2-am3  ki ^ĝiš-banšur-ra ^ĝiš-ma-al-tum-ma  ki ^ĝiš-gigir-ka ^ĝiš-ma-a-a-al-tum-ma  e2 anše-ka ^ĝiš-ar-gibil2-am3  ^ĝiš-al-am3 mu-bi dug3-ga ḫur-saĝ-ĝa2 mu-un-ĝal2  ĝiš ḫur-saĝ-ĝa2 ^ĝiš-al-la-nu-um-ma  šim ḫur-saĝ-ĝa2 ^ĝiš-ar-ga-nu-um-ma  na4 ḫur-saĝ-ĝa2 ^na4-algameš-am3
en: In the sky there is the altirigu bird, the bird of the god. On the earth there is the hoe : a dog in the reedbeds, a dragon in the forest. On the battlefield, there is the dur-allub battle-axe. By the city wall there is the battle-net . On the dining-table there is the bowl . In the waggon shed, there is the sledge . In the donkey stable there is the cupboard . The hoe ! -- the sound of the word is sweet: it also occurs on the hillsides: the tree of the hillsides is the allanum oak. The fragrance of the hillsides is the arganum balm. The precious stone of the hillsides is the algameš steatite.

akk: ^ĝiš-al lum-lum-ma ^ĝiš-al lam-lam-ma  ^ĝiš-al u3-šub-ba ^ĝiš-al saĝ ĝal2-la-am3  ^ĝiš-al-am3 a2 nam-ĝuruš-a-kam  ^ĝiš-al ^ĝiš-dusu niĝ2 iri du3-du3-dam  e2 zid al-du3-e gana2 zid al-ĝa2-ĝa2  gan2-ne2 zid-de3 šu daĝal-la-me-en  gan2-ne2 lugal-bi-ir bal-e  gan2-ne2 lugal-bi-ir gu2 nu-ĝar-ra-e  ^ĝiš-al-e lugal-bi-ir gu2 mu-na-ab-ĝa2-ĝa2  ^u2-numun2 ḫul ^u2-numun2 ḫul-e saĝ dub2-dub2-be2  ur2-ba mu-un-bur12-re pa-bi mu-un-ze2-e  ^ĝiš-al-e ^u2-ḫirin^ḫu-ri2-in- šu-še3 al-ĝa2-ĝa2
en: The hoe makes everything prosper, the hoe makes everything flourish. The hoe is good barley, the hoe is {a hunting net} { an overseer}. The hoe is brick moulds, the hoe has made people exist . It is the hoe that is the strength of young manhood. The hoe and the basket are the tools for building cities. It builds the right kind of house, it cultivates the right kind of fields. It is you, hoe, that extend the good agricultural land! The hoe subdues for its owner any agricultural lands that have been recalcitrant against their owner , any agricultural lands that have not submitted to their owner . It chops the heads off the vile esparto grasses, yanks them out at their roots, and tears at their stalks. The hoe also subdues the ḫirin weeds.

akk: ^ĝiš-al-e ĝiš nam tar-ra a-a ^d-en-lil2-la2  ^ĝiš-al-e za3-mi2 dug4-ga  ^d-nisaba za3-mi2
en: The hoe , the implement whose destiny was fixed by Father Enlil -- the renowned hoe ! Nisaba be praised!

akk: [e-el-lu] /ma\-al-lu  gud ĝen-a ĝen-a ^ĝiš-/šudul\-[a] gu2 ĝar-i3  [gud … ĝen-a ĝen-a ^ĝiš-šudul]-a gu2 ĝar-i3  […] ma-da-me-en  […] ^d-en-lil2-la2-me-en  […] kalam-ma-me-en
en: ellu mallu! Go, oxen, go, put your necks under the yoke! Go, …… oxen, go, put your necks under the yoke! I am …… of the country. I am …… of Enlil. I am …… of the Land.

akk: [e-el-lu] ma-a^!--lu  […] /saĝ\ mu-da-ĝal2  [… saĝ] mu-da-ĝal2  X X […]  a2-še ama ḫu-/mu\-[da-…]  a2-še ^d-nanše ḫu-mu-da-an-/šub^?--bu^?-\  ninda ^kuš-lu-ub2 ḫa-ma-ni-in-ĝar-ra-am3  a ^kuš-ummud-da ḫa-ma-ni-in-de2-am3  saĝ /us2\ [… ḫa]-ma-da-an-gub-ba  engar ninda gu7-a ḫa-ma-an-dug4-ga-am3  engar a naĝ-a ḫa-ma-an-dug4-ga-am3
en: ellu mallu! 6 lines fragmentary or missing And now, may the mother …… with me; and now, may Nanše …… with me. May she put bread in my leather bag, may she pour water into my waterskin. May she stand by for me ……. May she say to me, "Farmer, eat the bread!", may she say to me, "Farmer, drink the water!"

akk: e-el-lu ma-a-lu  ^d-nanše e2 ma-mu-de3 ba-nu2  ^d-nanše-ra inim ĝi6 im-ma-na-ab-DU  ninda ^kuš-lu-ub2-a im-ma-ni-in-ĝar  a ^kuš-ummud-da im-ma-ni-in-de2  [saĝ us2 …-gub]  ^lu2-engar igi X [(X)] im-ma-ši-in-bar  gud-ab2 X [(X)] eme ba-an-ĝar  X […] /ĝiri3^?-\ bi2-in-la2  [^lu2-engar] /ama\-a-ni gu3 mu-na-de2-e  [ninda ^kuš-lu-ub2-a] ma-an-ĝar  [a ^kuš-ummud-da] ma-an-de2  [saĝ us2 … ma-an]-/gub^?-\
en: ellu mallu! In the temple he lay down to dream with Nanše. He said good night to Nanše. He had his leather bag filled with bread, he had water poured into his waterskin. She stood by for him ……. The farmer had a vision : a young bull was talking ……, …… tied the feet . The farmer said to his mother, "Bread was put for me in my leather bag, water was poured for me into my waterskin. …… stood by for me." 4 lines missing or fragmentary

akk: /e\-[el-lu ma-al-lu]  a-na-[am3 …]  a-na-/am3\ […]  a-ba-am3 […]  a-ba-am3 […]  a-ba-am3 /lag\ […]  a-ba-am3 /mušen\ […]  a2 zid-da […]  a2 gab2-/bu\ […]  igi il2-/la\ […]  umbin gal-/ĝu10\ […]  mul-an-na X […]  gala-bi […] /\ […]  [gud …] /saĝ^?-\-dili gur4 mu-un-/ta\-šub  […] /inim\ mu-na-ni-ib-gi4-/gi4\  gud-me-/en\ gud tur-me-en  siki giri17-/ĝu10\ nu-lum-ma-me-en  gu2-tar-/ĝa2\ saḫar nu-šub-ba-bi  a-na-aš-am3 lugal-ĝu10 ĝe26-e mu-un-/kal\-me-en  amar ban3-da-ĝu10 inim 1-am3 a-ra-ab-[be2]-en  ĝizzal ḫe2-em-ši-/ak\  ^ĝiš-KU ad-da-zu 4-/am3\  ^ĝiš-KU ama-zu 8-am3  ^d-utu ĝiš sag9-zu ]
en: ellu mallu! What ……? What ……? Who ……? Who ……? Who …… the clods? Who …… the birds? On the right ……, on the left ……. 1 line fragmentary "My big hooves ……." The stars in the sky ……. …… will make straight its ……. The ox …… let his thick tongue hang down, …… he replied, "I am an ox, but just a young ox, in whose muzzle hair has not yet grown. No dust has fallen yet on my shoulders. My master, why am I so valuable?" "My stalwart calf, I shall speak to you only once, so pay attention. What a plough ! Your fathers are four. What a plough ! Your mothers are eight. May Utu guide straight your fine plough!"

akk: e-el-lu ma-a-[lu]  engar šu-nim-ma sipad tur3 kug-[ga]  ĝuruš-e ud tur-ra-ni-ta dam an-/tuku\-[am3]  dumu an-tuku-am3 dili-ni^?- nu-mu-un-[…]
en: ellu mallu! The early-working farmer, the shepherd of the holy cattle-pen, the young man who, since his youth, has had a wife and has had sons, does not …… alone.

akk: e-el-lu [ma-a-lu]  mul-an-na ĝe26-[e …]  gun3 an-na ĝe26-/e\ […]  ^tug2-niĝ2-barag2 ur3-ra /ĝe26\-[e …]  [X X] /ĝe26-e\ […]  /^ĝiš-X\ […]
en: ellu mallu! I …… the stars in the sky, I …… a gleam in the sky. I …… the bedding on the roof. 22 lines fragmentary or missing

akk: e-el-[lu] /ma\-a-lu  ^d-en-/ki\-[im-du] [lu2] eg2 pa5-ra-ke4  en /^d-\[…] /gu3\ mu-na-de2-e  lugal-/ĝu10\ […] X ga-mu-ra-ab-ak-e  gana2 zid-[de3 … a] /ga\-ra-ab-dug4  im /saĝ\ […] im-ma-ab-be2  ud /še\ […] X gana2 NE  AN-/AN\ […] /mu-da\-an-X […] ma-ab-ak  X […] X NE
en: ellu mallu! Enkimdu, he of dykes and canals, says to the lord ……, "My king, I want to ……. I will irrigate your fertile fields ……. The early rain ……"11 lines fragmentary or missing

akk: e-el-lu ma-al-lu  ^ĝiš-gana2-ur3 ^ĝiš-ga-rig2 a-šag4-ĝa2  ^ĝiš-zu2 gal-gal ḫa-ra-ab-si gana2 kug ri-ri-de3  ^ĝiš-al gu2 ki ḫe2-re-la2 mud sa2-bi2-ib  ^ĝiš-al gu2 ki ḫe2-re-la2  ^ĝiš-apin kug-zu ^ĝiš-dal-a la2-a-ba ^ĝiš-dal-ta um-ta-si-ig  nagar gal-zu gu ḫu-mu-ra-ab-tag-ge  /a2\ ^ĝiš-le-um-ma-bi […]  […] mu7-mu7 […]  [… šu] /zid\-da-na gi-1-nindan ḫe2-[…]  […] [^d-]/en\-ki-im-du lu2 eg2 /pa4\-[ra-ke4]  […]-a-ka ḫu-mu-ra-[…]
en: ellu mallu! The harrow, the comb of my field, must be fitted with large teeth to harrow the holy field. The mattock must dig the edges. Remove the stumps! The mattock must dig the edges. Once you have taken down from the beam your holy plough which was hanging from a beam, a skilled carpenter must tighten its bonds. …… its side boards. 12 lines missing or fragmentary …… noises. …… the measuring reed in his right hand. Enkimdu, he of dykes and canals ……, should …… for you in …….

akk: [e-el-lu] ma-al-lu gud ĝen-a ĝen-[a ^ĝiš-šudul-a gu2 ĝar-i3]  [gud …] ĝen-a ĝen-a ^ĝiš-šudul-a gu2 [ĝar-i3]  [ab-sin2 gana2] zid-da ĝiri3 gub-gub-i3 us2 [ ḫe2-e-dib]  […] e2 kaš-a-ka ul ti-a […]  […] ^d-inana-ka ki-bur2-/re\ […]  […] ki-bi i3-/gi4\-[gi4 …]
en: ellu mallu! Go, oxen, go, put your necks under the yoke! Go, …… oxen, go, put your necks under the yoke! Tread the furrows of the fertile field, walk the sides straight. In the alehouse, the joy ……, …… Inana …… a place of relaxation. …… is restored again …….
149. An ululumama song of Ninurta.

akk: ^gi-gakkul-e ^gi-gakkul-e  ^gi-gakkul-e ^dug-lam-sa2-ri  ^gi-gakkul-e niĝ2 ur5 sag9-sag9-ge  ^dug-lam-sa2-ri niĝ2 šag4 ḫul2-ḫul2-e  ^dug-u-gur-bal niĝ2 e2-a me-te-bi  ^dug-šag4-gub-be2 niĝ2 kaš sig9-sig9-ge  ^gi-buniĝ(SUG) ^u2-bur2 ^gi-ba-an-du8 silaĝ-ĝa2-ke4  dug sag9 dag-dug-e sa gi4-a
en: The gakkul vat, the gakkul vat! The gakkul vat, the lamsare vat! The gakkul vat, which puts us in a happy mood! The lamsare vat, which makes the heart rejoice! The ugurbal jar, glory of the house! The šaggub jar, filled with beer! The amam jar, which carries the beer from the lamsare vat! The troughs made with bur grass and the pails for kneading the dough! All the beautiful vessels are ready on their pot stands!

akk: šag4 diĝir-za ḫu-mu-ra-ab-ḫuĝ-e  igi ^gi-gakkul-am3 igi-me na-nam  šag4 ^gi-gakkul-am3 šag4-me na-nam   aĝ2  šag4-zu gur4-gur4-ru ni2-bi-a  šag4-me-a gur4-gur4-ru ni2-bi-a  ur5-me bi2-sag9 šag4-me bi2-ḫul2  šeg12 nam tar-ra a de2-zu  silim-ma ḫe2-ĝal2-e ki us2-sa-zu  ^d-nin-ka-si za-da ḫu-mu-u8-da-an-til3  kaš ĝeštin ḫu-mu-ra-an-bal-bal-e  kurun2 lal3-e gu3 nun ḫa-ra-ni-ib-be2
en: May the heart of your god be well disposed towards you! Let the eye of the gakkul vat be our eye, and let the heart of the gakkul vat be our heart! What makes your heart feel wonderful in itself also makes our hearts feel wonderful in themselves! We are in a happy mood, our hearts are joyful! You have poured a libation over the fated brick, and you have laid the foundations in peace and prosperity -- now may Ninkasi dwell with you! She should pour beer and wine for you! Let the pouring of the sweet liquor resound pleasantly for you!

akk: ^gi-buniĝ(SUG) ^u2-bur2-a kaš ku7-ku7-dam  sagi lu2-tur-ra lunga3 bi2-in-gub-en  a-niĝin2-e niĝin-na-ĝu10-ne  gur4-gur4-re-ĝa2 gur4-gur4-re-ĝa2-ĝu10-ne  kaš naĝ-e  me-e  sig10-ga-ĝu10-ne  kurun2 naĝ-a ul ti-a-ĝu10-ne  šag4 ḫul2-la ur5 sag9-ga-ĝu10-ne  šag4-ĝa2 šag4 ḫul2-la ĝal2-la-bi  ur5 sag9 ^tug2-pala3-a ša-mur10-ra-ĝu10-ne  šag4 ^d-inana ki-bi ba-ab-gi4  šag4  ga-ša-an-an-na-ke4  ki-bi ba-ab-gi4
en: In the troughs made with bur grass, there is sweet beer. I will have the cupbearers, the boys and the brewers stand by. As I spin around the lake of beer, while feeling wonderful, feeling wonderful, while drinking beer, in a blissful mood, while drinking alcohol and feeling exhilarated, with joy in the heart and a contented liver -- my heart is a heart filled with joy! I clothe my contented liver in a garment fit for a queen! The heart of Inana is happy once again; the heart of Inana is happy once again!
32. A …… to Ninkasi.

akk: /ĝi6\ re-a ĝi6 ba9-ra2 re-a  [mu] re-a mu su3-ra2 re-a  ud-ba ĝeštug2 tuku inim galam inim zu-a kalam-ma til3-la-a  šuruppag^ki- ĝeštug2 tuku inim galam inim zu-a kalam-ma til3-la-a  šuruppag^ki--e dumu-ni-ra na na-mu-un-de5-de5  šuruppag^ki- dumu ubara-tu-tu-ke4  zi-ud-su3-ra2 dumu-ni-ra na na-mu-un-de5-de5  dumu-ĝu10 na ga-de5 na de5-ĝu10 ḫe2-dab5  zi-ud-su3-ra2 inim ga-ra-ab-/dug4\ ĝizzal ḫe2-em-ši-ak  na de5-ga-ĝu10 šu nam-bi2-bar-re  inim dug4-ga-ĝu10 na-ab-ta-bal-e-de3  na de5 ab-ba niĝ2 kal-la-am3 gu2-zu ḫe2-em-ši-ĝal2
en: In those days, in those far remote days, in those nights, in those faraway nights, in those years, in those far remote years, at that time the wise one who knew how to speak in elaborate words lived in the Land; Šuruppag, the wise one, who knew how to speak with elaborate words lived in the Land. Šuruppag gave instructions to his son; Šuruppag, the son of Ubara-Tutu, gave instructions to his son Zi-ud-sura: My son, let me give you instructions: you should pay attention! Zi-ud-sura, let me speak a word to you: you should pay attention! Do not neglect my instructions! Do not transgress the words I speak! The instructions of an old man are precious; you should comply with them!
You should not buy a donkey which brays; it will split your midriff .

akk: dur3^ur3- gu3 di na-ab-sa10-sa10 murub4-zu ša-ra-ab-si-il  gana2 kaskal-[la] nam-bi2-ib2-ĝa2-ĝa2 nam-silig gu2-ĝa2-am3  gana2-zu-am3 pu2 na-an-ni-du3-e-en uĝ3-e ša-ri-ib-ḫul-ḫul  e2 sila daĝal nam-bi2-ib-la2-e keše2-da ĝal2-la-am3
en: You should not locate a field on a road; ……. You should not plough a field at { a road or} a path; ……. You should not make a well in your field: people will cause damage on it for you. You should not place your house next to a public square: there is always a crowd there.
You should not vouch for someone: that man will have a hold on you; and you yourself, you should not let somebody vouch for you { : that man will despise you}.
You should not make an inspection on a man: the flood will give it back to you.

akk: lu2-ra igi du8 na-an-ak-e uru2-bi ša-ri-/ib\-su-su  ki du14-da-ka nam-bi2-du-X-de3  du14-de3 lu2-ki-inim-ma nam-ba-e-ku4-ku4  du14-de3 ni2-zu nam-/ba\-[…]  du14 /nam-ak\-de3-en X […]  [X (X)] kan4 e2-gal-la X-am3 ba-ra-sig9-/ga\  du14-de3 bar-bar-ta gub-gub-[ba] in-nu-uš sila kur2-ra /nam-ma\-ni-ib-<du>
en: You should not loiter about where there is a quarrel; you should not let the quarrel make you a witness. You should not let yourself …… in a quarrel. You should not cause a quarrel; ……. …… the gate of the palace ……. Stand aside from a quarrel, …… you should not take another road.

akk: niĝ2 nam-mu-zuḫ-/zuḫ\ ni2-zu nam-mu-BAD-e  e2 na-a-an-ni-buru3-e-en mi-si-IŠ-ra   ni2-zu /piriĝ na-nam\ ul-dab5 saĝ na-nam  dumu-ĝu10  ni2-zu tun3-am3 nam-bi2-ib-bar-/re\-e
en: You should not steal anything; you should not …… yourself. You should not break into a house; you should not wish for the money chest . A thief is a lion, but after he has been caught, he will be a slave. My son, you should not commit robbery; you should not cut yourself with an axe.

akk: nitaḫ niĝir-si na-an-ak ni2-zu na-an-X-X  ki-sikil dam tuku-/da\  inim sig-ga /maḫ\-[am3]  dumu-[ĝu10] dagan-na lu2 dam /tuku-da\ dur2 nam-/bi2\-e-ĝa2-ĝa2
en: You should not make a young man best man. You should not …… yourself. You should not play around with a married young woman: the slander could be serious. My son, you should not sit alone in a chamber with a married woman.

akk: du14 nam-[mu2]-/mu2\-de3 ni2-zu na-an-[pe]-el-la2  lul /nam\-guru5-guru5 saĝ gu2 /sal-sal\-la  ka nam-tar-tar-re-/e\-en inim-zu ĝar-ra-am3  /ad^?-\ nam-gi4-gi4 igi dugud nu-mu-un-da-il2
en: You should not pick a quarrel; you should not disgrace yourself. You should not …… lies; ……. You should not boast; then your words will be trusted. You should not deliberate for too long ; you cannot bear …… glances.

akk: šu-zu uš2-am3 na-di-ni-ib-su-su  ĝiri3 ḫur-re gud ša-ba-ri-ib-su-su udu ša-ba-ri-ib-su-su
en: You should not eat stolen food with {anyone} { a thief}. You should not sink your hand into blood. After you have apportioned the bones, you will be made to restore the ox, you will be made to restore the sheep.
You should not speak improperly; later it will lay a trap for you.

akk: u2 nu-kiĝ2-ĝa2-še3 udu-zu /sag2\ nam-me  uš nu-sig10-ga-še3 gud lu2 na-ḫuĝ-e  uš sig10-ga kaskal sig10-ga-am3
en: You should not scatter your sheep into unknown pastures. You should not hire someone's ox for an uncertain ……. A safe …… means a safe journey.
You should not travel during the night: it can hide both good and evil.

akk: kaskal ĝi6 na-an-du šag4-bi sag9 ḫul-a
en: You should not buy an onager: it lasts only until the end of the day.
You should not have sex with your slave girl: she will chew you up .

akk: geme2-zu-ur2 ĝiš3 na-an-du3 zu ur2 šu-/mu\-ri-in-sa4
en: You should not curse strongly: it rebounds on you.

akk: aš2 a2 zig3 na-ab-bal-e šu-uš /im\-ši-ni10-ni10  maḫ-bi niĝ2 gid2-i (X) ba-an-šub-be2 niĝ2-e /ba^?-\-[an]-šub-be2
en: You should not draw up water which you cannot {reach} { grasp}: it will make you weak. 1 line unclear
You should not drive away a debtor: he will be hostile towards you.

akk: ur5 tuku na-an-bad-e lu2-bi ša-ba-e-X-X-kur2  sun7-na-da e2 na-an-da-ĝa2-ĝa2-/an\   gi4-in-še3  du-de3 ši-me-ši-ib-šub-šub  ši-du-un ši-du-un ši-me-ši-ib2-be2-e-ne
en: You should not establish a home with an arrogant man: he will make your life like that of a slave girl. You will not be able to travel through any human dwelling without be being shouted at: "There you go! There you go!"

akk: gi-sig-ga ^ĝiš-kiri6-ka da-ga nam-bi2-du8-e-en  sug6-ga-ab sug6-ga-ab ši-me-ši-ib2-be2-ne
en: You should not undo the …… of the garden's reed fence; "Restore it! Restore it!" they will say to you.
You should not provide a stranger with food; you should not wipe out a quarrel.

akk: ur nam-mu-un-gu7-en du14 nam-ur3-ur3-re-en  dumu-ĝu10 nam-silig nam-mu-ak-en lu2 ki nam-us2-e-en  dumu lu2-ra ĝiš3 a2 zig3 na-an-ne-en kisal-e bi2-zu-zu
en: My son, you should not use violence ; ……. You should not commit rape on someone's daughter; the courtyard will learn of it.
You should not drive away a {powerful} { strong} man; you should not destroy the outer wall. You should not drive away a young man; you should not make him turn against the city.
The eyes of the slanderer always move around as shiftily as a spindle. You should never remain in his presence; his intentions should not be allowed to have an effect on you.
You should not boast in {beer halls} { breweries} like a deceitful man: { then your words will be trusted.}

akk: ki nam-nitaḫ-ka um-me-te šu na-an-gud-gud-de3  ur-saĝ dili na-nam dili-ni lu2 šar2-ra-am3  ^d-utu dili na-nam dili-ni lu2 šar2-ra-am3  ur-saĝ-da gub-bu-/de3\ zi-zu ḫe2-en-da-ĝal2  ^d-utu-da /gub\-bu-de3 zi-zu /ḫe2-en\-da-ĝal2
en: Having reached the field of manhood, you should not jump with your hand. The warrior is unique, he alone is the equal of many; Utu is unique, he alone is the equal of many. With your life you should always be on the side of the warrior; with your life you should always be on the side of Utu.

akk: šuruppag^ki--e dumu-ni-ra na še3-mu-un-ni-in-de5  šuruppag^ki- dumu ubara-tu-tu-[ke4]  zi-ud-su3-ra2 dumu-ni-ra na še3-mu-un-ni-in-de5
en: Šuruppag gave these instructions to his son. Šuruppag, the son of Ubara-Tutu, gave these instructions to his son Zi-ud-sura.

akk: 2-kam-ma-še3 šuruppag^ki--e dumu-ni-ra na na-mu-un-de5-de5  /šuruppag\^ki- dumu ubara-tu-tu-ke4  zi-ud-su3-ra2 dumu-ni-ra na na-mu-[un-de5-de5]  dumu-ĝu10 na /ga\-de5 na de5-ĝu10 ḫe2-/dab5\  zi-ud-su3-ra2 inim [ga]-/ra\-ab-dug4 /ĝizzal\ ḫe2-em-ši-ak  na de5-ga-ĝu10 šu [nam]-bi2-bar-re-en  inim dug4-ga-ĝa2 [na]-/ab-ta\-bal-e-/de3\-en
en: A second time, Šuruppag gave instructions to his son. Šuruppag, the son of Ubara-Tutu, gave instructions to his son Zi-ud-sura: My son, let me give you instructions: you should pay attention! Zi-ud-sura, let me speak a word to you: you should pay attention! Do not neglect my instructions! Do not transgress the words I speak! { The instructions of an old man are precious; you should comply with them!}

akk: na de5 ab-/ba\ [niĝ2 kal-la-am3 gu2-zu ḫe2-em-ši-ĝal2]  ka kaš naĝ-a […] X-kam  lu2-tur-ĝu10 […] lu2 X […]  ka kaš /naĝ\-[a …] X  ^d-nin-ka-/si\ […]  […] /KA\ X UR3 /ḫe2\-[X] IM  […]-ur3-ur3-re  […] X a mu-/un\-ni-ib2-[il2]-il2  […] X im-sar-re  KA X saĝ im-ta-ab-gur4-gur4-re
en: The beer-drinking mouth ……. My little one ……. The beer-drinking mouth ……. Ninkasi ……. 5 lines unclear

akk: lu2 ni2-za-ke4 nu-e-ši-su-su  ĝiš-gi maš2 u2 na-nam šag4-bi inim sig-ga-am3
en: Your own man will not repay it for you. The reedbeds are ……, they can hide slander.

akk: e2-gal id2 maḫ-am3 šag4-bi gud du7-du7-dam  niĝ2 ku4-ku4 niĝ2 sa2 nu-di-dam  niĝ2 e3 niĝ2 nu-silig-ge-dam
en: The palace is like a mighty river: its middle is goring bulls; what flows in is never enough to fill it, and what flows out can never be stopped.

akk: ninda lu2-ka ga-ra-ab-šum2-bi ku-nu-a  šum2-mu-da-bi an ba9-ra2-am3  ga-ra-ab-šum2-bi lu2-ra ga-ni-in-us2  nu-ra-ab-šum2-mu ninda igi-bi-še3 til-la-am3
en: When it is about someone else's bread, it is easy to say "I will give it to you", but the time of actual giving can be as far away as the sky. If you go after the man who said "I will give it to you", he will say "I cannot give it to you -- the bread has just been finished up."

akk: niĝ2-u2-rum niĝ2 a2 sig10-ga-a-da  lu2-tur-ĝu10 niĝ2 nu-mu-un-da-sa2
en: Property is something to be expanded ; but nothing can equal my little ones.

akk: ka sag9-sag9-ge inim i3-šid-e  ka du3-du3-e kišib i3-il2-il2  ka lal3-e u2-lal3 e-bur12-re
en: The artistic mouth recites words; the harsh mouth brings litigation documents; the sweet mouth gathers sweet herbs.

akk: gal-gal di ^kuš-lu-ub2 sug4-ga ša-mu-un-de6  silim dug4 ka sug4-ga ša-ba-ni-ib-ĝar
en: The {garrulous} { liar} fills his bread bag; the haughty one brings an empty bag and can fill his empty mouth only with boasting.
Who works with leather will eventually work with his own leather.
The strong one can escape from anyone's hand.

akk: usu-tuku šu lu2-ta ša-ba-ra-an-tum3  ^lu2-lil-e niĝ2   /u3^?-\-sa2 ^lu2-lil-e niĝ2   na-an-keše2-keše2-re-de3 giri17 šu am3-mi-in-ĝal2  ga-til3-la giri17 šu am3-mi-in-ĝal2
en: The fool loses something. When sleeping, the fool loses something. "Do not tie me up!" he pleads; "Let me live!" he pleads.

akk: saĝ-du nu-tuku nam ši-ib-tar-re  teš2 nu-tuku lu2 ur2-še3 mu-un-de2-e  ĝe26-e na-nam u6-e ba-gub
en: The imprudent decrees fates; the shameless one piles up things in another's lap: "I am such that I deserve admiration."
A weak wife is always seized by fate.

akk: dam /dim3\-e /nam^?-\ tar-re ba-dab5-dab5  lu2 ḫuĝ-ĝa2-zu [^kuš-]lu-ub2 ši-me-da-ba-e  ^kuš-lu-ub2 ši-ma-da-gu7-e  ^kuš-lu-ub2 /ši\-[me]-/da\-til-e    ga-ba-ra-gu7 e2-gal-la ba-gub
en: If you hire a worker, he will share the bread bag with you; he eats with you from the same bag, and finishes up the bag with you. Then he will quit working with you and, saying "I have to live on something", he will serve at the palace.

akk: dumu-nitaḫ-zu e2-zu-še3 im-me  dumu-munus-zu ama5-ni-še3 im-me
en: You tell your son to come to your home; you tell your daughter to go to her women's quarters.
You should not pass judgment when you drink beer.
You should not worry unduly about what leaves the house.

akk: e2-ta e3 šag4-zu na-an-gu7-e  an su3-ud-dam ki kal-kal-la-am3  an-da niĝ2 im-da-lu-lu-un  kur-kur-re zi ši-im-da-pa-an-pa
en: Heaven is far, earth is most precious, but it is with heaven that you multiply your goods, and all foreign lands breathe under it.

akk: ud buru14-še3 ud kal-kal-la-še3  geme2-gin7 de5-ga-ab egir2-gin7 gu7-a  dumu-ĝu10 geme2-gin7 ri egir2-gin7 gu7-a ur5 ḫe2-en-na-nam-ma-am3
en: At harvest time, at the most priceless time, collect like a slave girl, eat like a queen; my son, to collect like a slave girl, to eat like a queen, this is how it should be.

akk: aš2 dug4-dug4-ge bar ši-in-dar  igi-tum3 la2 saĝ ĝiš im-ra-ra  gu3 mur-re lu2-lul-e tug2 ši-bir7-bir7-e  aš2 di niĝ2-erim2-e na de5 še3-il2-il2  inim dirig u3-bu-bu-ul-la-am3 u2 lipiš gig-ga-am3  MU dar-dar-da ga-mu-e-da-zalag-ge  inim šudu3-de3-ĝu10 ḫe2-ĝal2-la-am3  a-ra-zu a sedx(KAD3)-da šag4-ge im-sedx(KAD3)-e  aš2 di^?- na-ĝa2-aḫ di-da ĝizzal kalam-ma-ke4
en: Who insults can hurt only the skin; greedy eyes , however, can kill. The liar, shouting, tears up his garments. Insults bring advice to the wicked. To speak arrogantly is like an abscess: a herb that makes the stomach sick. 1 line unclear My words of prayer bring abundance. Prayer is cool water that cools the heart. Only insults and stupid speaking receive the attention of the Land.

akk: šuruppag^ki--e dumu-ni-ra na še3-mu-ni-in-de5  šuruppag^ki- dumu ubara-tu-tu-ke4  zi-ud-su3-ra2 dumu-ni-ra na še-mu-ni-in-de5
en: Šuruppag gave these instructions to his son. Šuruppag, the son of Ubara-Tutu, gave these instructions to his son Zi-ud-sura.

akk: 3-kam-ma-še3 šuruppag^ki- dumu-ni-ra na na-mu-un-de5-[de5]  [šuruppag^ki- dumu] [ubara]-tu-tu-ke4  [zi-ud-su3]-ra na še3-mu-ni-in-de5  dumu-ĝu10 na ga-de5 na de5-ĝu10 ḫe2-dab5  zi-ud-su3-ra2 inim ga-ra-ab-dug4 ĝizzal ḫe2-em-ši-ak  na de5-ga-ĝu10 nam-bi2-bar-re  inim dug4-ga-ĝu10 na-ab-ta-bal-e-de3
en: A third time, Šuruppag gave instructions to his son. Šuruppag, the son of Ubara-Tutu, gave instructions to his son Zi-ud-sura: My son, let me give you instructions: you should pay attention! Zi-ud-sura, let me speak a word to you: you should pay attention! Do not neglect my instructions! Do not transgress the words I speak! { The instructions of an old man are precious; you should comply with them!}

akk: na de5 ab-ba niĝ2 kal-la-am3 /gu2\-zu ḫe2-em-ši-ak
en: You should not beat a farmer's son: he has constructed your embankments and ditches.

akk: dumu engar-ra-ra niĝ2 nam-mu-ra-ra-an eg2 pa5-zu še3-em-ra  [kar]-/ke4\ na-an-sa10-sa10-an ka u4-sar-ra-kam  ama-a-tud na-an-sa10-sa10-an u2 lipiš gig-ga-am3  dumu-gir15 na-an-sa10-sa10-an zag e2-ĝar8-e us2-sa-am3  saĝ kur-ra kur-bi-ta um-ta-a-ed3  lu2 ki nu-zu-a-ni-ta u3-mu-e-de6  dumu-ĝu10 ki ^d-utu e3-a-aš  a ḫu-mu-ra-an-de2-e igi-zu-še3 ḫe2-du  e2 nu-tuku e2-a-ni-še3 la-ba-du  iri nu-tuku iri-ni-še3 la-ba-du  ^ĝiš-ig X [… šu] /la^?-\-ba-an-da-us2-sa  X [X X]-/še3\ la-ba-an-da-ku4-ku4  la-ba-e-da-ḫi-li-e la-ba-e-da-sun7-e
en: You should not buy a prostitute: she is a mouth that bites. You should not buy a house-born slave: he is a herb that makes the stomach sick. You should not buy a free man: he will always lean against the wall. You should not buy a palace slave girl: she will always be the bottom of the barrel . You should rather bring down a foreign slave from the mountains, or you should bring somebody from a place where he is an alien; my son, then he will pour water for you where the sun rises and he will walk before you. He does not belong to any family, so he does not want to go to his family; he does not belong to any city, so he does not want to go to his city. { He cannot knock at the door of ……, he cannot enter …….} He will not …… with you, he will not be presumptuous with you.

akk: dumu-ĝu10 ki ^d-utu e3-a-aš  dili-zu-ne kaskal na-an-ni-du-un  lu2 zu-a-zu saĝ šu UD ba-/ra\-ak-ke4
en: My son, you should not travel alone eastwards. Your acquaintance should not …….

akk: mu mu-a sig10-ga saĝ-du lu2-u3-ra im-ma^?--X-e  kur-ra kur na-an-na-dub-be2
en: A name placed on another one ……; you should not pile up a mountain on another one.

akk: nam-tar peš10 dur5-ra-am3  lu2-da ĝiri3-ni im-ma-da-an-ze2-er
en: Fate is a wet bank; it can make one slip.

akk: šeš-gal a-a na-nam nin9 gal ama na-nam  šeš-gal-zu-ur2 ĝizzal ḫe2-em-ši^!--ak  nin9 gal ama-zu-gin7 gu2 ḫe2-em-ši-ĝal2
en: The elder brother is indeed like a father; the elder sister is indeed like a mother. Listen therefore to your elder brother, and you should be obedient to your elder sister as if she were your mother.

akk: za-e igi-zu-ta kiĝ2 na-an-ak-[e]  ka-zu-ta niĝ2-nam nu-lu-lu-un
en: You should not work using only your eyes; you will not multiply your possessions using only your mouth.
The negligent one ruins his family.

akk: e2 dur2-bi-še3 mu-un-ĝen  ninda-e lu2 kur-ra bi2-in-ed3-de3  lu2-lul lu2 bar-ra bi2-in-tum2-mu  ninda-e lu2 kur-ta im-ma-da-ra-an-ed3-de3
en: The need for food makes some people ascend the mountains; it also brings traitors and foreigners, since the need for food brings down other people from the mountains.

akk: uru2  tur-re lugal-bi-ir amar ši-in-ga-an-u3-tud   uru2  maḫ-e e2 du3-a ši-ḫur-re
en: A small city provides its king with a calf; a huge city digs a house plot .

akk: […] X-ke4 a2 šu im-du7-du7  lu2 niĝ2-tuku lu2 niĝ2 nu-tuku gig še3-em-ĝar  lu2 dam tuku a2 šu im-du7-du7  dam nu-un-tuku še-er-tab-ba mu-un-nu2  e2 gul-gul-lu-de3 e2 ša-ba-da-an-gul-e  lu2 zi-zi-i-de3 lu2 ša-ba-da-an-zi-zi-i
en: …… is well equipped. The poor man inflicts all kinds of illnesses on the rich man. The married man is well equipped; the unmarried makes his bed in a haystack . He who wishes to destroy a house will go ahead and destroy the house; he who wishes to raise up will go ahead and raise up.

akk: gud maḫ-a gu2-bi lu2 a-ba-an-dab5  lu2 id2-/da\ ba-ra-an-bal-e  lu2 gu-la iri-za-ka zag-ba u3-ba-e-zal-ta  dumu-ĝu10 za-a ur5-re ḫe2-em-me-re-a-ed3-de3
en: By grasping the neck of a huge ox, you can cross the river. By moving along at the side of the mighty men of your city, my son, you will certainly ascend .

akk: geme2-/zu\ ḫur^?--saĝ-ta ši-im-ta-an-tum3 sag9 ši-im-ta-an-de6  ḫul ši-in-ga-am3-ta-an-tum3  sag9-ga šu-am3 ḫul šag4 an-ga-am3  sag9-ga šag4-ge šu nu-bar-re  ḫul šag4-ge šu nu-di-ni-bar-re  sag9-ga ki dur5-ru-am3 šag4-ge nu-da13-da13  ḫul e2 niĝ2-gur11-ra ur5-e la-ba-an-gu7-e  mu-un-sag9 mu-[un]-/sag9\  ka-ni mu-[un]-/tag\-[tag]  ḫul-da id2-da ma2^?- ḫe2-en-da-su  an-edin-na ^kuš-ummud ḫe2-en-da-dar
en: When you bring a slave girl from the hills, she brings both good and evil with her. The good is in the hands; the evil is in the heart. The heart does not let go of the good; but the heart cannot let go of the evil either. As if it were a watery place, the heart does not abandon the good. Evil is a storeroom ……. { 2 lines unclear} May the boat with the evil sink in the river! May his waterskin split in the desert!

akk: šag4 ki aĝ2 niĝ2 e2 du3-du3-u3-dam  šag4 ḫul gig niĝ2 e2 gul-gul-lu-dam
en: A loving heart maintains a family; a hateful heart destroys a family.

akk: nir-ĝal2-e niĝ2-tuku gaba-ĝal2 me nam-nun-na  nir-ĝal2-ra gu2 ḫe2-en-ne-ni-ĝal2  a2-tuku ni2-zu ḫe2-en-ne-ši-la2  dumu-ĝu10 lu2 ḫul-ĝal2-ra ḫe2-en-ne-ši-ĝal2-le
en: To have authority, to have possessions and to be steadfast are princely divine powers. You should submit to the respected; you should be humble before the powerful. My son, you will then survive against the wicked.

akk: ezem-ma-ka dam na-an-tuku-tuku-e  šag4-ga ḫuĝ-ĝa2-am3 bar-ra ḫuĝ-ĝa2-am3  tug2^?- ḫuĝ-ĝa2-am3 gada^?- ḫuĝ-ĝa2-am3  [… nu]-mu-un-da-sa2
en: You should not choose a wife during a festival. Her inside is illusory ; her outside is illusory . {The silver on her is borrowed; the lapis lazuli on her is borrowed} { ……; the jewellery on her is borrowed, the jewellery on her is borrowed}. The dress on her is borrowed; the linen garment on her is borrowed. With …… nothing is comparable.

akk: gud [… na]-/an\-ni-sa10-sa10  gud /lul-la\ na-/sa10\-sa10 ^e2-tur3 buru3 X X […]
en: You should not buy a …… bull. You should not buy a vicious bull; …… a hole in the cattle-pen …….
One appoints a reliable woman for a good household.

akk: munus zid e2 zid-še3 lu2 ši-/in\-[ĝar]  ud buru14-ka anše na-an-sa10-sa10  anše LA gu7 anše-da im-[…]
en: You should not buy a donkey at the time of harvest. A donkey which eats …… will …… with another donkey.

akk: anše lul-la gu2-tar im-la2  dumu-ĝu10 lu2-lul-e zag-si mu-un-sag9-sag9
en: A vicious donkey hangs its neck; however, a vicious man, my son, …….
A woman with her own property ruins the house.
A drunkard will drown the harvest.

akk: kurun naĝ-naĝ-e buru14 im-su-su-su  ^f-šu-KU6 ^ĝiš-kun5 lu2 2(MIN)-e da nu-DI  e2-a nim-gin7 mi-ni-ib-dal-dal-en  eme3 sila-a inim i3-šid-e  munus giri17 ḫur ak šeg11 gi4-gi4-dam  ^ĝiš-bal ḫur-ra šu-na na-mu-un-ĝal2  e2-e2-a i-in-ku4-ku4-ku4  e-sir2-e-sir2-ra gu2 mu-un-gi-gi-de3  da ur3-ra im-me im-me e3-ab  bad3-si-bad3-si-a igi mu-ši-X-il2-il2^?--e  ki du14-de3 ĝal2-la-še3 zi im-X-pa^?--/pa\-[an]-e^?-  ki MU X /šub\-ba a2-za [X X] X IM [X]
en: A female burglar …… ladder; she flies into the houses like a fly. A she-donkey …… on the street. A sow suckles its child on the street. A woman who pricked herself begins to cry and holds the spindle which pricked her in her hand. She enters every house; she peers into all streets. …… she keeps saying "Get out!" She looks around from all parapets. She pants where there is a quarrel. 2 lines unclear

akk: /dumu-ĝu10\ [(…)] gum2-gamx(LUM) mi-ni-ib-za  […] X X […] tum3  […] nu2  […] DU  šag4 ḫul2-la i-im-dirig-/ge\ […]
en: Marry …… whose heart hates . My son, …… 4 lines unclear A heart which overflows with joy …….

akk: niĝ2-nam nu-kal zi ku7-ku7-da  niĝ2 nam-kal-kal-en niĝ2-e me-kal-kal  dumu-ĝu10 gun3-gun3-gin7 igi gun3-gun3
en: Nothing at all is to be valued, but life should be sweet. You should not serve things; things should serve you. My son, …….
You should not …… grain; its …… are numerous.

akk: ^d-ezina2-ra na-an-keše2-keše2-re-de3-en ^ĝiš-a2-bi i3-šar2  kir11-e aš2 nam-en dumu-munus in-u3-tud-un  ^ĝiš-mi-si-IŠ-a lag nam-bi2-šub-be2-en dumu-nitaḫ in-u3-tud-un
en: You should not abuse a ewe; otherwise you will give birth to a daughter. You should not throw a lump of earth into the money chest ; otherwise you will give birth to a son.

akk: dam nam-mu-un-kar-re-en gu3 KA na-an-ĝa2-ĝa2  ki dam kar-re nam-silig gum-ĝa2-am3
en: You should not abduct a wife; you should not make her cry . The place where the wife is abducted to …….

akk: a ĝiri3 a gu2 niĝin2-na ga-am3-me-re7-de3-en  lu2 gu-la a2 1(DIŠ)-e ga-na-gam-me-en-de3
en: "Let us run in circles , saying: "Oh my foot, oh my neck!". Let us with united forces make the mighty bow!"

akk: galam-ma na-an-ug5-ge-en dumu in-sug4-ge tud-da  en-ra BAD-a-gin7 ^d-nanna-ug5-ge-en šu na-an-du3-du3-en
en: You should not kill a ……, he is a child born by ……. You should not kill …… like ……; you should not bind him.
The wet-nurses in the women's quarters determine the fate of their lord.

akk: ama-zu-ur2 inim dirig nam-ba-na-ab-be2-en ḫul ša-ba-ra-gig-ga-am3  inim ama-za inim diĝir-za ka-še3 nam-bi2-ib-dib2-be2-en  ama ^d-utu-/am3\ lu2 mu-un-u3-tud  ab-ba diĝir-ra-/am3\ [(X)] mu-un-dadag-ge  ab-ba diĝir-am3 /inim\-ma-ni zid-da  na de5 ab-ba-še3 ĝizzal ḫe2-em-ši-ia-ak
en: You should not speak arrogantly to your mother; that causes hatred for you. You should not question the words of your mother and your personal god. The mother, like Utu, gives birth to the man; the father, like a god, makes him bright . The father is like a god: his words are reliable. The instructions of the father should be complied with.
Without suburbs a city has no centre either.

akk: e2 iri bar-ra-ke4 iri šag4-ga ši-du3-du3-e  dumu-ĝu10 gana2 eg2 dur2-bi-še3 ĝal2-la  al-duru5 šukur2-ra-am3 al-ḫad2 šukur2-ra-am3
en: My son, a field situated at the bottom of the embankments, be it wet or dry, is nevertheless a source of income.
It is inconceivable that something is lost forever.
…… of Dilmun …….

akk: ^urud-^ ?-giĝ4 dilmun^ki--na sam2-še3 TE-ga  ur nu-zu ḫul-am3 lu2 nu-/zu\ [ḫuš-am3]  ki nu-/zu\ ḫuš-am3 ur nu-zu teš2-am3  kaskal nu-zu gaba kur-ra-ka  diĝir kur-ra lu2 gu7-gu7-u3-me-eš  e2 lu2-gin7 nu-du3 iri lu2-gin7 nu-du3  ki-zu-a lu2-ka lu2 ša-ba-ra-an-ed2-de3  sipad-/ra\ kiĝ2-kiĝ2 mu-na-til udu gi4-gi4 [mu-na-til]
en: {To get lost is bad for a dog; but terrible for a man} { An unknown place is terrible; to get lost is shameful for a dog}. On the unfamiliar way at the edge of the mountains, the gods of the mountains are man-eaters. They do not build houses there as men do; they do not build cities there as men do. 1 line unclear

akk: /engar\-ra a-šag4 ur11-ru mu-na-til  […] X gi4 mu-/na\-KU-/en^?-\
en: For the shepherd, he stopped searching, he stopped bringing back the sheep. For the farmer , he stopped ploughing the field. 1 line unclear

akk: […] LA […] u2 de5-/ge\ […]  kadra inim-ma-bi niĝ2 šag4 ten-na /mu^?-\-[…]  e2-/gal\-[la] /kur9\-ra-bi niĝ2 šag4 ten-na […]  /kadra\ inim-inim-ma /mul\ […]
en: This gift of words is something which soothes the mind ……; when it enters the palace, it soothes the mind ……. The gift of many words …… stars.
These are the instructions given by Šuruppag, the son of Ubara-Tutu.

akk: na de5 šuruppag^ki- dumu ubara-tu-tu-ke4 na de5-ga  šuruppag^ki- dumu ubara-tu-tu-ke4 na de5-ga  nin dub gal-gal-la šu du7-a  ki-sikil ^d-nisaba za3-mi2
en: Praise be to the lady who completed the great tablets, the maiden Nisaba, that Šuruppag, the son of Ubara-Tutu, gave his instructions!
Ud-ul-uru gave advice to his son:

akk: a-šag4 dib-be2-da-zu-ne  eg2 pa5 du6 du8-u3-de3 igi kar2-kar2-ab  a-šag4 a de2-a-zu-ne a-bi šag4-ba nu-il2  ud a-ta im-mu-e-a-ed3-de3-a  a-šag4 ki duru5-bi en-nu-uĝ3 ak-ab ki-še-er a-ra-ab-tuku  gud suḫub2 ĝiri3 na-ra-ab-zukum-e
en: When you have to prepare a field, inspect the levees, canals and mounds that have to be opened. When you let the flood water into the field, this water should not rise too high in it. At the time that the field emerges from the water, watch its area with standing water; it should be fenced. Do not let cattle herds trample there.

akk: u2-saga11-bi u3-bi2-ze2 a-šag4 ki-ĝar u3-bi2-dug4  10-am3 ^urud-giĝ4 sal 2/3 ma-na-ta sa2-a-ab  ^ĝiš-al-šub-be2 umbin gud^?- ḫa-ra-šu2-šu2 sa ḫa-ra-ab-la2-la2  ki ka sal-la-bi u2-tag ḫa-ra-tag-tag  gu2 a-šag4-ga ub-da 4-ba ^ĝiš-al-e ḫa-ra-ni10-ni10  en-na a-šag4-ga al-šeĝ6-šeĝ6-e-da teš2 a-ra-ab-sig10-ge5-a
en: After you cut back the plant bundles and establish the limits of the field, level it repeatedly with a thin hoe weighing two-thirds of a mina approx. 650 g. Let a flat hoe erase the oxen tracks, let the field be swept clean. A maul should flatten the furrow bottoms of the area. A hoe should go round the four edges of the field. Until the field is dry it should be smoothed out.

akk: ^ĝiš-šu-kar2-zu sa ḫa-ra-ab-gi4-a  ^ĝiš-šudul-zu a2-šita4-a-bi ḫa-ra-keše2  ^kuš-usan3 gibil-zu ^ĝiš-gag-a ḫa-ra-ab-la2  ^kuš-usan3 sumun-zu ^ĝiš-mud la2-la2-a-bi  dumu gašam-ta dug3 ḫa-ra-ab-ak-e  ^urud-giĝ4 ^urud-bulug ^urud-šum-me ^ĝiš-šu-kar2-zu a2-zu   ^kuš-saĝ-keše2 ^kuš-bar-ed3-de3 ^kuš-ka-du3 ^kuš-usan3 saĝ-zu ḫe2-ḫa-za  ^gi-ba-an-du8-zu kab2 /di\ ḫu-mu-ra-ab-ak a2 kalag-ga ḫu-mu-ra-an-ak-e  a2-aš2 a-šag4-ga-zu da ḫe2-en-ĝal2 kiĝ2-zu igi kar2-ka-ab
en: Your implements should be ready. The parts of your yoke should be assembled. Your new whip should hang from a nail -- the bindings of the handle of your old whip should be repaired by artisans. The adze, drill and saw, your tools and your strength, should be in good order. Let braided thongs, straps, leather wrappings and whips be attached securely. Let your sowing basket be checked, and its sides made strong. What you need for the field should be at hand. Inspect your work carefully.

akk: gud-^ĝiš-apin gud dirig-ga a-ab-tuku-a  gud gud-da dur bi2-ib-tu-lu-a  ^ĝiš-apin-bi ^ĝiš-apin-na a-ab-dirig  /eš2-gar3\ ^ĝiš-apin 1-e 180 iku-am3  za-e 144 iku ĝiš du3-ba-ab  /a2^?-\ šag4 ḫul2-gin7 a-ra-ab-dim2-e  18 iku-ba 3 še gur ba-an-ĝa2-ĝa2
en: The plough oxen will have back-up oxen. The attachments of ox to ox should be loose. Each plough will have a back-up plough. The assigned task for one plough is 180 iku approx. 65 ha, but if you build the implement at 144 iku approx. 52 ha, the work will be pleasantly performed for you. 180 sila of grain approx. 180 litres; expressed in the cuneiform as 3 of an unwritten measure comprising 60 sila, gur indicating that the preceding signs specify a capacity will be spent on each 18 iku area approx. 6 1/2 ha.

akk: usu ^ĝiš-apin 1(DIŠ)-e a-šag4 ^ĝiš-bar-dili-bi u3-bi2-ak  ^ĝiš-bar-dili-bi ^ĝiš-apin-tug2-saga11 u3-bi2-ak tug2-gur-ra-ab  ĝiš ur3-ra-ab ĝiš gi4-a-ab ĝiš peš-bi2-ib  ki sumur-bi ^ĝiš-niĝ2-gul-ta ^ĝiš-gag-dag2-aš u3-bi2-ak  ^ĝiš-mud ^ĝiš-niĝ2-gul-zu saĝ-za ḫe2-ḫa-za niĝ2  na-du-un
en: After working one plough's area with a bardili plough, and after working the bardili plough's area with a tugsaga plough, till it with the tuggur plough. Harrow once, twice, three times. When you flatten the stubborn spots with a heavy maul, the handle of your maul should be securely attached, otherwise it will not perform as needed.

akk: kiĝ2 ak-zu-a   kiĝ2 ak-zu-še3   a-šag4 kiĝ2-zu ak na-an-na-ab-be2  ud mul-an-na šu im-ma-ab-du7-a-ta  10-am3 a2 gud a-šag4 zi-zi-i-da-še3 igi-zu nam-ba-e-gid2-i  ^ĝiš-al du3-a-bi ḫa-ra-ab-ak-e
en: When your field work becomes excessive, you should not neglect your work; no one should have to tell anyone else: "Do your field work!". When the constellations in the sky are right, do not be reluctant to take the oxen force to the field many times. The hoe should work everything.

akk: a-šag4 ur11-ru-da-zu-ne  ^ĝiš-apin-zu gu ḫa-ra-ab-dub2  ^ĝiš-ka-šu2 ^ĝiš-apin-na-zu ^kuš-im-du5-mu šub-i3  ^ĝiš-dam-zu ^ĝiš-gag sal-la šub-i3  ^ĝiš-le-um-zu a2 ḫe2-tal2-tal2 ab-sin2-zu gub-ba^?--ab
en: When you have to work the field with the seeder-plough, your plough should be properly adjusted. Put a leather sealing on the kašu of your plough. Provide your beam with narrow pegs. Your boards should be spread. Make your furrows.

akk: 1 nindan us2 ab-sin2 8 gub-ba-ab  ab-sin2 durun-dur2-ru-na še-bi gu2 a-ab-gid2  a-šag4 ur11-ru-da-zu-ne  lu2 še-numun ĝar-ra-zu igi-zu ĝar-i3  2 šu-si-ta-am3 ^d-ezina2 ḫe2-en-šub  1 nindan us2-ta 1 giĝ4 še ḫa-ra-ĝar  tukum-bi še-numun a-tur-ra nu-ub-suḫur  ^ĝiš-niĝ2-kud ^ĝiš-eme-^ĝiš-apin-na-zu kur2-ra-ab  tukum-bi dur a-ab-tu-lu dur tur-ra-ab
en: Make eight furrows per nindan 6 m of width; the barley will lodge in more closely spaced furrows. When you have to work the field with the seeder-plough, keep your eye on your man who drops the seed. The grain should fall two fingers deep. You should put one giĝ of seed per nindan approx. 3 ml per m. If the barley seed is not being inserted in the hollow of the furrow, change the wedge of your plough share. If the bindings become loose, tighten them.

akk: ki ab-sin2  i3-ur11-ru-a ab-sin2 ^ĝiš-šibir ur11-ru-ab  ki ab-sin2 ^ĝiš-šibir i3-ur11-ru-a^?- ab-sin2^?-  ur11-ru-ab  ab-sin2  gu2 tu-lu gu2 TAG mu-ra-ĝa2-ĝa2  ab-sin2 lug-gu2-zu   ab-sin2 ab-ki-iz-bi DU-a gana2 ku5-ra2-zu ur11-ru-ab  lag-bi ḫa-ra-ri-ri  ki-saḫar us2-bi ab-sin2 ḫa-ra-ni-ib-ra  ki-saḫar ka tab-bi ab-sin2 ḫa-ra-sig-sig  ḫenbur2-še3 a-ra-sag9
en: Where you have made vertical furrows, make slanted furrows, and where you have made slanted furrows, make vertical furrows. Straight furrows will give you edges that are wide enough and nice . Your crooked furrows should be straightened out. Make the furrows clear. Plough your portion of field. The clods should be picked out. The furrows should be made wide where the soil is open, and the furrows should be narrower where the soil is clogged: it is good for the seedlings.

akk: ud ḫenbur2-e ki im-ma-ab-dar-ra-ta  sizkur2 ^d-nin-kilim-ke4 dug4-ga-ab  zu2 bir5^mušen--ra bal-e-eb  ud še ka sal-la ab-sin2-na-ka a-ab-dirig  a numun saĝ-ĝa2-ke4 dug4-ga-ab  ud še ^gi-kid-ma2-šag4-ga-ba ab-gub-ba a dug4-ga-ab  še lillan-ba a dug4-ga-ab  ud še luḫ-ḫa an-sud-a a na-ab-be2-en sa-ma-na2-aš ba-gig  ud še bir ak-de3 a-ab-du7-a a dug4-ga-ab  ^ĝiš-ba-an-ba 1 sila3 še ku-dun ba-tuku-tuku
en: After the seedlings break open the ground, perform the rites against mice. Turn away the teeth of the locusts. When the plants overflow the narrow bottoms of the furrows, water them with the water of the first seed. When the plants resemble a …… reed mat, water them. Water the plants when they are heading. When the plants are fully leafed out, do not water them or they will become infected by leaf rust. When the barley is right for husking, water it. It will provide a yield increase of one sila per ban approx. 1 litre in 10.

akk: še gur10-gur10-ru-da-zu-ne še ur5 nam-ba-gam-e-en  ud a2-ba-ka gur10-gur10-ra-ab  u3 lu2 1-e igi-ni-še3 zar ḫu-mu-ra-ab-sa2-e  3-am3 ḫu-mu-ra-ab-gur10-gur10-re  lu2 še de5-de5-ga-zu še šu ḫuz na-an-ak-e  še-garadin3-e še na-an-si-il-si-il-le-e-ne
en: When you have to reap the barley, do not let the plants become overripe. Harvest at the right time. One man is to cut the barley, and one to tie the sheaves; and one before him should apportion the sheaves: three men should harvest for you. The people who gather the barley should not let the grain dry. They should not scatter the grain when it is in the stacks.

akk: kiĝ2 ud-da-zu ud tur-ra-gin7  usu di4-di4-la2-zu-ne u3 lu2 še de5-de5-ga-zu-ne  šid-bi du6-ul-la-ab zar-re-eš2 nu2-a-ab^?-  kiĝ2-zu mi2 zid ḫa-ra-ab-dug4  dabin še sumun-e tuku-a-ta  ka-gu7-zu-še3 lu2 še ĝiš na-ab-ra-ra-an  še-zar-ra ne-ḫa-ab  sizkur2 še-zar-ra ud šu2-uš-e ḫa-ra-ab-dug4  ud še al-ed3-de3-en-na-zu-ne  lu2 še la2-la2-zu-ne 30 giĝ4 ḫa-ra-an-ak-ak
en: Your daily work starts at daybreak. Gather your force of helpers and grain gatherers in sufficient number and lay down the sheaves. Your work should be carefully done. Although they have been having stale coarse flour, do not let anyone thresh for your new bread -- let the sheaves have a rest. The rites for the sheaves should be performed daily. When you transport your barley, your barley carriers should handle small amounts .

akk: kislaḫ-zu ki-ĝar dug4-ga-ab  ḫar-ra-an gur-zu   ^ĝiš-mar-gid2-da-zu   gud ^ĝiš-mar-gid2-da-zu mur gu7-bi2-ib  ^ĝiš-šu-kar2-zu ḫa-ra-[X X]
en: Mark the limits of a vacant lot of yours. Establish properly your access paths to it. Your waggons should be in working order. Feed the waggon's oxen. Your implements should be …….

akk: sur12 du8-a-zu ud 5-am3 ḫa-ba-ne-ḫa  sur12 ba9-ra2-zu-ne niĝ2-ur5-ra du8-i3  ud še ba9-ra2-zu-ne  zu2 ĝiš-ba9-ra2-zu kuš la2-la2-bi esir2 ḫa-ra-ab-sub6-sub6  gud dur2-dur2-ru-da-zu-ne  lu2 še ba9-ra2-zu usu^?- ḫe2-en-de3-gub^?-  ud še ki ba-e-ni-us2-sa  sizkur2 še nu-nir-ra dug4-ga-ab
en: Let your prepared threshing floor rest for a few days. When you open the threshing floor, smooth its surface . When you thresh, the teeth of your threshing sledge and its leather straps should be secured with bitumen. When you make the oxen trample the grain, your threshers should be strong. When your grain is spread on the ground, perform the rites of the grain not yet clean.

akk: ud še al-la2-e-na-zu  lu2 še ki-ta al-gub-bu-a lu2 ĝeštug2-ga gub-ba-ab  lu2 še DU-a 2-am3 ḫa-ra-gub-bu-uš
en: When you winnow, put an intelligent person as your second winnower. Two people should work at moving the grain around.

akk: ud še ba-e-nir-ra ĝidru-še3 nu2-a-ab  sizkur2 a2 ud te-en ĝi6-ba dug4-ga-ab  ud MAŠ-a-gin7 še bur2-ra-ab
en: When the grain is clean, lay it under the measuring stick. Perform the rites in the evening and at night. Release the grain at midday.

akk: na de5-ga ^d-nin-urta dumu ^d-en-lil2-la2-ke4  ^d-nin-urta engar zid ^d-en-lil2-la2 za3-mi2-zu dug3-ga-am3
en: Instructions of the god Ninurta, the son of Enlil -- Ninurta, faithful farmer of Enlil, your praise be good!

akk: gu5^?--li-li 3-am3 dumu adab^ki--ke4-ne  di in-da-ab-tuku-uš-am3 di-da ab-kiĝ2-kiĝ2-e  inim ib2-ta-an-šar2-šar2-eš-am3 lugal-e an-ta ba-an-gi
en: There were three friends, citizens of Adab, who fell into a dispute with each other, and sought justice. They deliberated the matter with many words, and went before the king.

akk: lugal-me gud-da ri i3-ak-e-de3-nam  gud lu2 1(DIŠ)-a-kam ab2 lu2 1(DIŠ)-a-kam ^ĝiš-mar lu2 1(DIŠ)-a-kam  enmen2 bi2-tuku-un-da-nam a nu-mu-e-da-ĝal2  lu2 gud-da-ra a u3-um-te-si a ga-naĝ-en-de3-en-e-še  gud-ĝu10 ur^!--maḫ-e u3-bi2-gu7 gud-ĝu10-ta ba-ra-ed2-de3-en-e-še  lu2 ab2-ba-ra a u3-um-te-si a ga-naĝ-en-de3-en-e-še  ab2-ĝu10 edin-še3 u3-ba-ĝen ab2-ĝu10-ta ba-ra-ed2-de3-en-e-še  lu2 ^ĝiš-mar-ra-ra a u3-um-te-si a ga-naĝ-en-de3-en-e-še  ^ĝiš-mar-ĝu10 gu2^?--un^?-  u3-un-/ku-ku\-ru  (ta-az-za-ba-al) ^ĝiš-mar-ĝu10-ta ba-ra-ed2-de3-en-e-še  gana ga-ni-re7-en-de3-en gana ga-an-ga-am3-gi-de3-en
en: "Our king! We are ox-drivers. The ox belongs to one man, the cow belongs to one man, and the waggon belongs to one man. We became thirsty and had no water. We said to the owner of the ox, "If you were to fetch some water, then we could drink!". And he said, "What if my ox is devoured by a lion? I will not leave my ox!". We said to the owner of the cow, "If you were to fetch some water, then we could drink!". And he said, "What if my cow went off into the desert? I will not leave my cow!". We said to the owner of the waggon, "If you were to fetch some water, then we could drink!". And he said, "What if the load were removed from my waggon? I will not leave my waggon!". "Come on, let's all go! Come on, and let's return together!""

akk: gud eš2^?- ba-a-la2-e um^?--la2 ab2 a-sila3-ĝar-ra-bi um^?--sur-sur-ru amar ^ĝiš-mar-ra zu2 bi2-in-gub  amar-e a-ba-kam amar-e a-ba-am3 ba-an-de6
en: "First the ox, although tied with a leash , mounted the cow, and then she dropped her young, and the calf started to chew up the waggon's load. Who does this calf belong to? Who can take the calf?"

akk: lugal-e inim nu-mu-un-ne-ši-ib2-gi se2-ek-rum-še3 ba-da-an-kur9  lugal-e se2-ek-rum-ta ad mu-un-di-ni-ib2-gi-gi
en: The king did not give them an answer, but went to visit a cloistered lady. The king sought advice from the cloistered lady:

akk: [ĝuruš 3]-/am3\ an-ta ba-an-gi-eš-a  /lugal-me\ gud-da ri i3-ak-en-de3-nam  gud lu2 1(DIŠ)-a-kam ab2 lu2 1(DIŠ)-a-kam ^ĝiš-mar lu2 1(DIŠ)-a-kam  enmen2^!- bi2-/tuku\-un-da-nam a nu-mu-e-da-ĝal2  lu2 gud-da-ra a u-um-te-šub a ga-naĝ-en-de3-en-e-[še]  gud-ĝu10 ur-maḫ-e u3-bi2-gu7 gud-ĝu10-ta ba-ra-/ed2\-[de3-en-e-še]  lu2 ab2-ba-ra a u3-um-te-šub a ga-naĝ-en-de3-[en-e-še]  ab2-/ĝu10\ [edin]-/še3\ u3-ba-ĝen ab2-ĝu10-ta ba-ra-ed2-[de3-en-e-še]  /lu2\ [^ĝiš-mar-ra]-/ra\ a u3-um-te-šub a ga-naĝ-en-de3-/en\-[e-še]  [^ĝiš-mar-ĝu10 gu2-un] /u3\-[un-ku-ku-ru] ^ĝiš-mar-ĝu10-ta ba-ra-/ed2\-[de3-en-e-še]  [gana ga-ni-re7-en-de3-en] /gana^?- ga^?-\-[an-ga-am3-gi-de3-en]
en: "Three young men came before me and said: "Our king, we are ox-drivers. The ox belongs to one man, the cow belongs to one man, and the waggon belongs to one man. We became thirsty and had no water. We said to the owner of the ox, "If you were to draw some water, then we could drink!". And he said, "What if my ox is devoured by a lion? I will not leave my ox!". We said to the owner of the cow, "If you were to draw some water, then we could drink!". And he said, "What if my cow went off into the desert? I will not leave my cow!". We said to the owner of the waggon, "If you were to draw some water, then we could drink!". And he said, "What if the load were removed from my waggon? I will not leave my waggon!" he said. "Come on, let's all go! Come on, and let's return together!"""

akk: gud eš2^?- ba-a-la2-e ab^?--la2 ab2 a-sila3-ĝar-ra-bi ab^?--sur-sur-ru amar ^ĝiš-mar-ra zu2 bi2-in-gub  [amar-e a-ba-kam amar-e a-ba-am3 ba-an-de6]
en: " "First the ox, although tied with a leash , mounted the cow, and then she dropped her young, and the calf started to chew up the waggon's load. Who does this calf belong to? Who can take the calf?""

akk: [ga-nam lu2 gud-da-ke4 a-šag4-ga-ni …]  [gud-da-ni ur-maḫ-e u3-bi2-gu7 …]  [a-šag4-ga-ni …]  ur-saĝ X […]  lu2 ḫur-saĝ-gin7 AN X […]  gu3-ra ur-/re\ ba-X […]  a2-tuku^?- a-šag4-ga-na zag /lu2^?-\ […]
en: "Well now, the owner of the ox, …… his field ……. After his ox has been eaten by a lion ……, his field ……."1 line missing "The hero ……. Like a mountaineer ……. A dog …… the ox ……. A strong man …… in his field ……."

akk: ga-nam lu2 ab2-ba-ke4 dam-a-[ni …]  ab2-ba-ni edin-še3 u3-ba-ĝen-na […]  dam-a-ni  tilla2-a u3^!--ba-an-ak  […] (im-su2-qi2 i-la-ak-ma)  ab2 a-sila3-ĝar-ra-bi um-sur-sur-ru […]  ur-saĝ IM-a ĝen-na-da […]  dam-a-ni ni2-te^?--ni ri-ri-e-/a DI\ X […]  gu3-ra kurum6-ma-ni ur2-ra-na-še3 bi2-in-gur-ra šag4-ĝar AN […]  dam-a-ni e2-a-na an-da-tuš^!--am3 šag4-ge guru6-/ni\ […]
en: "Well now, the owner of the cow …… his wife. After his cow has gone off into the desert ……, his wife will walk the streets ……. After the cow has dropped its young ……, the hero, walking in the rain ……. His wife …… herself. The ox's food ration which he has turned to his ……, …… hunger. His wife dwells with him in his house, his desired one ……"

akk: ga-nam lu2 ^ĝiš-mar-ra-ke4 me^!--ni ugu-na um-da-šub-ba X […]  ^ĝiš-mar-ra-ni gu2-un um-kud-ku5-ru-a ^ĝiš-mar-/ra-ni-ta u3\-[…]  me-ni e2-a-na u3-da-an-de6 e2-a-ni-ta ba-ra-/šub\-[ba]  amar ^ĝiš-mar-ra zu2 bi2-in-tum3-/tum3\-a-ni e2-a-na ab-ta-an-[tur^?-]-tur^?-  gu3-ra X e2 AŠ ur-ke4 A ĝiš ad-bi ĝeštug2-ĝa2^?- u3-un-ḫal-ḫa nu-mu-da-zi-zi  gu2-un-na-ni bur2-bur2-da ensi2^?- gu-la an-dib-ba nu-mu-un-da-/gi^?-\-gi
en: "Well now, the owner of the waggon, after he has abandoned his ……, and the load has been removed from his waggon, and …… from his waggon, and after he has brought his …… into his house, …… will be made to leave his house. His calf that began to chew up the waggon's load will be …… in his house. When he has approached …… the open-armed hero, the king, having learnt about his case, will make his …… leave his {waste ground} { location}. …… the ox, …… has partaken of my wisdom, shall not oppose it. His load, ……, will not return ."

akk: lugal-e se2-ek-rum-ta ed2-da-ni-ta  lu2 1(DIŠ)^?- šag4-ga-ni A^?- šag4-ga-ni ba-an-ši-ib2-si  lu2 dam-a-ni ḫul an-gig-ga-am3 dam-a-ni-ta ba-an-da-ĝen  lu2 me-ni me-ni ba-an-da-/šub^?-\  inim galam-galam-ma dumu adab^ki--ke4-ne  inim galam-galam-ma-ta di in-dab5-dab5-be2  DIŠ ^d-pa5-niĝin3-ĝar-ra pap-šeš-ne-ne um-mi-a diĝir adab^ki--ke4 dub-sar-bi
en: When the king came out from the cloistered lady's presence, each man's heart was dissatisfied. The man who hated his wife left his wife. The man …… his …… abandoned his ……. With elaborate words, with elaborate words, the case of the citizens of Adab was settled. Pa-niĝin-ĝara, their sage, the scholar, the god of Adab, was the scribe.

akk: nam-zid-tar-ra ^d-en-lil2 mu-zal-le  inim in-na-an-dug4  me-ta-am3 nam-zid-tar-ra  e2 ^d-en-lil2-la2-ta  bal gub-ba-ĝu10 bi2-silim-ma-am3  ki gudug-e-ne-ka udu-bi-da i3-gub-bu-nam  e2-ĝu10-še3 al-du-un  nam-mu-un-gub-be2-en  ĝiri3-ĝu10 ud tab2-tab2  a-ba-am3 za-e-me-en lu2
en: Nam-zid-tara walked by Enlil, who said to him: "Where have you come from, Nam-zid-tara?" "From Enlil's temple. My turn of duty is finished. I serve at the place of the gudug priests, with their sheep. I am on my way home. Don't stop me; I am in a hurry. Who are you who asks me questions?"

akk: ĝe26-e ^d-en-lil2-me-en  ^d-en-lil2-le igi-ni mu-ni-in-gi4  uga^mušen--aš u3-mu-ni-in-kur9  gu3 al-de2-de2-e  uga^mušen- nu-me-en ^d-en-lil2-me-en  nam mu-tar-ra ĝe26-e ^d-en-lil2-me-en a-gin7 bi2-zu
en: "I am Enlil." But Enlil had changed his appearance: he had turned into a raven and was croaking. "But you are not a raven, you really are Enlil!" "How did you recognise that I am Enlil, who decrees the destinies?"

akk: ud en-me-šar2-ra šeš ad-da-zu LU2×KAR2-da-a  nam-^d-en-lil2 ba-e-de6-a ud-de3 en-gin7 nam /ga\-zu-e-še
en: "When your uncle En-me-šara was a captive, after taking for himself the rank of Enlil, he said: "Now I shall know the fates, like a lord.""

akk: kug ḫe2-tuku za ḫe2-tuku gud ḫe2-tuku udu ḫe2-tuku  ud nam-lu2-u18-lu al-ku-nu  niĝ2-tuku-zu me-še3 e-tum3-ma  ^d-en-lil2-me-en nam mu-tar-ra  a-ba-am3 mu-zu
en: "You may acquire precious metals, you may acquire precious stones, you may acquire cattle or you may acquire sheep; but the day of a human being is always getting closer, so where does your wealth lead? Now, I am indeed Enlil, who decrees the fates. What is your name?"

akk: nam-zid-tar-ra mu-ĝu10-um  mu-zu-gin7 nam-zu ḫe2-tar-re  e2 lugal-za-ka e3-a  ibila-zu e2-ĝa2  ḫe2-en-dib-dib-be2-ne
en: "My name is Nam-zid-tara ." "Your fate shall be assigned according to your name: leave the house of your master, and your heirs shall come and go regularly in my temple."

akk: ^m-lugal-nesaĝ-e dumu zu-zu um-mi-a nibru^ki--ke4  tu6-ni-lu2-sag9 ur kiĝ2-gi4-a-ka-ni ^d-nin-tin-ug5-ga-ra mu-na-an-dim2  nam-bi-še3 ur-e nin-a-ni-ir kun mu-na-ab-gun3-gun3 zu2 mu-na-ab-/ra^?--aḫ^?-\  nin an ki-bi šukur2 šum2-ma aĝrig ^d-en-lil2-la2  a2-sag3 simx(GIG)-ma šag4-bi bar ak ĝiri3-pax(PAD)-ra2 igi bar-re  sa nam-til3-la sa nam-uš2-a-ka igi saĝ5-saĝ5 niĝ2-keše2-bi sag9-ge  niĝ2 ra-aḫ-a dug4-ga  ki gig-bi zu-zu  a-zu sag9-ge šim-mu2 tur5-ra-ta šag4 lu2-ulu3 igi du8
en: Lugal-nesaĝe the son of Zuzu, the master-scribe of Nibru, has fashioned for Nintinuga his messenger dog Tuni-lu-sag. That is why the dog will wag his tail or chew for his mistress the queen of heaven and earth, the provider of food, the stewardess of Enlil, the sweet breast satisfying all lands, the bringer of abundance, who can diagnose the intentions of the virulent asag demon and who checks people's bones; who examines the sinews of life and the sinews of death, comforting those joints; who knows every sick spot where there is affliction, torment or distress -- the kindly physician, the exorcist to the sick, who looks after the hearts of humans.

akk: nin-ĝu10 mu-un-dim2-en-na  tu6-ni-lu2-sag9 mu-še3 mu-un-sa4  X X-an-sag9-ga mu-še3 mu-sa4  [X]-ga-DI zi-pa-aĝ2 u3-mu-ni-[X X] a2-/sag3\ zi ba-an-/da\-[X]  [X]-ĝu10 mu-zu-ta im-da-an-/pad3^?-\  nam-gur4-ra-zu ki-zu i3-kiĝ2-ĝe26  tu6-ni-lu2-sag9 mu-še3 mu-un-sa4  ud til3-la-ĝa2 igi ḫu-mu-un-du8  ud ba-ug7-en kur-ra a sig9-ga ḫu-mu-un-na8-[na8]
en: My lady, what I have fashioned I have named with the name Tuni-lu-sag, I call by the name ……. He will …… the throat, and the asag demon will be pacified . My …… will be uttered alongside your name. Your importance ……. I have named him with the name Tuni-lu-sag. May Nintinuga look after me during my life, and when I die may she provide me with clear water in the nether world.

akk: nibru^ki--ta-lu2  dumu lugal-šuba dam-gar3-ra-ke4  ^d-nergal-ra  ḫa-zi-in nagga mu-na-ni-in-dim2  ĝiš-bi ^ĝiš-ar-ga-nu-um ḫur-saĝ-ĝa2  a-lal3-e dirig-ga-am3  na4-bi an-ta-sur-ra-am3  gaba-ri nu-tuku-am3  ḫe2-sag3-ge a2-ni na-an-kuš2-u3
en: Nibruta-lu, the son of the merchant Lugal-šuba, has had this tin axe made for Nergal. Its wooden part is of arganum tree of the mountains, a wood which is superior even to the alal stone; its stone part is of antasura, a stone which has no equal. The arm of the man who strikes with it will never get tired.

akk: ḫe2-eb2-ta-TAR-e  ga-mu-na-ab-silim    ki-bi ga-mu-na-ab-gi4  ud til3-la-ĝa2 igi ḫu-mu-un-du8  ud ba-ug7-en kur-ra  a sig9-ga ḫu-mu-un-na8-na8
en: Should it break, I will repair it for Nergal. Should it disappear, I will replace it for him. May Nergal look after me during my life, and may he provide me with clean water in the underworld after my death.

akk: kišib mu sar ur-DUN dam-gar3-ra   inim pu-uḫ2-ru-um-ma-ta  niĝir-e sila-sila-a si gu3 ba-ni-in-ra  lu2 na-me niĝ2 na-me ugu-na li-bi2-in-tuku
en: A seal inscribed with the name of Ur-DUN, the merchant, was lost. In accordance with the word of the assembly, the herald has sounded the horn throughout all the streets: no one now has any claim against him.

akk: ^m-lugal-me-lem4 ensi2 saĝĝa  KA-KA-ne-ne^?- ba-an-me-eš kišib-ba-ne-ne in-X-eš  ^m-zu-zu um-mi-a  ^m-si-du3 dub-sar  ^m-al-lub /aĝrig\  ^m-ba-an-sag9-ge-en gala  ^m-ul-li2-a ḫa-za-nu-um  niĝir lu2-ki-inim-ma-[me]
en: {Lu-Suena} { Lu-gena} , the governor-general; Lugal-melem, the governor and temple administrator { were their …… and …… their seals} ; Zuzu, the scholar; Si-du, the scribe; Allub, the steward; Bansagen, the lament singer; Ullia, the mayor; and the herald are the witnesses.

akk: ku6-ĝu10 e2 ma-ra-an-du3 /araḫ4\ [ma-ra-an-du3]  e2-a e2 dirig-ga amaš gid2-da ma-/ra\-[an-du3]  šag4-bi na-izi tug2 ma-ra-mur10 ki šag4 ḫul2-le a asila ma-ra-[X]  e2 gu ḫa-la-ḫa-la-ba na-an-na-te kuš3-kuš3-ta /mu\-[…]  e2-e niĝ2-gu7 i3-ĝal2 niĝ2-gu7 saĝ-ĝa2-ba  e2-e niĝ2-gu7 i3-ĝal2 niĝ2-gu7 silim-ma-ba  e2 ki kaš de2-a-zu nim nu-mu-un-bu-bu-bu  mu ḪAR-da-zu du6-da ĝiri3 kur2 nu-ĝal2-la  zag-du8 ^ĝiš-si-ĝar-bi zid2 dub-dub-bu niĝ2-na-e ĝar-ra  e2-e ir-bi tir šim ^ĝiš-erin-na-gin7 ir-si-bi ba-ur5  e2-e kaš mu-un-ĝal2 kaš sig5-ga mu-un-ĝal2  &kaš;dida-imĝaĝa ninda ku7-ku7-da-bi gi ĝar-re-eš mu-un-ĝal2
en: My fish, I have built you a home! My fish, I have built you a house, I have built you a store! I have built you a house bigger than a house, in fact a large sheepfold. Inside there is incense, and I have covered it with cloths for you; in this happy place, I …… water of joy for you; a house not bothered by cords dividing the plots, …… in the gutters. In the house, there is food, food of the best quality. In the house, there is food, food in good condition. No flies buzz around in your house where beer is poured out. Your reputation …… cannot be alienated . The threshold and the door-bolt, the ritual flour and the incense-burner are all in place. The scent and fragance in the house are like an aromatic cedar forest. In the house, there is beer, there is good beer. There is sweet beer, and honeyed cakes, …….

akk: zu-a-zu ḫe2-em-du  kal-la-zu ḫe2-em-du  ad-da pap-bil2-ga-zu ḫe2-em-du  dumu šeš-gal-zu dumu šeš-ban3-da-zu ḫe2-em-du  di4-di4-la2-zu gal-gal-zu ḫe2-em-du  dam-zu dumu-zu ḫe2-em-du  gu5-li-zu dub3-us2-sa-zu ḫe2-em-du  murum5 ušbar-zu ḫe2-em-du  ildum2 bar nam-ga-kur9-ra-zu-uš ḫe2-em-du  dumu gu7-li-zu nam-mu-ni-ib-da13-da13-a  da-a-zu nam-me-eš nam-mu-ni-in-da13-da13
en: Let your acquaintances come! Let your dear ones come! Let your father and grandfather come! Let the sons of your elder brother and the sons of your younger brother come! Let your little ones come, and your big ones too! Let your wife and your children come! Let your friends and companions come! Let your brother-in-law and your father-in-law come! Let the crowd by the side of your front door come! Don't leave your friends' children outside! Don't leave your neighbours outside, whoever they may be!

akk: kur9-ra-ma-ni-ib dumu ki aĝ2-ĝu10  kur9-ra-ma-ni-ib dumu sag9-ga-ĝu10  ud nam-zal-e ĝi6 nam-sa2-e  iti6 e2^?--ba nam-ba-ni-ib-ku4-ku4  ud me-e-zal-la-a-gin7 ĝi6 me-e-sa2-a-gin7  kur9-ra ba-ni-ḫuĝ-ĝe26 ki-ĝar ma-ra-ab-du7  šag4-ba dur2 ĝar X   ku6-ĝu10 lu2 nu2-a ba-ra-ab-zi-zi  lu2 tuš-a du14 ba-ra-mu2-mu2
en: Enter, my beloved son! Enter, my fine son! Don't let the day go by, don't let the night come! The moonlight should not enter that house! But if the day has gone by and the night comes, enter and I will let you relax there; I have made the grounds suitable for you! Inside, I have fixed up a seat for you. My fish, no one who sleeps there will be disturbed; no one who sits there will get involved in a quarrel.

akk: kur9-ra-ma-ni-ib dumu ki aĝ2-ĝu10  kur9-ra-ma-ni-ib dumu sag9-ga-ĝu10  id2 mun-na-gin7 pa5 na-an-zu-zu  saḫar-ĝar id2-da-gin7 zi-zi na-an-zu-zu-u3  a zal-le-gin7 nu2^!--zu na-an-ba-la2-e  iti6 e2-ba nam-ba-ni-in-ku4-ku4
en: Enter, my beloved son! Enter, my fine son! As if you were in a river with brackish water, don't go investigating any canals! As if you were in silt settled on the riverbed, may you not be able to get up! As if you were in flowing water, you should not fix your bed! The moonlight should not enter that house!

akk: na-an-ga-ba-e-da-du-e igi-zu ki-ĝu10-uš-še3  [X]-/gin7\ ki mur gu7-zu-še3 na-an-ga-ba-e-da-du-e igi-zu ki-ĝu10-uš-še3  ur-gin7 ki si-im-si-im ak-zu-še3 na-an-ga-ba-e-da-du-e igi-zu ki-ĝu10-uš-še3  /tum12^?-\[^mušen-]-/gin7\ ki ab-TU^?- du-zu-še3 na-an-ga-ba-e-da-du-e igi-zu ki-ĝu10-uš-še3  gud-gin7 tur3-zu-še3 udu-gin7 amaš-[zu-še3] na-an-ga-ba-e-da-du-e igi-zu ki-ĝu10-uš-še3
en: And may you not succeed in getting away: face towards me! And may you not succeed in getting away like a …… to your lair: face towards me! And may you not succeed in getting away like a dog to where you go sniffing: face towards me! And may you not succeed in getting away like a …… to where you ……: face towards me! And may you not succeed in getting away like a bull to your cattle-pen, like a sheep to your sheepfold: face towards me!

akk: a2-še gud-gin7 tur3-zu-še3 X […]  kur9-ra-ma-ni ^d-/suen\ [ḫe2-en-da-ḫul2-ḫul2]  a2-še udu-gin7 amaš-/zu\-[še3 …]  kur9-ra-ma-ni ^d-dumu-zid-/de3\ [ḫe2-en-da-ḫul2-ḫul2]  gud-gin7 tur3-zu-še3 saĝ il2-[la-zu-ne]  en ^d-aš-im2-babbar ^d-suen [ḫe2-en-da-ḫul2-ḫul2]  udu-gin7 amaš-a saĝ [il2-la-zu-ne]  ^d-dumu-zid ^lu2-sipad [ḫe2-en-da-ḫul2-ḫul2]  nam-ba-an-da-X […]
en: Now, just …… like a bull to your cattle-pen! Enter for me, and Suen will be delighted with you! Now, just …… like a sheep to your sheepfold! Enter for me, and Dumuzid will be delighted with you! When you lift your head like a bull towards your cattle-pen, Lord Ašimbabbar Suen will be delighted with you! When you raise your head like a sheep in the sheepfold, Dumuzid the shepherd will be delighted with you! 15 lines fragmentary or missing

akk: ku6 KAŠ4 ba-ba zag nam DAG-ge  ku6-ĝu10 ku6 ḫi-a ḫe2-ga-me-da-an-ku4-ku4  sun4^?- sag9-sag9 u2-lal3 gu7-/gu7\  ku6-ĝu10 suḫur-gal^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-ga-me-da-an-ku4-ku4  ^gi-ub-zal gu7-gu7 KU i3-[…]  ku6-ĝu10 suḫur-tur<^ku6--ĝu10> ḫe2-ga-me-da-[an-ku4-ku4]  nundum gal-gal gi-zi naĝ-ĝa2  ḫa-la ḪI-ḪI […]  gu7-gu7-da-bi […]  ku6-ĝu10 eštub^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-da-[an-ku4-ku4]  ^ĝiš-gi-muš gig2 a-šag4-ga ri-a  šaḫ2 ama gan gu2 id2-da-ka niĝ2-silaĝ-ĝa2 kar-kar-re  ku6-ĝu10 gu2-bi2^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-da-an-ku4-ku4
en: The fish who ……. May all kinds of fish also enter with you, my fish! The one with handsome barbels who eats the honey plant, my suḫur-gal fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The one who always eats …… reeds, ……, my suḫur-tur fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The one with big lips, who sucks the gizi reeds, 1 line fragmentary whose food ……, my eštub fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The black punting-pole, engendered in the fields, the farrowing sow who takes away the dough from the river banks, my gubi fish : may he also enter with you, my fish!

akk: ku6 šudu3-ba dumu er2 pad3-da-gin7  saĝ-du ^ĝiš-al-la zu2 ^ĝiš-ga-rig2 zu  ĝiri3-pax(PAD)-ra2-bi ^ĝiš-u3-suḫ5 an-na  mu-tun3-na-bi ^kuš-ummud ^d-dumu-zid-da  kuš niĝ2-gu7-a kiĝ2-še3 nu-ĝa2-ĝa2  kun sal-la-bi ^kuš-a2-si šu-KU6-de3-ne  ku6 šu tu11-tu11 kuš ni2-ba gu7-gu7  šag4-ga-ni giri17-ba nu-ĝal2-la  ku6 gaba-ri a2-ur2 dab5-ba  ^kuš-dala2-a gag-še3 bal-bal-a-bi  niĝ2-gig eš3 iri sa2-dug4 nu-ĝa2-ĝa2  ku6-ĝu10 mur^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-da-an-ku4-ku4
en: The one with a spiny tail and a spiny back, who goes ……, my še-suḫur-gal fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The fish who is like a crying child in its prayers, my še-suḫur-sig fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! With a pickaxe as a head, and having a comb for teeth, the branches of a fir-tree as its bones, Dumuzid's waterskin for its stomach , with a dehaired skin that does not need processing, with its slender tail like the fishermen's whip, the jumping fish, with naturally smoothed skin, with no entrails in its nose, the fish that hides from its adversary, whose sting goes across like a nail, that is taboo and is not placed as an offering in the city's shrines, my mur fish : may he also enter with you, my fish!

akk: ĝiri3 ku6-a a lu3-lu3 gur-ra  ku6 i3-guru5-a igi du8-de3 dab5-ba  ku6-ĝu10 kiĝ2^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-[da-an-ku4-ku4]  saĝ-du ^na4-kinkin(ḪAR)-šu šu saĝ ur-gir15-/ra\  MURGU LUM-LUM-de3 bar šir du3-du3-de3  ku6 ^u2-X [X] MU nu-gu7 al-/ḪAR\ […]  ku6-ĝu10 ĝir2-gid2^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-[da-an-ku4-ku4]  šag4-niĝin za-pa-aĝ2-bi gu2 bal-bi  ku6-ĝu10 gir^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-<da-an-ku4-ku4>  /ku6\ KU-na sig10-ga ku6 še-er-tab-ba e3 zu-zu  ku6 dug3-ga i3-ĝal2 niĝ2-gig-ga  ku6-ĝu10 ab-suḫur^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-<da-an-ku4-ku4>  ku6 a-KUD du3 ze2 me-ze2-bi ĝar-ra  ku6-ĝu10 a-garx(NUNtenû)-garx(NUNtenû)^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-<da-an-ku4-ku4>  dumu dam-gar3-ra NI GA IM A-ĝu10  ku6-ĝu10 ka-mar^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-<mu-e-da-an-ku4-ku4>  dumu mar-tu bar-ta tum2-tum2-mu
en: The one whose fins churn the troubled waters, a fish who seizes …… at a glance , my kiĝ fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! With a head like a small millstone, …… a dog's head, 1 line unclear the fish who does not eat the …… plants, ……, my ĝir-gid fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! With the noise of his entrails ……, my gir fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The fish who ……, the fish who knows how to escape through a reed barrier, the fish who despite being tasty is an abomination, my ab-suḫur fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The fish that causes breaches in dykes, with venom in its jaws, my agargar fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The one whom the merchants ……, my kamar fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The one whom the Martu fetch away, my nunbar-gid fish: may he also enter with you, my fish!

akk: ku6 u2-gu7 nu-gu7-a a pu2 /KA\ […]  ku6-ĝu10 a-zag-gur11^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-<mu-e-da-an-ku4-ku4>  kuš dugud gar3-ru šu X […]  ku6-ĝu10 /muš\[^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-da-an-ku4-ku4]
en: The fish who does not eat edible plants, ……, my azagur fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The one that …… a heavy skin, ……, my muš fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! approx. 7 lines fragmentary or missing

……, spotted ……, my ĝiru fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The one that the children bring in ……, my salsal fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The one with snake's eyes, a …… mouse's mouth, who …… on riverbanks, approx. 8 lines fragmentary or missing

The one who utters its sinister cry in the marshes and rivers, my akane bird: you would be dangling from its claws, my fish! The one who circles the nets looking for you in the waters where the nets are stretched, my ubure bird: you would be dangling from its claws, my fish! The one with long legs, that laughs, the one from faraway waters, that ……, my egret : you would be dangling from its claws, my fish! The one who does not adorn ……, with the …… of a bird and webbed feet, my kib bird: you would be dangling from its claws, my fish! The one who seizes the quadrupeds that wander into the marshes, my kuda crocodile: you would be dangling from its claws, my fish!

But you won't be dangling from their claws, you won't be snatched up by their feet! Time is pressing, my fish! Just you come to me! Time is pressing! Just you come to me! Nanše, the queen of the fishermen, will be delighted with you.

Inside there is incense, and I have covered it with cloths for you; in this happy place, I …… water of joy for you; a house not bothered by cords dividing the plots, …… in the gutters. In the house, there is food, food of the best quality. In the house, there is food, food in good condition. No flies buzz around in your house where beer is poured out. Your reputation …… cannot be alienated . The threshold and the door-bolt, the ritual flour and the incense-burner are all in place. The scent and fragance in the house are like an aromatic cedar forest. In the house, there is beer, there is good beer. There is sweet beer, and honeyed cakes, …….
