en: The one with a spiny tail and a spiny back, who goes ……, my še-suḫur-gal fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The fish who is like a crying child in its prayers, my še-suḫur-sig fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! With a pickaxe as a head, and having a comb for teeth, the branches of a fir-tree as its bones, Dumuzid's waterskin for its stomach , with a dehaired skin that does not need processing, with its slender tail like the fishermen's whip, the jumping fish, with naturally smoothed skin, with no entrails in its nose, the fish that hides from its adversary, whose sting goes across like a nail, that is taboo and is not placed as an offering in the city's shrines, my mur fish : may he also enter with you, my fish!

akk: ĝiri3 ku6-a a lu3-lu3 gur-ra  ku6 i3-guru5-a igi du8-de3 dab5-ba  ku6-ĝu10 kiĝ2^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-[da-an-ku4-ku4]  saĝ-du ^na4-kinkin(ḪAR)-šu šu saĝ ur-gir15-/ra\  MURGU LUM-LUM-de3 bar šir du3-du3-de3  ku6 ^u2-X [X] MU nu-gu7 al-/ḪAR\ […]  ku6-ĝu10 ĝir2-gid2^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-[da-an-ku4-ku4]  šag4-niĝin za-pa-aĝ2-bi gu2 bal-bi  ku6-ĝu10 gir^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-<da-an-ku4-ku4>  /ku6\ KU-na sig10-ga ku6 še-er-tab-ba e3 zu-zu  ku6 dug3-ga i3-ĝal2 niĝ2-gig-ga  ku6-ĝu10 ab-suḫur^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-<da-an-ku4-ku4>  ku6 a-KUD du3 ze2 me-ze2-bi ĝar-ra  ku6-ĝu10 a-garx(NUNtenû)-garx(NUNtenû)^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-<da-an-ku4-ku4>  dumu dam-gar3-ra NI GA IM A-ĝu10  ku6-ĝu10 ka-mar^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-<mu-e-da-an-ku4-ku4>  dumu mar-tu bar-ta tum2-tum2-mu
en: The one whose fins churn the troubled waters, a fish who seizes …… at a glance , my kiĝ fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! With a head like a small millstone, …… a dog's head, 1 line unclear the fish who does not eat the …… plants, ……, my ĝir-gid fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! With the noise of his entrails ……, my gir fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The fish who ……, the fish who knows how to escape through a reed barrier, the fish who despite being tasty is an abomination, my ab-suḫur fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The fish that causes breaches in dykes, with venom in its jaws, my agargar fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The one whom the merchants ……, my kamar fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The one whom the Martu fetch away, my nunbar-gid fish: may he also enter with you, my fish!

akk: ku6 u2-gu7 nu-gu7-a a pu2 /KA\ […]  ku6-ĝu10 a-zag-gur11^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-<mu-e-da-an-ku4-ku4>  kuš dugud gar3-ru šu X […]  ku6-ĝu10 /muš\[^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-da-an-ku4-ku4]
en: The fish who does not eat edible plants, ……, my azagur fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The one that …… a heavy skin, ……, my muš fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! approx. 7 lines fragmentary or missing

……, spotted ……, my ĝiru fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The one that the children bring in ……, my salsal fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The one with snake's eyes, a …… mouse's mouth, who …… on riverbanks, approx. 8 lines fragmentary or missing

The one who utters its sinister cry in the marshes and rivers, my akane bird: you would be dangling from its claws, my fish! The one who circles the nets looking for you in the waters where the nets are stretched, my ubure bird: you would be dangling from its claws, my fish! The one with long legs, that laughs, the one from faraway waters, that ……, my egret : you would be dangling from its claws, my fish! The one who does not adorn ……, with the …… of a bird and webbed feet, my kib bird: you would be dangling from its claws, my fish! The one who seizes the quadrupeds that wander into the marshes, my kuda crocodile: you would be dangling from its claws, my fish!

But you won't be dangling from their claws, you won't be snatched up by their feet! Time is pressing, my fish! Just you come to me! Time is pressing! Just you come to me! Nanše, the queen of the fishermen, will be delighted with you.

akk: ku6-ĝu10 e2 ma-ra-an-du3 /araḫ4\ [ma-ra-an-du3]  e2-a e2 dirig-ga amaš gid2-da ma-/ra\-[an-du3]  šag4-bi na-izi tug2 ma-ra-mur10 ki šag4 ḫul2-le a asila ma-ra-[X]  e2 gu ḫa-la-ḫa-la-ba na-an-na-te kuš3-kuš3-ta /mu\-[…]  e2-e niĝ2-gu7 i3-ĝal2 niĝ2-gu7 saĝ-ĝa2-ba  e2-e niĝ2-gu7 i3-ĝal2 niĝ2-gu7 silim-ma-ba  e2 ki kaš de2-a-zu nim nu-mu-un-bu-bu-bu  mu ḪAR-da-zu du6-da ĝiri3 kur2 nu-ĝal2-la  zag-du8 ^ĝiš-si-ĝar-bi zid2 dub-dub-bu niĝ2-na-e ĝar-ra  e2-e ir-bi tir šim ^ĝiš-erin-na-gin7 ir-si-bi ba-ur5  e2-e kaš mu-un-ĝal2 kaš sig5-ga mu-un-ĝal2  &kaš;dida-imĝaĝa ninda ku7-ku7-da-bi gi ĝar-re-eš mu-un-ĝal2
en: My fish, I have built you a home! My fish, I have built you a house, I have built you a store! I have built you a house bigger than a house, in fact a large sheepfold. Inside there is incense, and I have covered it with cloths for you; in this happy place, I …… water of joy for you; a house not bothered by cords dividing the plots, …… in the gutters. In the house, there is food, food of the best quality. In the house, there is food, food in good condition. No flies buzz around in your house where beer is poured out. Your reputation …… cannot be alienated . The threshold and the door-bolt, the ritual flour and the incense-burner are all in place. The scent and fragance in the house are like an aromatic cedar forest. In the house, there is beer, there is good beer. There is sweet beer, and honeyed cakes, …….

akk: zu-a-zu ḫe2-em-du  kal-la-zu ḫe2-em-du  ad-da pap-bil2-ga-zu ḫe2-em-du  dumu šeš-gal-zu dumu šeš-ban3-da-zu ḫe2-em-du  di4-di4-la2-zu gal-gal-zu ḫe2-em-du  dam-zu dumu-zu ḫe2-em-du  gu5-li-zu dub3-us2-sa-zu ḫe2-em-du  murum5 ušbar-zu ḫe2-em-du  ildum2 bar nam-ga-kur9-ra-zu-uš ḫe2-em-du  dumu gu7-li-zu nam-mu-ni-ib-da13-da13-a  da-a-zu nam-me-eš nam-mu-ni-in-da13-da13
en: Let your acquaintances come! Let your dear ones come! Let your father and grandfather come! Let the sons of your elder brother and the sons of your younger brother come! Let your little ones come, and your big ones too! Let your wife and your children come! Let your friends and companions come! Let your brother-in-law and your father-in-law come! Let the crowd by the side of your front door come! Don't leave your friends' children outside! Don't leave your neighbours outside, whoever they may be!

akk: kur9-ra-ma-ni-ib dumu ki aĝ2-ĝu10  kur9-ra-ma-ni-ib dumu sag9-ga-ĝu10  ud nam-zal-e ĝi6 nam-sa2-e  iti6 e2^?--ba nam-ba-ni-ib-ku4-ku4  ud me-e-zal-la-a-gin7 ĝi6 me-e-sa2-a-gin7  kur9-ra ba-ni-ḫuĝ-ĝe26 ki-ĝar ma-ra-ab-du7  šag4-ba dur2 ĝar X   ku6-ĝu10 lu2 nu2-a ba-ra-ab-zi-zi  lu2 tuš-a du14 ba-ra-mu2-mu2
en: Enter, my beloved son! Enter, my fine son! Don't let the day go by, don't let the night come! The moonlight should not enter that house! But if the day has gone by and the night comes, enter and I will let you relax there; I have made the grounds suitable for you! Inside, I have fixed up a seat for you. My fish, no one who sleeps there will be disturbed; no one who sits there will get involved in a quarrel.

akk: kur9-ra-ma-ni-ib dumu ki aĝ2-ĝu10  kur9-ra-ma-ni-ib dumu sag9-ga-ĝu10  id2 mun-na-gin7 pa5 na-an-zu-zu  saḫar-ĝar id2-da-gin7 zi-zi na-an-zu-zu-u3  a zal-le-gin7 nu2^!--zu na-an-ba-la2-e  iti6 e2-ba nam-ba-ni-in-ku4-ku4
en: Enter, my beloved son! Enter, my fine son! As if you were in a river with brackish water, don't go investigating any canals! As if you were in silt settled on the riverbed, may you not be able to get up! As if you were in flowing water, you should not fix your bed! The moonlight should not enter that house!

akk: na-an-ga-ba-e-da-du-e igi-zu ki-ĝu10-uš-še3  [X]-/gin7\ ki mur gu7-zu-še3 na-an-ga-ba-e-da-du-e igi-zu ki-ĝu10-uš-še3  ur-gin7 ki si-im-si-im ak-zu-še3 na-an-ga-ba-e-da-du-e igi-zu ki-ĝu10-uš-še3  /tum12^?-\[^mušen-]-/gin7\ ki ab-TU^?- du-zu-še3 na-an-ga-ba-e-da-du-e igi-zu ki-ĝu10-uš-še3  gud-gin7 tur3-zu-še3 udu-gin7 amaš-[zu-še3] na-an-ga-ba-e-da-du-e igi-zu ki-ĝu10-uš-še3
en: And may you not succeed in getting away: face towards me! And may you not succeed in getting away like a …… to your lair: face towards me! And may you not succeed in getting away like a dog to where you go sniffing: face towards me! And may you not succeed in getting away like a …… to where you ……: face towards me! And may you not succeed in getting away like a bull to your cattle-pen, like a sheep to your sheepfold: face towards me!

akk: a2-še gud-gin7 tur3-zu-še3 X […]  kur9-ra-ma-ni ^d-/suen\ [ḫe2-en-da-ḫul2-ḫul2]  a2-še udu-gin7 amaš-/zu\-[še3 …]  kur9-ra-ma-ni ^d-dumu-zid-/de3\ [ḫe2-en-da-ḫul2-ḫul2]  gud-gin7 tur3-zu-še3 saĝ il2-[la-zu-ne]  en ^d-aš-im2-babbar ^d-suen [ḫe2-en-da-ḫul2-ḫul2]  udu-gin7 amaš-a saĝ [il2-la-zu-ne]  ^d-dumu-zid ^lu2-sipad [ḫe2-en-da-ḫul2-ḫul2]  nam-ba-an-da-X […]
en: Now, just …… like a bull to your cattle-pen! Enter for me, and Suen will be delighted with you! Now, just …… like a sheep to your sheepfold! Enter for me, and Dumuzid will be delighted with you! When you lift your head like a bull towards your cattle-pen, Lord Ašimbabbar Suen will be delighted with you! When you raise your head like a sheep in the sheepfold, Dumuzid the shepherd will be delighted with you! 15 lines fragmentary or missing

en: The fish who ……. May all kinds of fish also enter with you, my fish! The one with handsome barbels who eats the honey plant, my suḫur-gal fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The one who always eats …… reeds, ……, my suḫur-tur fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The one with big lips, who sucks the gizi reeds, 1 line fragmentary whose food ……, my eštub fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The black punting-pole, engendered in the fields, the farrowing sow who takes away the dough from the river banks, my gubi fish : may he also enter with you, my fish!

And may you not succeed in getting away like a dog to where you go sniffing: face towards me! And may you not succeed in getting away like a …… to where you ……: face towards me! And may you not succeed in getting away like a bull to your cattle-pen, like a sheep to your sheepfold: face towards me!

akk: a2-še gud-gin7 tur3-zu-še3 X […]  kur9-ra-ma-ni ^d-/suen\ [ḫe2-en-da-ḫul2-ḫul2]  a2-še udu-gin7 amaš-/zu\-[še3 …]  kur9-ra-ma-ni ^d-dumu-zid-/de3\ [ḫe2-en-da-ḫul2-ḫul2]  gud-gin7 tur3-zu-še3 saĝ il2-[la-zu-ne]  en ^d-aš-im2-babbar ^d-suen [ḫe2-en-da-ḫul2-ḫul2]  udu-gin7 amaš-a saĝ [il2-la-zu-ne]  ^d-dumu-zid ^lu2-sipad [ḫe2-en-da-ḫul2-ḫul2]  nam-ba-an-da-X […]
en: Now, just …… like a bull to your cattle-pen! Enter for me, and Suen will be delighted with you! Now, just …… like a sheep to your sheepfold! Enter for me, and Dumuzid will be delighted with you! When you lift your head like a bull towards your cattle-pen, Lord Ašimbabbar Suen will be delighted with you! When you raise your head like a sheep in the sheepfold, Dumuzid the shepherd will be delighted with you! 15 lines fragmentary or missing

akk: ku6 KAŠ4 ba-ba zag nam DAG-ge  ku6-ĝu10 ku6 ḫi-a ḫe2-ga-me-da-an-ku4-ku4  sun4^?- sag9-sag9 u2-lal3 gu7-/gu7\  ku6-ĝu10 suḫur-gal^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-ga-me-da-an-ku4-ku4  ^gi-ub-zal gu7-gu7 KU i3-[…]  ku6-ĝu10 suḫur-tur<^ku6--ĝu10> ḫe2-ga-me-da-[an-ku4-ku4]  nundum gal-gal gi-zi naĝ-ĝa2  ḫa-la ḪI-ḪI […]  gu7-gu7-da-bi […]  ku6-ĝu10 eštub^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-da-[an-ku4-ku4]  ^ĝiš-gi-muš gig2 a-šag4-ga ri-a  šaḫ2 ama gan gu2 id2-da-ka niĝ2-silaĝ-ĝa2 kar-kar-re  ku6-ĝu10 gu2-bi2^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-da-an-ku4-ku4
en: The fish who ……. May all kinds of fish also enter with you, my fish! The one with handsome barbels who eats the honey plant, my suḫur-gal fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The one who always eats …… reeds, ……, my suḫur-tur fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The one with big lips, who sucks the gizi reeds, 1 line fragmentary whose food ……, my eštub fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The black punting-pole, engendered in the fields, the farrowing sow who takes away the dough from the river banks, my gubi fish : may he also enter with you, my fish!

akk: ku6 šudu3-ba dumu er2 pad3-da-gin7  saĝ-du ^ĝiš-al-la zu2 ^ĝiš-ga-rig2 zu  ĝiri3-pax(PAD)-ra2-bi ^ĝiš-u3-suḫ5 an-na  mu-tun3-na-bi ^kuš-ummud ^d-dumu-zid-da  kuš niĝ2-gu7-a kiĝ2-še3 nu-ĝa2-ĝa2  kun sal-la-bi ^kuš-a2-si šu-KU6-de3-ne  ku6 šu tu11-tu11 kuš ni2-ba gu7-gu7  šag4-ga-ni giri17-ba nu-ĝal2-la  ku6 gaba-ri a2-ur2 dab5-ba  ^kuš-dala2-a gag-še3 bal-bal-a-bi  niĝ2-gig eš3 iri sa2-dug4 nu-ĝa2-ĝa2  ku6-ĝu10 mur^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-da-an-ku4-ku4
en: The one with a spiny tail and a spiny back, who goes ……, my še-suḫur-gal fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The fish who is like a crying child in its prayers, my še-suḫur-sig fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! With a pickaxe as a head, and having a comb for teeth, the branches of a fir-tree as its bones, Dumuzid's waterskin for its stomach , with a dehaired skin that does not need processing, with its slender tail like the fishermen's whip, the jumping fish, with naturally smoothed skin, with no entrails in its nose, the fish that hides from its adversary, whose sting goes across like a nail, that is taboo and is not placed as an offering in the city's shrines, my mur fish : may he also enter with you, my fish!

akk: ĝiri3 ku6-a a lu3-lu3 gur-ra  ku6 i3-guru5-a igi du8-de3 dab5-ba  ku6-ĝu10 kiĝ2^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-[da-an-ku4-ku4]  saĝ-du ^na4-kinkin(ḪAR)-šu šu saĝ ur-gir15-/ra\  MURGU LUM-LUM-de3 bar šir du3-du3-de3  ku6 ^u2-X [X] MU nu-gu7 al-/ḪAR\ […]  ku6-ĝu10 ĝir2-gid2^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-[da-an-ku4-ku4]  šag4-niĝin za-pa-aĝ2-bi gu2 bal-bi  ku6-ĝu10 gir^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-<da-an-ku4-ku4>  /ku6\ KU-na sig10-ga ku6 še-er-tab-ba e3 zu-zu  ku6 dug3-ga i3-ĝal2 niĝ2-gig-ga  ku6-ĝu10 ab-suḫur^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-<da-an-ku4-ku4>  ku6 a-KUD du3 ze2 me-ze2-bi ĝar-ra  ku6-ĝu10 a-garx(NUNtenû)-garx(NUNtenû)^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-<da-an-ku4-ku4>  dumu dam-gar3-ra NI GA IM A-ĝu10  ku6-ĝu10 ka-mar^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-<mu-e-da-an-ku4-ku4>  dumu mar-tu bar-ta tum2-tum2-mu
en: The one whose fins churn the troubled waters, a fish who seizes …… at a glance , my kiĝ fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! With a head like a small millstone, …… a dog's head, 1 line unclear the fish who does not eat the …… plants, ……, my ĝir-gid fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! With the noise of his entrails ……, my gir fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The fish who ……, the fish who knows how to escape through a reed barrier, the fish who despite being tasty is an abomination, my ab-suḫur fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The fish that causes breaches in dykes, with venom in its jaws, my agargar fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The one whom the merchants ……, my kamar fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The one whom the Martu fetch away, my nunbar-gid fish: may he also enter with you, my fish!

akk: ku6 u2-gu7 nu-gu7-a a pu2 /KA\ […]  ku6-ĝu10 a-zag-gur11^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-<mu-e-da-an-ku4-ku4>  kuš dugud gar3-ru šu X […]  ku6-ĝu10 /muš\[^ku6--ĝu10 ḫe2-en-ga-mu-e-da-an-ku4-ku4]
en: The fish who does not eat edible plants, ……, my azagur fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! The one that …… a heavy skin, ……, my muš fish: may he also enter with you, my fish! approx. 7 lines fragmentary or missing

akk: [ĝiš-gi] /daĝal\ tu-tu-[ub-ba^ki--a-ka] mu2-a-bi dug3-ga-am3  [ambar-ra] [kiri8]-tab-ba^ki--a-[ka] mu2-a-bi dug3-ga-am3  [a-dar]-ra akšak^ki--a-ka mu2-a-bi dug3-ga-am3  [sug] /zu2\ keše2-da ^d-en-ki-ka3-ka mu2-a-bi dug3-ga-am3  [sug] ban3-da sug ^d-en-ki-ka3-ka mu2-a-bi dug3-ga-am3  /^gi-\bar-bar ^d-en-ki-ka3-ka mu2-a-bi dug3-ga-am3  urim2^ki--ma gi-zi di4-di4-la2 mu2-a-bi dug3-ga-am3  urim2^ki--ma ab2 lu amar lu-a re mu2-a-bi dug3-ga-am3
en: What do they say in the reedbeds whose growth is good? In the wide reedbeds of Tutub, whose growth is good? In the marshes of Kiritaba, whose growth is good? In the adara thickets of Akšak, whose growth is good? In Enki's interconnecting lagoons, whose growth is good? In the smaller lagoon, Enki's lagoon, whose growth is good? In Enki's barbar reeds, whose growth is good? In the little zi reeds of Urim, whose growth is good? In Urim, where cows and calves abound, whose growth is good?

akk: ud-bi-a /a\ X /gi\-ta nam-kud amaš-e pa nam-e3  ^u2-aš-tal2-tal2 ĝiš-gi-ta numun-bi sal-sal-e  ^u2-ku-mul tur-tur ki-ta nam-ta-an-e3 nam-di4-di4-la2 dug3-ga-am3  ^gi-en3-bar tur-re suḫ10 nam-dub-dub nam-ki-sikil dug3-ga-am3  ^gi-ub-zal iri-bi-da nam-da-DI nam-ĝuruš dug3-ga-am3  ^gi-pe-el-la2 ur2-ra saĝ-še3 nam-ib-dul e2-gi4-a dug3-ga-am3  ^gi-pe-el-la2 ur2-ra saĝ-še3 nam-ta-ab-gi4 dumu ban3-da dug3-ga-am3  ^gi-gašam-e ki am3-buru3-e nam-ab-ba dug3-ga-am3  gi-zi ni2-bi-a nam-mu-un-šu2 nam-um-ma dug3-ga-am3  [ĝiš]-/gi\ sig7-ga-bi saĝ nam-il2 gu3-de2-a dug3-ga-am3  ^ĝiš-ildag2 šita3-na saĝ nam-il2 nam-lugal-la dug3-ga-am3  […]-e pa mul-mul-la dumu lugal-la dug3-ga-am3
en: At that time, the water was drained away from the reeds ……, and they were visible at the sheepfold. The aštaltal plant, spreading its seeds from the reedbeds, and the little kumul plants came out of the earth: they are good as little ones. The small enbar reed tighten her headdress: it is good as a young maiden. The ubzal reed goes about the city: it is good as a young man. The pela reed is covered from bottom to top: it is a good daughter-in-law. The pela reed turns from bottom to top: it is a good young son. The gašam reed digs in the ground: it is good as an old man. The zi reed …… on its own: it is good as an old woman. The reedbed lifts its head beautifully: it is a good Gudea. The ildag tree lifts its head in the irrigation ditch: it is good as a king. …… with bright branches: it is a good prince.

akk: [ud-bi]-a zag ĝiš-gi-e^?- ki-a tuš^?--e u3-gul mu-na-ĝa2-ĝa2  /igira2\^mušen- nunuz ga-bur12 ga-de6 ab-e X BA^?- X X-eš2^?-  [mušen]-e lu2 kadra-ke4 kadra na-ak-e  /igira2\^mušen- lu2 kadra-ke4 kadra na-ak-e
en: On that day, beside the reedbeds, someone sitting on the bank prays: "Let me snatch away the heron's eggs, let me take them away ……, so that the gift-bringing bird will not be able to make a gift, so that the gift-bringing heron will not be able make a gift!"

akk: ku6 im-dab5 nunuz im-de5-de5-ge zag im-ma-ni-in-tag  u2-lal3-e suḫur^ku6--e zag im-ma-ni-in-tag  eštub^ku6--e gi-zi di4-di4-la2 zag im-ma-ni-in-tag  kiĝ2-tur-e ^u2-li-gi4-li-gi4-a zag im-ma-ni-in-tag  [agargara^ku6-]-e niĝ2 zig3-ga-ni zag-bar-ra zag im-ma-ni-in-tag  /igira2\^mušen- nunuz nam-šum ab-ba na-gaz-gaz
en: It catches fish; it collects eggs and crushes them. It crushes the suḫur carp in the honey plants. It crushes the eštub carp in the little zi reeds. It crushes toads in the ligiligi grass. It crushes fish spawn, its offspring, its family. It strikes heron's eggs and smashes them in the sea.

akk: [mušen]-e lu2 kadra-ke4 u3-gul mu-un-na-ĝa2-ĝa2  [igira2]^mušen- lugal ^d-en-ki e2-a ba-ši-in-kur9 gu3 mu-un-na-de2-e  […] /ki\ daĝal šum2-ma-ab nunuz ki ḫa-ba-ni-in-tag  […] /mu\-na-da-ab-šum2-mu  […] ḪI mu-na-ĝa2-ĝa2  […] ḪI ab-ba na-nam  […] gi mušen-na-ka  […]-a-ka nunuz ki ba-ni-in-tag  [ĝiš-gi daĝal tu-tu-ub-ba^ki--ke4 nunuz ki ba-ni-in]-/tag\  ambar-ra kiri8-tab[^ki--a-ke4] nunuz ki ba-ni-in-tag  a-dar-ra akšak^ki--[a-ke4] [nunuz ki ba-ni-in]-/tag\  sug zu2 keše2-da ^d-en-ki-/ka3\-[ke4] [nunuz ki ba-ni]-/in\-tag  sug ban3-da sug eridug^ki--ga-ke4 nunuz [ki ba-ni]-in-tag  ^gi-bar-bar ^d-en-ki-ka3-ke4 nunuz ki ba-ni-in-tag  urim2^ki--ma gi-zi di4-di4-la2 nunuz ki ba-ni-in-tag  urim2^ki--ma ab2 lu amar lu-a re nunuz ki ba-ni-[in-tag]
en: The gift-giving bird made a plea; the heron entered the house of King Enki and spoke to him: "Give me …… a wide-open place to lay my eggs in." He gave her ……, and did …… for her. …… is indeed …… 1 line fragmentary She laid eggs in the ……. She laid eggs in the wide reedbeds of Tutub. She laid eggs in the marshes of Kiritaba. She laid eggs in the adara thickets of Akšak. She laid eggs in Enki's interconnecting lagoons. She laid eggs in the smaller lagoon, the lagoon of Eridug. She laid eggs in Enki's barbar reeds. She laid eggs in the little zi reeds of Urim. She laid eggs in Urim, where cows and calves abound.

akk: ud-bi-a niĝ2-bun2-na lu2 du14 mu2-a-ke4 lu2 ḫar-ra-/an\ [gig-ga]-ke4  igira2^mušen- igira2^mušen--da du14 ga-nam mu-da-mu2  niĝ2-bun2-na igira2^mušen--da du14 ga-nam mu-da-mu2  lu2 igi-ni-ta igi muš-ke4 du14 ga-nam mu-da-mu2  ka-ga14-ni ka muš-a-ke4 du14 ga-nam /mu\-[da]-mu2  eme-ni eme muš-a-ke4 du14 ga-nam [mu]-da-mu2  gug-ni gug ur tur-ra-ke4 du14 ga-/nam\ [mu-da]-mu2  šu sal-sal-e  me-[ri]  sal-sal-e du14 ga-[nam mu-da]-mu2  niĝ2-bun2-na šeg12 udun-na-ke4 du14 [ga-nam mu-da]-mu2  šag4 mu2-sar-ra-ke4 du14 ga-/nam\ [mu-da]-mu2  ^ĝiš-al-gin7 im-ma ud zal-la re du14 ga-/nam\ [mu-da]-/mu2\  ^ĝiš-dusu saḫar-ra nu-luḫ-ḫa-e du14 ga-/nam\ [mu-da]-/mu2\
en: Then the quarrelsome turtle, he of the troublesome way, said: "I am going to pick a quarrel with the heron, the heron! I, the turtle, am going to pick a quarrel with the heron! I, whose eyes are snake's eyes, am going to pick a quarrel! I, whose mouth is a snake's mouth, am going to pick a quarrel! I, whose tongue is a snake's tongue, am going to pick a quarrel! I, whose bite is a puppy's bite, am going to pick a quarrel! With my slender hands and slender feet, I am going to pick a quarrel! I, the turtle -- an oven brick -- am going to pick a quarrel! I, who live in the vegetable gardens, am going to pick a quarrel! I, who like a digging tool spend my time in the mud, am going to pick a quarrel! I, an unwashed refuse-basket, am going to pick a quarrel!"

akk: niĝ2-bun2-na lu2-^ĝiš-ḫar-mušen-na lu2-dub3-ĝar-ra-e  igira2 gi du3-a-ni mu-na-an-bu-bu  gud3 us2-sa-ni ba-ni-in-suḫ3-suḫ3  dumu-ni a-e ba-ni-in-ra  mušen-e lu2 igi ku10-ku10-ga-ke4  niĝ2-bun2-na saĝ-ki-ni umbin um-mi-in-la2  uš2-bi gaba-na im-mi-in-/šu2\-[šu2]
en: The turtle, the trapper of birds, the setter of nets, overthrew the heron's construction of reeds for her, turned her nest upside down, and tipped her children into the water. The turtle scratched the dark-eyed bird's forehead with its claws, so that her breast was covered in blood from it. { …… in the dust.}

akk: saḫar-e a /šag4\ […]  igira2^mušen- er2 im-ma-an-pad3 šex(SIG7)-šex(SIG7) i3^?--/ĝa2\-ĝa2  mušen-me-en gud3 sug4-ga-ĝu10 […] u3-um-DU ab-[…]  [igira2^mušen-]-me-en […]  lugal-ĝu10 di-ĝu10 ga-ba-ed3 /ka\ […]  lugal-ĝu10  ka-aš-ĝu10 ḫe2-bar-[re]  ^d-en-ki-ke4  ka-aš-[ĝu10 ḫe2-bar-re]  inim-inim-ma-ĝu10 en eridug^ki--ga-ke4 […]
en: The heron cried out, shedding tears: "If I, a bird, …… my empty nest and …… { I, a heron, ……; I shall take my case up to my king, ……}. Let my king judge my case, and give me verdict! Let Enki judge my case, and give me verdict! May the lord of Eridug …… my claim."

akk: 2-kam-ma-še3 mušen lu2 kadra kadra-a na-ak-e  igira2^mušen--e lu2 kadra-ke4 kadra-a na-ak-e  ku6 im-dab5 nunuz im-de5-de5-ge zag im-ma-ni-ib-tag  eštub^ku6--e gi-zi di4-di4-la2 zag im-ma-ni-ib-tag  kiĝ2-tur-e ^u2-li-gi4-li-gi4 [zag im-ma-ni]-/ib\-tag  agargara^ku6--e niĝ2 zig3-ga-ni zag-bar-ra [zag im-ma-ni-ib-tag]
en: "A second time, may the gift-bringing bird not be able to make a gift, may the gift-bringing heron not be able to make a gift!" It  catches fish; it collects eggs and crushes them. It crushes the suḫur carp in the {honey plants} { reedbeds}. It crushes the eštub carp in the little zi reeds. It crushes toads in the ligiligi grass. It crushes fish spawn, its offspring, its family.

akk: {i3-buru3 ki-a […] saĝ an-še3 mu-[…]}  /igira2\^mušen--e […]  X X /DI^?-\ A […]  lugal-ĝu10 ĝiš-gi daĝal mu-e-šum2 nunuz ki ḫa-ba-ni-ib-tag  ĝiš-gi daĝal-e tu-tu-ub-ba-ke4 nunuz ki ḫa-ba-ni-ib-tag  ambar-ra kiri8-tab^ki--a-ke4 nunuz ki ḫa-ba-ni-ib-tag  a-dar-ra akšak^ki--a-ke4 nunuz ki ḫa-ba-/ni\-[ib-tag]  sug zu2 keše2-da ^d-en-ki-ka3-ke4 nunuz ki ḫa-ba-ni-ib-tag  sug ban3-da sug eridug^ki--ga-ke4 nunuz ki ḫa-ba-ni-ib-tag  ^gi-bar-bar-a ^d-en-ki-ka3-ke4 nunuz ki ḫa-ba-ni-ib-tag  urim2^ki--ma gi-zi di4-di4-la2 nunuz ki ḫa-ba-ni-ib-tag  urim2^ki--ma ab2 lu amar lu-a re nunuz ki ḫa-ba-ni-ib-tag
en: {It dug in the ground, …… its head upwards …….} { The heron ……, …….} She  { entered the house and} cried out to King Enki: "My king, you gave me the wide reedbeds, and I laid eggs there. I laid eggs in the wide reedbeds of Tutub. I laid eggs in the marshes of Kiritaba. I laid eggs in the adara thickets of Akšak. I laid eggs in Enki's interconnecting lagoons. I laid eggs in the smaller lagoon, the lagoon of Eridug. I laid eggs in Enki's barbar reeds. I laid eggs in the little zi reeds of Urim. I laid eggs in Urim, where cows and calves abound."

akk: ud-bi-a niĝ2-bun2-na lu2 du14 mu2-a-ke4 lu2 ḫar-ra-an gig-ga-ke4  lu2 igi-ni-ta igi muš-a-ke4 lu2 ḫar-[ra-an gig-ga-ke4]  ka-ga14-ni-ta ka muš-a-ke4 lu2 ḫar-[ra-an gig-ga-ke4]  eme-a-ni-ta eme muš-a-ke4 lu2 ḫar-[ra-an gig-ga-ke4]  gug-a-ni gug ur tur-ra-ke4 lu2 [ḫar-ra-an gig-ga-ke4]  šu sal-sal-la  me-ri  sal-sal-la lu2 [ḫar-ra-an gig-ga-ke4]  niĝ2-bun2-na šeg12 udun-na-ke4 [lu2 ḫar-ra-an gig-ga-ke4]  šag4 mu2-sar-ra-ke4 lu2 ḫar-ra-an gig-ga-ke4  ^ĝiš-al-gin7 im-ma ud zal-la re [lu2 ḫar-ra-an gig-ga-ke4]  dusu saḫar-ra nu-luḫ-ḫa-e [lu2 ḫar-ra-an gig-ga-ke4]  niĝ2-bun2-na lu2-^ĝiš-ḫar-mušen-na lu2-dub3-ĝar-ra-e  igira2^mušen- gi du3-a-ĝu10 ba-ni-in-bur12-bur12
en: "Then the quarrelsome turtle, he of the troublesome way, he whose eyes are snake's eyes, he of the troublesome way, he whose mouth is a snake's mouth, he of the troublesome way, he whose tongue is a snake's tongue, he of the troublesome way, he whose bite is a puppy's bite, he of the troublesome way, he with the slender hands and slender feet, the turtle -- an oven brick -- he of the troublesome way, he who lives in the vegetable gardens, he of the troublesome way, he who like a digging tool spends his time in the mud, he of the troublesome way, an unwashed refuse-basket, he of the troublesome way, the turtle, the trapper of birds, the setter of nets, overthrew my heron's construction of reeds."

akk: gud3 us2-sa-a-ĝu10 ba-ni-in-suḫ3-suḫ3  dumu-ĝu10 a-e ba-ni-in-ra-ra  mušen-me-en lu2 igi ku10-ku10-ga-ke4  niĝ2-bun2-na saĝ-ki-ĝu10 umbin bi2-in-la2
en: "He turned my nest upside down, and tipped my children into the water. The turtle scratched my forehead -- me, the dark-eyed bird -- with its claws, so that my breast was covered with my blood { …… in the water}."

akk: nun-e sukkal ^d-isimud-ra gu3 mu-un-na-de2-e  sukkal ^d-isimud-ĝu10 mu dug3 an-na-ĝu10  /^d-en-ki-ra\ i3-gub-be2-en ud-ul a-ra-zu  [zi]-/pa\-tum a2 gabu2-ba u3-bi2-in-sur-ra  [pisaĝ] /zabar\-ra u3-bi2-in-dim2  [gi] šu-a ak gu-a am3-ši-šu2  […] X u3-mu-e-ši-la2  saĝ gu-še3 /gu\ u3-mu-e-ši-la2  de5-ga niĝ2-silaĝ-ĝa2-ka u3-mu-e-kal  ušur bar-ra a u3-mu-e-de6  sug zu2 keše2-da ^d-en-ki-ka3-ke4 [(X)] u3-mu-e-/ĝar\  [ud-bi]-/a\ niĝ2 […] NU UN šu-/gur\-ra ḫa-ba-tuš-e  […]-/ga\
en: The prince called to his minister, Isimud: "My minister, Isimud, my Sweet Name of Heaven!" "I stand at Enki's service! What is your wish?" "First …… is filtered on the left side, then a copper box is made, so that …… is covered. Then you tie ……, and you tie the top with string ……; then you …… with a piece of dough, and you irrigate the outer enclosure ; and you put …… Enki's interconnecting lagoons. Then let him sit …… 1 line missing1 line fragmentary"

akk: [^d-isimud-de3 … ĝizzal ba]-ši-in-ak  zi-pa-tum [a2 gabu2-ba u3-bi2]-in-sur-ra  pisaĝ zabar-ra [u3-bi2]-in-dim2  gi šu-a u3-bi2-in-šu2  saĝ gu-še3 gu um-ši-la2  de5-ga niĝ2-silaĝ-ĝa2 im-mi-in-kal^?-  ušur bar-ra a um-[mi]-in-de6  sug zu2 keše2-da ^d-en-ki-ka3-ke4 a im-/mi-in\-ra  ud-bi-a niĝ2 ĝe26-e nun-e im-/ma\-gub-gub-be2-en
en: Isimud …… paid attention. First he filtered …… on the left side, then he made a copper box and covered ……. Then he tied the top with string ……; then he …… with a piece of dough, and he irrigated the outer enclosure ; and he …… Enki's interconnecting lagoons.  "Then I, the prince, will make …… stand ……."

en: The turtle called to the prince: "You are a prince! She ……. …… from fire. I am not a god; …… 1 line fragmentary King Enki ……. You are a prince! She ……. My heart ……. You are a prince! She …… your word. My little one destroyed a wall ……; she ……. You are a prince! You are ……. …… brickwork. 16 lines missing Your flax is single 1 line unclearYour …… is single; ……. …… the hero ……. Your seed is single ……. …… a tall tree. My strong copper ……. …… good semen ……"

en: Then, on the ziggurat ……. King Enki was …… on the ziggurat. The great brickwork of the ziggurat …… the abzu; the brickwork of the abzu ……. He took dirt from his fingernail and created the dimgi vegetable. He made the dimgi …… in the ground. Your flax came out of the earth ……. He watered the little ones with his hand; he watered the big ones with his foot. The flax grew large. After the flax had grown tall, after he had bound it …… 1 line fragmentary 6 lines missing The king ……. 1 line fragmentary 1 line missing3 lines fragmentary They seized …… for him. They …… for him. They confronted …… in the desert. 1 line unclear ……, they laid out the hunting net. …… did not catch; he caught in the hunting net, …… did not catch; he spread out the hunting net. 5 lines fragmentary …… of Enki 1 line fragmentary May you be ……; may you be ……; may you be ……; may you be …… unknown no. of lines missing
